text: Remarkable food with beach access for the whole family, flip flops acceptable.  You step up to the counter, order, get a number and bus you own food to a table inside or out.  The locals know about this place and really love it just as we did on our first visit.  Highly recommended.  Probably good enough to drive from Santa Barbara to eat here.  Local beer on tap, kids are more than welcome.

I loved everything about this lovely train station.  The staff was friendly and helpful.  The station was beautiful.  Every aspect of passing through was wonderful.  It is a great place.  Thank you Philadelphia for making our vacation special and providing such a great place.

The classic facade, built over an earlier facing, was copied from a first century Roman book, Spanish edition, published in Madrid 1787.  The three statues, left, right and top represent Faith, Hope and Charity.  The fourth added in 1927 is Santa Barbara.  Of all the 21 mission this one is the most imposing and offers a large open space in front for the admiration of this structure.

The Praline Connection makes a mean po' boy.  The restaurant is located just outside the French Market on Frenchman St, in a lower-key, musically-influenced area of town.  I was looking forward to trying out their fried oyster po' boy, but unfortunately, the restaurant was out of oysters.  They use only Louisiana oysters and because of the oil spill in the Gulf, they cannot serve any dishes with oysters.  Boo.

I subbed in a fish (catfish, I assume) po' boy instead and it was delectable.  It had catfish, shredded lettuce, slices of tomato, mayo, and pickles, inside a loaf of French bread.  With a side of fries, it was yummy and filling.

Small note on the fries: the menus have printed the fries are only $1.50 extra when ordered with a po' boy.  However, the restaurant charged us $2.00 and the server told us there was a sign out front that noted the change.  The menus still say $1.50 though.  The restaurant needs to correct this.  How are you just going to leave incorrect pricing in your menu (50 cents isn't a lot, but it's the principle)?

We were told by our waitress to try their fried chicken next time.  The waiters and waitresses are dressed in white dress shirts and black slacks with black top hats and suspenders.  The floor is tiled in black and white tiles.  The restaurant is connected to a small praline/candy shop where you can buy fresh daily-made pralines.  The pralines are about $2 apiece.  I bought a few of the original on my way out and they were pretty good.  Super sugary for sure.

We walked over to Tennessee Brew Works, one of Nashville's popular craft breweries, after hitting up Jack White's Third Man Records shop nearby. Both businesses are located in Pie Town, a neighborhood on the southern edge of downtown Nashville. There's not a whole lot of stuff in this part of town. These are definitely two of the highlights.

Tennessee Brew Works opened on August 18, 2013. It's popular. This place has won numerous awards and earned plenty of recognition including the best brewery in Tennessee according to Yelp. These folks are all about being local, green, and sustainable. The taproom is two stories with views of the brewery from both floors. There's a patio with both covered and uncovered spaces (mostly uncovered) as well as a small, string-lit rooftop patio. As this is a brewery, the property has an industrial, warehouse feel to it, much like the other businesses in Pie Town. It's clean and modernized. The first floor of the brewery features a small stage for live music (a band was setting up on our way out) and the room upstairs, which is much more spacious, has TVs playing sports and nice overhead views of the brewery floor below.

Brewery tours take place every Saturday at 3pm, 4pm, and 5pm. It costs $10 plus tax and a fee per person. Tickets for the tour can be purchased online.

Along with high-quality craft beer, the brewery also serves food. Their limited menu includes apps/snacks like Baja fish tacos, Springer Mountain chicken wings, salads, burgers, and sandwiches (including a Nashville Hot Chicken Sandwich). Food prices range from $8 to $18 per plate.

We grabbed a few beers and hung out inside the taproom downstairs. Downstairs, they use barrels (some with tabletops) for tables with bar stools. We showed up around 2pm on a Saturday and the place was busy. It wasn't slammed or jam-packed, but most of the tables upstairs and downstairs were taken. Our group of six was lucky to find a table in a corner next to some brewery windows. The atmosphere was very relaxed and laid back. The staff was cool and friendly. We all enjoyed our time here.

I don't think Tennessee Brew Works has dedicated parking. We parked for free on the street (Middleton Street because we also went to Third Man Records). This isn't the nicest neighborhood so I wouldn't leave any valuables in your car.

Logan Circle, also known as Logan Square, is a public park located in the center of the Logan Square neighborhood (yes, same name) in Philadelphia. It's managed by the city's Parks & Rec department. This is a great sightseeing spot in Philly. I recommend it. The views are beautiful.

Some quick Q&A:

1. Why is it called Logan Circle?

Because it serves as a major traffic circle for Benjamin Franklin Parkway (https://www.yelp.com/biz/ben-franklin-parkway-philadelphia), connecting it to North 19th Street, Vine Street, and Race Street.

2. Why is it called Logan Square?

Because it was one of five squares originally planned for the city in 1864 by William Penn, founder of Pennsylvania.

3. Who is the circle/square named after?

James Logan, 14th mayor of Philadelphia.

Logan Circle is actually surrounded by three other parks: Aviator Park, Sister Cities Park, and Shakespeare Park (small). Combined, the land area for these four parks, including the roads (Benjamin Franklin Parkway is wide and scenic) is about four city blocks. So for a city park, it's not huge, but not small neither.

The highlight of Logan Circle is a large fountain in the center called the Swann Memorial Fountain: https://www.yelp.com/biz/swann-memorial-fountain-philadelphia-2. We visited on a bright and sunny Sunday afternoon and the park was filled with people, both locals and tourists. Even though there were signs that said no swimming in the fountain, I can't tell you how many kids I saw swimming and playing in the fountain. A lot. It almost looked more like a pool or water park than a historic fountain.

Logan Circle is centrally-located between Philadelphia City Hall and the Philadelphia Museum of Art (Rocky Steps: https://www.yelp.com/biz/rocky-steps-philadelphia). Benjamin Franklin Parkway connects all of it. If you've never been to Philly before and want to sight-see, I think walking the parkway between city hall and the museum is a must. Including the aforementioned adjacent parks, Logan Circle is surrounded by sights and attractions including the Franklin Institute, the Academy of Natural Sciences of Drexel University, and the Cathedral Basilica of Saints Peter and Paul.

Note: At the time of writing this review, there's another Yelp listing for Logan Circle. It's called Logan Square Park: https://www.yelp.com/biz/logan-square-park-philadelphia. Technically, the two listings should be merged, but the Yelp moderators disagree.

I had a great experience with Assurant. I purchased my old Google Pixel phone from the Google Store (online). One of the options I could add to my phone was Device Protection for $99. Device protection is the same thing as phone insurance and Assurant was the provider.

The coverage I purchased was good for two years from the date I received my phone. The maximum number of accidental damage repairs or replacements under Device Protection was two during the coverage period. My Pixel's camera lenses, both front and back, got scratched. The scratches caused light streaks in my photos and videos so I decided to file a claim and get a replacement.

Per the Device Protection welcome and terms and conditions email I got from Assurant, I filed my claim at https://mydeviceprotect.com/. It was really quick and easy to do, especially since Assurant had most of my information on file from my phone's IMEI/serial number. I filed my claim on a Friday night. In less than 24 hours, someone from Assurant called to verify my information and approve my claim. I received a claim approval email after the call and a shipping notification that Monday (first business day after my claim was approved). I received my replacement Pixel on Tuesday afternoon; basically, in two business days. Fast!

I did have to pay a $79 deductible, but it was totally worth it to me. It was like I got a brand new Pixel for only $178 ($99 for Device Protection + $79 deductible). Technically, the phone was refurbished, but it looked and worked like new - the battery too, which was huge, since my old battery was on its way out. Considering my particular phone model at the time, a 32-GB Pixel 1, originally retailed for $649, I thought this was a good deal. Plus, I had one more replacement remaining on my contract before my two years were up. It was nice to have that peace of mind.

Google made it easy to transfer all of my apps and data from my old Pixel to my new Pixel. I just connected the two phones with a USB-C cable and followed the prompts. The entire transfer took about an hour (my new Pixel had to download and install almost 100 apps). I was really pleased with how simple and seamless the transition was. My old phone was essentially mirrored to my new one which was exactly what I wanted. I did have to set up new fingerprint recognition and log in to all of my apps again, but that was it. I was back up and running with a "new" phone with hardly any interruption.

I returned my old Pixel in the same packaging that my new Pixel came in. Assurant emailed me a shipping label to print and tape to the outside of the box. I had to return my old Pixel within 14 days from the date my new Pixel was shipped. Otherwise, I could've been charged an "unrecovered equipment fee" of up to $2,000.

In the end, I am very happy with the Device Protection I purchased from Assurant. I already bought it again for my latest phone, the Pixel 3, for $129 (unsurprisingly, the insurance price went up).

The Philadelphia Phillies are one of the oldest American professional sports franchises, established in 1883. Unlike other storied teams, the Fightin' Phils have never left their original city.

It took nearly 100 years, but the Phillies were able to win their first World Series championship in 1980 and then again, 28 years later, in 2008. In 1980, future Hall-of-Famer and perhaps the greatest third baseman of all time, Mike Schmidt, led Philadelphia to a 4-2 series win over the Kansas City Royals. In 2008, four-time All-Star pitcher Cole Hamels led Philly in a dominating series performance over the Tampa Bay Rays, 4-1. (Since 2020, Hamels has played for my favorite team, the Atlanta Braves.)

The Phillies play at Citizens Bank Park, located in South Philly. The ballpark opened in 2004 and is part of the South Philadelphia Sports Complex which includes the adjacent Lincoln Financial Field (home of the NFL's Philadelphia Eagles) and Wells Fargo Center (home of the NBA's Philadelphia 76ers). You can see the complex from the interstate (I-95) as you drive into the city from the airport. It's just across the Delaware River from New Jersey.

The Phillies haven't done well since 2011, the last year they made the playoffs. From 2012 to present, they've yet to finish a single season above .500 (they finished at exactly .500 twice, in 2012 and 2019), a far cry from their 2008 championship. However, the Charlie Manuel (manager) years (2005-2013), immediately preceding the current playoff drought, comprise a great era in Philadelphia's baseball history. Under Manuel, the Phillies made the playoffs five straight seasons (including that '08 World Series title), had first baseman Ryan Howard named NL Rookie of the Year in 2005 and then NL MVP the following year in 2006, shortstop Jimmy Rollins named NL MVP in 2007, and pitcher Roy Halladay named NL Cy Young Award winner in 2010. Unfortunately, the team hasn't been the same since Manuel's firing during the 2013 season.

At the time of writing this review, the Phillies have an all-time win percentage of .472 (9,853 wins against 11,032 losses).

We stayed at the Courtyard by Marriott Philadelphia Plymouth Meeting and really enjoyed our stay. Everyone at the hotel seemed nice, especially Kim, the lady who checked us in. Kim set the tone and was really welcoming and affable. The hotel and amenities were nice considering the tier of hotel and price paid. We were part of a wedding block and were charged $119.90 per night after taxes. Not bad.

If you're not familiar with Philadelphia, this hotel is located in the suburbs northwest of town. There's plenty of free parking and the hotel is located within walking distance of a big shopping mall, Plymouth Meeting Mall, that is anchored in part by a Whole Foods. Aside from the mall, if you don't have a car, you're going to have to Lyft/Uber to get anywhere.

This Courtyard by Marriott is four stories. Our room was 335 on the 3rd floor. It was a "KSOF" (king with sofa bed) room with a view of the parking lot and office building to the north. The hotel is surrounded by several office buildings so I suspect a lot of business travelers stay here to work at those buildings.

From the outside, the hotel looks like your standard Courtyard by Marriott. Inside, it looks like some renovation work has been done. The place was clean and looked fairly modern. While there's no full-service restaurant or shop, there is a fast-casual counter where you can order made-to-order food and drinks, a small retail corner with grab-and-go items, some dining and lounge-like areas, and a business center of sorts. There's also an indoor pool, hot tub, and gym. The gym is tiny. Outside in the back is a little courtyard with nice landscaping and additional seating. It's worth exploring and checking out.

When we checked in, Kim handed us two bottles of water and two Peanut Chews, delicious candy bars that are manufactured in Pennsylvania.

Our room was clean and comfy, and contemporary in design. The toiletries, such as the shampoo, conditioner, and body wash, were Paul Mitchell Tea Tree brand. The bathroom had a standard tub and shower with a floor that was tastefully tiled. The bed was very comfortable, from the soft-yet-firm mattress to the silky-smooth and smell-good sheets. There was an artsy-looking couch (sofa bed) with a conveniently-angled end table. The office desk was extendable which was great for more surface space. The TV was a smart TV with apps like Netflix and YouTube installed. There was a coffee maker, iron and ironing board, luggage rack, and hair dryer. The Wi-Fi was free and fast enough. And there was free, self-serve, tasty coffee and fruit-flavored ice water in the lobby.

Standard check-in time is 3pm and check-out is 12pm. I used the Marriott Bonvoy app to keep track of my reservation and make an early check-in (12pm) request. The hotel (Kim) was quick to respond to my chat messages in the app and she remembered me from our chat conversation when I showed up in person to check-in. I like how they stay on top of that. Saturday night, when the lobby was used for the wedding after-party, I called in a request for additional toiletries and housekeeping was reasonably quick to respond despite the craziness going on downstairs. I appreciated that.

Overall, I think this is a very good mid-tier hotel. I recommend it.

In terms of points percentage, the Philadelphia Flyers are currently the third-most successful team of the 31 active teams in the NHL. The Flyers won back-to-back Stanley Cups in 1974 and 1975. The team's number of championships (2) is tied for 11th best in the league. Historically, the Flyers have been a perennial playoff team. All time, the team ranks in the top 10 in total playoff seasons. However, over the last decade, the Flyers have only made the playoffs on average about every other year. All things considered, Philadelphia has been home to one of the NHL's better-performing franchises.

The Flyers are among the NHL's second-oldest members. They were part of the second wave of franchises that joined during the league's 1967 expansion. That expansion saw the league size double from six teams (the Original Six) to 12 teams. Of the 1967 expansion teams, Philadelphia was the first to win the Stanley Cup. Another 1967 expansion team, the in-state rival Pittsburgh Penguins, have won the Stanley Cup five times (the most of any of the expansion teams from that year). After winning back-to-back titles in 1974 and 1975, the Flyers went on to appear in six more Stanley Cup Finals, the latest in 2010.

Four of the Flyers' six retired jersey numbers belong to players who won the Stanley Cup. They include goaltender Bernie Parent, defenseman Barry Ashbee, left-winger Bill Barber, and center Bobby Clarke. Parent is a legend among goalies and a Philadelphia sports icon. Clarke was the captain of both teams that won the Stanley Cup. Parent, Barber, and Clarke were all inducted into the Hockey Hall of Fame. Ashbee was a member of the 1974 championship team, but his career was unfortunately cut short from an eye injury he suffered in the Flyers' series preceding the Stanley Cup Finals. Tragically, only about three years later, Ashbee passed away from leukemia at age 37.

The Flyers' home arena is the Wells Fargo Center. With a present seating capacity of 19,600 (the number can vary depending on where you look; 19,600 is from the Wells Fargo Center website), the Wells Fargo Center is the fourth-biggest arena in the NHL. The Flyers and the NBA's Philadelphia 76ers have been the building's only two full-time occupants since the building opened in 1996. The seating capacity for Sixers games is slightly larger at 21,000. Wells Fargo Center is part of the South Philadelphia Sports Complex which includes Lincoln Financial Field (Philadelphia Eagles; NFL) and Citizens Bank Park (Philadelphia Phillies; MLB).

#AnytimeAnywhere

I'm rating the Edmonton Oilers five stars based on their dominance from 1983 to 1990. Sadly, Edmonton has only made the playoffs twice since losing to the Carolina Hurricanes in a heartbreaking Game 7 in the 2006 Stanley Cup Finals. However, their history in the 80s cannot be denied. The Oilers won the Cup five times in seven years: 1984, 1985, 1987, 1988, and 1990. To date, the Oilers are tied with the Pittsburgh Penguins for the sixth-most number of Stanley Cup championships. The Oilers and the Penguins have the most NHL titles outside of the Original Six. A finer point, the Oilers franchise did not join the NHL until 1979 while the Penguins were part of the league's 1967 expansion. It's impressive how many championships Edmonton racked up after being a member of the NHL for only about a decade.

"The Great One" Wayne Gretzky, started his NHL career with Edmonton. He is the franchise's all-time scoring leader in both goals (583) and points (1,669). Unlike many of the great hockey players today, Gretzky was not drafted. He played in the now-defunct World Hockey Association (WHA) for Edmonton for one season before the WHA folded. After that, the Oilers joined the NHL and the rest is history. Gretzky won all four of his Stanley Cups with Edmonton. He left the team in 1988 when he was traded by the Oilers to the Los Angeles Kings. The Oilers would go on to win the following Stanley Cup without him and Gretzky would never win another Cup again.

Today, Connor McDavid is the Oilers' best player. He's currently considered one of the best players in hockey. Edmonton drafted him with the No. 1 overall pick in the 2015 NHL Entry Draft. Already, McDavid has won the Hart Memorial Trophy (NHL regular season MVP in 2017; Gretzky won the Hart Trophy nine times), the Ted Lindsay Award twice (NHL regular season most outstanding player in 2017 and 2018), and the Art Ross Trophy twice (NHL regular season most points in 2017 and 2018). He was also on the cover of EA Sports NHL 18. He's quickly climbing up in the franchise record books.

The Oilers' current home is Rogers Place, located in downtown Edmonton. Opened in 2016, Rogers Place is one of the NHL's newest arenas. It has over 1,250 TV screens and the largest HD center ice scoreboard in the league. For hockey, Rogers Place has a seating capacity of 18,347. The Edmonton Oil Kings of the Western Hockey League (WHL) have also called Rogers Place home since 2016. Both teams are owned by Daryl Katz.

If you've never been to Philadelphia Chinatown before, it's worth checking out. It's located just one block away from Philadelphia City Hall and is adjacent to the very popular Reading Terminal Market, so it's convenient to other must-see spots in the city.

By my count, Chinatown takes up about 21 city blocks. The Pennsylvania Convention Center takes up roughly a quarter of the neighborhood. Like other Chinatowns in big American cities, Philly's Chinatown is relatively old and densely-packed. Food is a big draw, of course, with restaurants serving not only Chinese food like dim sum and Peking duck, but also Japanese ramen and yakitori, Korean fried chicken, Malaysian, Thai, and Vietnamese cuisine, and vegetarian food. There are also Asian bakeries and bubble tea galore.

The official entrance to Chinatown is located on the south side of the neighborhood on N 10th St at Arch St. The gate is known as the Friendship Gate or Friendship Arch (https://www.yelp.com/biz/chinatown-friendship-gate-philadelphia). It's a vehicular gate and, ironically, traffic flows only one-way: out of Chinatown. N 10th St is also home to the Chinese Cultural & Community Center as well as the Mandarin-language campus of the Chinese Christian Church & Center (https://www.yelp.com/biz/chinese-christian-church-and-center-philadelphia-2).

I attended a wedding at the church's Vine Campus which is less than a five-minute walk away. Vine St forms Chinatown's north border with N Broad St to the west, N 7th St to the east, and Arch St to the south. The neighborhood immediately north of Chinatown, Callowhill, is referred to by many as Chinatown North. The Asian Arts Initiative, a non-profit community and arts center, is located there (https://www.yelp.com/biz/asian-arts-initiative-philadelphia).

If you want to sight-see and explore Chinatown, N 10th St at Race St is a good place to start. From there, there's a lot of stuff to see in every direction.

In addition to being close to City Hall and Reading Terminal Market, Chinatown is also only a block away from the National Constitution Center, Independence National Historical Park, and other historic spots on the east side of town.

I've reviewed a lot of things on Yelp, from bridges and tunnels (http://bit.ly/2YCOtxX) to gas stations (http://bit.ly/2GXPRAi), but never a gate. This is my first review of a gate.

The Chinatown Friendship Gate, also known as the Chinatown Friendship Arch and the China Gate, is the "official" entrance to Philadelphia's Chinatown. The gate is located on N 10th St at Arch St. It's 40 feet tall and weighs 88 tons. It's called the Friendship Gate because it symbolizes the friendship between Philly and its sister city in China, Tianjin. The gate officially "opened" (was dedicated) in January 1984 with a rededication in 2008.

This is a neat landmark and worth checking out if you've never been to Philly Chinatown before. It's ornate and colorful and makes for a nice photo/selfie. The architectural style comes from the Ming (1368 to 1644) and Qing (1644 to 1912) dynasties. I think Philly's Chinatown gate trumps San Francisco's Chinatown gate, Dragon Gate (http://bit.ly/2Yy21uu), in terms of size and decor, but SF's gate is actually three gates in one (two gates for pedestrians and one for vehicles). This gate is built over vehicular traffic only: two one-way car lanes and one one-way bike lane, all heading south out of Chinatown and into Center City.

If you're visiting Philly from out of town, I recommend going to Tea Do (http://bit.ly/2M9XSWV) one block north of the gate and Reading Terminal Market (http://bit.ly/2OOoUFG) two blocks east.

After leaving a review for this gate, I realized I never left one for the SF version (http://bit.ly/2Yy21uu). Now I have to do it.

The Roosevelt is an elegant and grand old-school hotel.  As soon as you step through the revolving doors, you feel like you're in a luxurious five-star hotel from the 1930s.  Crystal chandeliers and large columns run the length of the long hallway-like lobby with beautiful mosaic tile on the floor, marbled walls and ornate ceilings, fine furniture, etc.  The elevators are tiny.  The hallways to the rooms are wide with decorated carpet and more chandeliers.  The hallways remind me of the the hallways from the hotel in the movie "The Shining."

The rooms are equipped with Samsung plasma TVs, crystal lamps, views of downtown New Orleans, TVs in the bathrooms, walk-in closets with full ironing boards, and more.  The maids are dressed in traditional black and white French maid outfits, which is a nice touch.  There is complimentary Wi-Fi Internet for Hilton Gold and Diamond members.  The Roosevelt is part of the Waldorf Astoria collection of hotels.  The hotel is tucked down a quiet street just around the corner from Bourbon St, making it a great location to stay if you're visiting town and want to be near the French Quarter.

Drago's was a bit disappointing.  The restaurant is known for their charbroiled oysters which were created by Drago Cvitanovich himself.  The oysters are prepared with garlic, parsley, butter, black pepper, and two cheeses.  I ordered a dozen of these, but only received 10.  After letting the server know, he (eventually) brought out three additional oysters.

The charbroiled oysters were hot off the grill, very buttery, and quite tasty.  However, many of the oysters were quite small (the key to good charbroiled oysters is to use big fat oysters).  At $16.95 for one dozen, it may not have been worth it.

We also tried to order raw oysters of which they had none.  Our server tried to explain to us why they did not have raw oysters and all we could surmise from his explanation was that there were not a sufficient number of oyster boats due to the BP oil spill, but he also mentioned something about a one-hour refrigeration time, so it left us a bit confused.  Oh well.  No raw oysters = bad.

Drago's serves higher-end Creole cuisine and also specializes in a variety of lobster dishes.  The restaurant is located at the ground level of the Hilton.  They do not take reservations (first-come, first-serve only).  The restaurant is popular and thus service can be slow.  Valet parking is available, but if you are staying anywhere near the French Quarter, you can walk it.

When I think of Hattie B's Hot Chicken, my mouth waters. I love spicy food and who doesn't love fried chicken? The combination is truly mouthwatering and delicious. I'm getting hungry just writing this review.

Since 2012, Hattie B's has grown into a small chain specializing in Nashville hot chicken. This location, in the Melrose neighborhood of Nashville, is the company's third and newest location in the city. It's relatively new, having opened less than a year ago (November 2017). A location recently opened in July 2018 where I live in Atlanta. At the time of writing this review, the chain's newest location opened last month in August 2018 inside The Cosmopolitan in Las Vegas.

While Hattie B's isn't the originator of Nashville hot chicken (Prince's Hot Chicken Shack was the first and many say they do it better), Hattie B's has done a lot to popularize it in the last six-plus years.

We visited this location on a Friday shortly after the business opened at 11am. This was my first visit to a Hattie B's and I heard the restaurants often have long lines/waits. Since we arrived early, we barely had to wait. This is a fast-casual joint where you place your order and pay upfront at the counter and then wait for your food to be served to you. Fountain drinks, tea, and lemonade are self-serve.

The ample seating at this location - it's got a spacious dining room and covered patio - was the main reason we chose to come to this location over the other two in Nashville. It turned out to be the right choice. The place was mostly empty when we arrived, but was packed with a line out the door and spilling onto the sidewalk when we left shortly after 12pm. So, if you want to avoid a wait, arrive early.

The restaurant itself looks great. It looks like new construction. A functional, modern design with a somewhat vintage Southern feel. There's a fenced-in lawn outside, next to the patio, with umbrella-covered picnic tables and cornhole. TVs inside and out. It was nice and clean during our visit.

Hattie B's serves hot chicken plates that come with different types of chicken, two Southern sides, bread, and pickles for anywhere from $8.50 for a small dark plate (leg/thigh quarter) to $13.50 for a large white plate (two breast/wing quarters). They also serve wings, tenders, and chicken sandwiches ($9 per sammie). With the hot chicken, you can go with zero heat or choose from five heat levels, ranging in spicy intensity from "Mild" ("touch of heat") to "Shut the Cluck Up!!!" ("burn notice").

Desserts include classics like banana pudding, peach cobbler, and floats ($3 each). Aside from the aforementioned non-alcoholic drinks, they serve beer (draft, canned, and bottled) too. Finally, on Sundays from 11am to 4pm, you can get chicken and waffles ($11-16 each) and bacon cheese grits.

We ordered a bunch of stuff. Here are the things I tried:

* Small dark plate (leg/thigh quarter at medium heat) with pimento mac & cheese and Southern greens ($8.50)
* Tenders plate ($9.50) - three jumbo tenders (two at medium heat, one at hot) with crinkle-cut fries and creamy coleslaw
* Large white plate (two breasts/wing quarters) with baked beans and Southern greens ($13.50)
* One additional tender ($2) at "Shut the Cluck Up!!!" spicy
* Peach cobbler ($3)

The chicken and sides were yummy. Every piece of chicken, whether it was dark meat, white meat, or a tender was packed with flavor and spice. In terms of enjoyment level, I liked the medium and hot spice levels the best. In terms of taste, I thought the dark meat, naturally, tasted the best. The leg and thigh were tender, juicy, and extra savory. The batter on the dark meat chicken was most crispy and crunchy. Just excellent.

The tenders were my second-favorite followed by the white meat chicken (breast and wing). All chicken types came with a good portion of meat, particularly the white meat. Despite being white meat, the breast and wing still had a good bit of crunch on the outside and moistness and tenderness on the inside. It was good stuff.

One bite of the "Shut the Cluck Up!!!" tender and my mouth was definitely on fire, but not a sensation I haven't felt before (being a lover of spicy food). However, there comes a point where food gets so spicy that you can no longer taste the food and only feel the heat. At that point, it's not enjoyable anymore. That's what Hattie B's "Shut the Cluck Up!!!" is. It's legitimately very spicy, but I don't recommend it to most people unless one just wants to try it for the experience.

Each order of chicken, even the lone tender, were customarily served atop a slice of white bread with two pickles toothpicked on top of the meat.

As for the sides and dessert, they were OK to great. My favorites (great) were the Southern greens (with pepper sauce), baked beans, and peach cobbler. The pimento mac & cheese was good while the creamy coleslaw was just alright (I don't really recommend the latter). Overall, the ingredients were fresh and solid quality.

Philadelphia City Hall is massive and impressive. Completed in 1901, it's the largest city hall in America, covering 14.5 acres of total floor space and rising high at 548 feet (it was the tallest building in Philadelphia until 1986). The building is topped with an enormous statue of William Penn, founder of Philadelphia and Pennsylvania. This statue is its most notable and defining feature. It's situated so high, you can see it from many different places within the city.

City Hall has made appearances in numerous films including, most recently, the DC superhero movie Shazam! (2019). Something funny happens to William Penn in the movie. https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0448115/

There was also a curse associated with the William Penn statue known as the Curse of Billy Penn. I first learned about it while watching the Rocky location tour documentary Rocky Jumped a Park Bench: https://youtu.be/ryGnmGKbRFo?t=757. In the documentary, host James Rolfe (more famously known as the Angry Video Game Nerd) explains that Philadelphia sports teams were cursed because there was another building in the city that was built higher than William Penn. That curse was broken when the Phillies won the 2008 World Series. Less than 10 years later, the Eagles would go on to win Super Bowl LII (2018). In college sports, Villanova won the 2016 and 2018 NCAA men's basketball championships.

Two tours are available for City Hall, the Interior Tour and the Tower Tour. The Interior Tour lasts about 1.5 to 2 hours and includes the Tower Tour. The Tower Tour, where you go to the top of the tower for amazing city views, is also available separately. Currently, an adult ticket costs $15 for the Interior Tour and $8 for the Tower Tour (less for military, seniors, and students). Visit the City Hall Visitor Center at 1 S Penn Square, Room 121 and the Independence Visitor Center's website for more info: https://www.phlvisitorcenter.com/CityHall.

No trip to City Hall is complete without visiting the two relatively new/renovated parks nearby, Dilworth Park (https://www.yelp.com/biz/dilworth-park-philadelphia-9) and Love Park (https://www.yelp.com/biz/love-park-philadelphia). If you're sightseeing in Philly, these and walking up the Benjamin Franklin Parkway (https://www.yelp.com/biz/ben-franklin-parkway-philadelphia) to the Rocky Steps (https://www.yelp.com/biz/rocky-steps-philadelphia) and the Philadelphia Museum of Art (https://www.yelp.com/biz/philadelphia-museum-of-art-philadelphia) are highly recommended.

A couple of our friends live at Hanover North Broad and it seems like a great in-the-city apartment in Philadelphia. The apartments are located in the north central part of Center City, just one block north of Chinatown. They're relatively new, having opened in 2017.

At the time of writing this review, monthly rents start at $1,714 for a 529-square-foot 1 bed/1 bath. 2/2s range from $2,460 for 1,146 square feet to $3,894 for 1,782 square feet with two balconies. Not cheap, but these are "luxury" apartments in a prime location with numerous amenities. Amenities include a private clubhouse, billiards/pool table, theater, conference and dining room, gym, courtyards with grills and outdoor fireplaces, bocce, and more. No concierge or swimming pool, however. The apartments have upscale, modern designs with vaulted ceilings. The apartment entrances are interior hallway entrances only.

One thing that's unique and quirky about Hanover North Broad is the apartment complex is separated into two completely separate buildings. N Broad St, which is a major 6-lane street, splits the two buildings. Our friends live in the East Building, so if they want to go to the gym, they have to cross over a busy street.

We spent most of our time hanging out and lounging around at the East Building's elevated courtyard. This courtyard was clean with manicured landscaping, bocce, cushioned seating, tables, grills, and cabanas with nice TVs. We couldn't get the fireplace working. I'm not sure what was wrong with it. I was hoping the courtyard would have a nice city view or a view of the street below, but it does not. I'm not sure why they designed it that way; probably because there's not much to look at on Carlton St.

Both buildings have parking garages that are open to the public for a fee (the ground level of the two buildings includes retail). The East Building garage was brightly lit and felt clean and safe enough. The spaces are tight, not uncommon for big city decks.

The leasing office is located in the West Building which is also the bigger building of the two.

We enjoyed our breakfast at Sabrina's Cafe and Spencer's Too in Logan Square, Center City. This local restaurant chain was recommended to us by three separate friends as one of Philadelphia's best spots for breakfast and brunch (they serve lunch and dinner too). The food was good and service was great. While I don't think this place is *significantly* better than other popular and highly-regarded brunch restaurants I've tried, it's still definitely worth checking out if you want American breakfast/brunch comfort food. The food is delicious, though heavy, and the portions are huge and filling.

There are five Sabrina's locations in the Delaware Valley including three in Philly proper. This location is the second and it opened in 2007 (the first opened in 2001). Sabrina's is named after the owners' daughter. This particular location has "and Spencer's Too" in the name because of the owners' son, who was born later. We chose to dine at this location because it was close to our hotel, the Philadelphia 201, which is only a couple blocks away; a short walk. If you're staying at this hotel or anywhere nearby, I do recommend Sabrina's for breakfast/brunch.

I heard this place gets packed with waits the norm. We showed up bright and early on a Monday morning just before opening (8am). A small crowd had already built up on the sidewalk in front of the entrance. When the doors opened, all of us were seated immediately. This place has plenty of space. It has a diner feel to it. You can sit at the counter with its cushioned and pattern-upholstered chairs or at one of the numerous small tables or booths. The atmosphere is casual and homey. There's a tiled coffee bar and lampshades with floral designs.

During our visit, the large blackboard menu on the dining room's center wall featured chalk drawings of Sonic and Knuckles (random). Specials included chicken and waffles ($14.95) and dinner entrees like seafood scampi ($15.95) and goat cheese penne pasta ($14.95). We also received a seasonal drink menu and monthly food specials.

Sabrina's signature breakfast items are the huevos rancheros ($11.79), stuffed challah French toast ($11.99), and "The Tots" ($12.59). Other breakfast/brunch foods include eggs, frittatas, omelettes, pancakes, bagels and lox, housemade granola, avocado toast, and a quinoa bowl. Most of these other items cost about the same or less than the signature items. Most non-breakfast/brunch food includes soups and salads and burgers and sandwiches. Expect to spend about $11-13 each for those items. They have a kids menu too. Beverage-wise, they offer coffee and espresso-based drinks, teas, fresh juices, and Jones brand "craft" soda.

We ordered two signature items and a couple seasonal drinks:

* Stuffed Challah French Toast ($11.99) with farmer's cream cheese topped with bananas and vanilla bean syrup
* The Tots ($12.59) - fried panko-encrusted tater tots topped with grilled hot sausage hash; caramelized onions, bell peppers, and fennel seed; topped with basil chimichurri, sour cream, and over-easy eggs
* Cookie Butter Iced Mocha ($4.79) - cookie butter, dark chocolate, espresso, and milk
* Iced Strawberry Mocha ($4.79) - strawberry, dark chocolate, espresso, and milk

The food was great. I preferred the Stuffed Challah French Toast over The Tots, but I could change my mind given the day. The French toast was outstanding. The best thing about it to me was the filling: farmer's cream cheese. I'm a cream cheese fan in general, but this particular cream cheese was lighter and less dense than your typical American cream cheese. Its silky smooth texture trended towards whipped cream. Overall, wonderful flavor when combined with the vanilla bean syrup (I love vanilla). Ripe slices of banana and a bit of cinnamon and powdered sugar were thrown on top. The consistency of the French toast itself was soft, springy, and appetizing. I recommend this dish.

The Tots was heavy, but satisfying. It's a lot of food packed into a medium-sized bowl. The panko-encrusted tater tots were bigger than average tots. They were like tots on steroids. The ingredients, particularly the hot sausage hash and the over-easy eggs, came out temperature hot from the kitchen. I had to wait for the bowl to cool down a bit. This one was a savory, greasy smorgasbord of textures and flavors. I had the tots with ketchup and ate the rest of the dish with various hot sauces at the table (Cholula, Frank's RedHot, Sriracha). If you have a ravenous appetite, The Tots is for you; it's packed with lots of carbs and protein.

The iced mochas were good. They were expectedly sweet; almost too sweet for me (and I have a sweet tooth). I liked the Cookie Butter Iced Mocha better than the Strawberry. Both drinks were rich, flavorful, and refreshing. The dark chocolate flavor was strong. If you order these, you might ask if you can adjust the sweetness.

Patricia was our server and she was attentive and sweet. The hostess was nice too.

I'd come back.

Paradise Park Trailer Resort is a honky-tonk bar and restaurant that opened on Lower Broadway in downtown Nashville in 2007. I visited this past Friday night and learned, later on in the weekend, that this place is closing soon. It's supposed to close this month (July 2018) so I wanted to get my review out before they closed.

We showed up just before midnight on Friday and this place was packed. The line to get in wasn't very long, but it was very crowded inside, especially on the first floor. There were two bands, one on the first floor (ground level) as soon as you walk in and one inside on the rooftop (fourth level). I believe both bands were cover bands (definitely the band on the top floor; I remember one song they sang was the Alien Ant Farm version of Smooth Criminal). Both bands were pretty good and most people seemed to be having a good time.

There are a lot of lights and neon signs on Broadway. You can't miss Paradise Park's sign because it's one of the biggest. It's green and red and spans over two stories. It's one of the most prominent signs on the street. The space has colorful and kitschy decor (neon signs, string lights, Christmas lights, a disco ball, and more). Just inside the entrance is a photo booth and Skee-Ball. During our visit, the second and third floors were closed. The second floor was home to a dueling piano bar called The Big Bang.

We spent most of our time on the rooftop patio which was a lot more laid back and relaxed than downstairs. The rooftop has both an interior and exterior bar. The outdoor portion of the rooftop is covered in artificial turf with picnic tables, lawn/porch chairs, and high tops for seating. There was always a game of cornhole going on while we were up there. The highlight, to me, is the view from the rooftop. You get to see the beautiful downtown Nashville cityscape as well as all of the activity below on Broadway. Paradise Park seems to be in the center of it all. If it's not closed by the time you read this, the rooftop is definitely worth checking out.

If you want to use the elevator and it's not working, try punching in 0114 (authorization code). Otherwise, you'll have to get an employee to help you or just take the stairs.

On June 13, 2018, the Nashville Business Journal reported the building (411 Broadway) sold for $27 million last summer (https://www.bizjournals.com/nashville/news/2018/06/13/the-goldberg-brothers-are-closing-this-downtown.html) and will close in July 2018. The owners of the building and Paradise Park, who also own a bunch of restaurants in Nashville, are planning to open a new concept which will utilize all four stories of the building. It's supposed to open in 2019.

Virago is a posh, loungy sushi restaurant located in Nashville's trendy downtown neighborhood, the Gulch. I thought it was alright.

Virago is part of the "upscale" M Street restaurant group which includes five restaurants along McGavock between 12th and 11th Aves. They are: Kayne Prime (steakhouse), Moto (Italian), Saint Anejo (Mexican), Virago, and Whiskey Kitchen (pub grub). We showed up to McGavock around 9:20pm on a Friday night without a reservation to any of these places. After first checking with Whiskey Kitchen and then Saint Anejo, we settled on Virago because they could seat us almost immediately. Whiskey Kitchen and Saint Anejo were packed with waits. There were plenty of open tables at Virago.

Virago is on OpenTable. Book your reservation for free and earn dining points that can be used towards future discounts at select OpenTable restaurants or an Amazon gift card.

All three of Whiskey Kitchen, Saint Anejo, and Virago looked modern and stylish. It's evident this company has put a lot of money into the construction and design of its restaurants. Virago is the oldest of the bunch. It opened in 2000. It's been in its current spot since 2010 (the original location was in Midtown). This isn't an authentic Japanese or sushi restaurant, but more of a sleek Americanized sushi and Asian fusion joint with a huge drink menu. I'm not a huge fan of these types of places as the food can often be subpar and overpriced. Virago pretty much fell in line.

The restaurant has a swanky aesthetic. When we visited, it felt a lot like a lounge complete with lounge music and dim lighting. The place is spacious. There's a sizable wraparound sushi bar and multiple dining rooms and seating areas including a large lounge/waiting area with couches. There are private booths, big tables for groups, and a variety of lighting from pendant lights to recessed lighting. This restaurant can easily accommodate groups (we had six in ours) and the candle-lit ambiance is ideal for dates too.

The dinner menu had a decent selection of Japanese and fusiony food. They included salads and appetizers ($7-14 each) like "V2 edamame" (charred edamame with togarashi Japanese spice mix and sweet soy sauce) and yellowtail jalapeno (a popular app); ishiyaki - foods cooked over hot stones ($29-96 per order); agemono - deep-fried dishes ($9-19 each); robatayaki - skewers ($9-24 per order) and meat/seafood ($22-34 each) cooked over charcoal; nigiri and sashimi ($6-15 for two pieces); and makimono - rolls ($13-29 each). They also had chirashi - assorted sashimi over sushi rice ($24 for a small size, $42 for a large), omakase - a chef's tasting ($85 for the "chef's tour" and $95 for the "sushi tour"), and more. Finally, there were daily specials such as ramen ($17), Waygu strip steak ($30), and matcha sponge cake ($12).

The drink menu was extensive: cocktails, wine by the bottle or by the glass, over 40 selections of sake (impressive), and all sorts of beer and spirits (scotch, bourbon, Japanese whisky, gin, tequila, vodka, rum, etc.).

Here's what I tried:

* Ishiyaki Wagyu strip, 6 oz. ($35) - hot rock, togarashi salt
* Chirashi don, large size ($42) - chef's sashimi selection on rice
* Sake #702. Ozeki Nigori, 375 mL ($17) - crisp and vibrant, unfiltered

In general, the food was good, though not great, and everything was presented nicely.

The ishiyaki Wagyu strip was quite tasty though 6 ounces of meat wasn't much. However, what little meat there was was high quality. The meat, which had great marbling, was served raw and cut into thin slices. This was a cook-it-yourself dish. Each slice of meat was cooked, sizzling, on top of a single hot black stone. This dish was 100% meat aside from a miniscule amount of green onion (primarily used as a garnish), oil (I believe it was sesame oil, to help with cooking), two sauces (one a savory dipping sauce and the other a concentrated chili sauce, perhaps Sriracha), and togarashi salt which was more salt than togarashi. Togarashi (or shichimi) contains seven different ingredients including various pepper flakes and sesame seeds. The stone lost its heat towards the end of the meal, so the server had to bring another one. While this dish was yummy, it wasn't filling.

Since I'm allergic to shrimp, I asked for the chirashi don to be prepared without shrimp. There was no shrimp on the plate, but my mouth still experienced a mild allergic reaction. There was definitely some cross-contamination going on. Aside from that, I thought the chirashi was average at best. I order chirashi often at sushi restaurants and Virago's version was simply OK. The large version was filling (at $42, it should be). It contained plenty of thick slices of ahi tuna, yellowtail, salmon, escolar, and albacore tuna plus avocado, cucumber, and multicolored fish eggs (either tobiko or masago).

We got multiple bottles of the Ozeki Nigori, a cloudy, milky-white sake. It was slightly sweet and I liked it.

Service from Regan was good.

We were meeting a friend outside Philadelphia City Hall (https://www.yelp.com/biz/city-hall-philadelphia). On our way to City Hall, we happened to pass through Love Park, an urban park that takes up one city block adjacent to City Hall. It's nice. When we visited around 7:40pm on a Sunday, it was clean, spacious, and not crowded.

There was a big "I [heart] Philly" sign with City Hall serving as the ideal backdrop. It was perfect for tourists like us to take a picture with. This place isn't called Love Park because of that sign though. The park got its name from the popular red-colored "Love" sculpture on the other side of the park, closer to City Hall. This is the same Love sculpture that's on display in other cities like London, New York, and San Francisco. The original sculpture is inside the Indianapolis Museum of Art.

Unlike other cities, Philly's Love sculpture is propped up high so you can stand and pose for a shot underneath it (as opposed to in front or beside it). The park serves as the southern endpoint for Benjamin Franklin Parkway (https://www.yelp.com/biz/ben-franklin-parkway-philadelphia), a wide one-mile-long street worth walking if you've never been to Philly before. If you look north (technically, northwest) up the parkway, you can see Logan Square (https://www.yelp.com/biz/logan-circle-philadelphia-2) and the Philadelphia Museum of Art (https://www.yelp.com/biz/philadelphia-museum-of-art-philadelphia) with its famous Rocky Steps (https://www.yelp.com/biz/rocky-steps-philadelphia). It's a cool visual.

The park must have been renovated relatively recently because pictures I've seen of it on Yelp show a fountain which no longer exists. Instead, there's now a big splash pad. Dilworth Park (https://www.yelp.com/biz/dilworth-park-philadelphia-9), one block over, has one too. Kids were having a blast in both. Around Love Park's splash pad are several red lounge chairs. A nearby gravel space has umbrella-covered red tables with additional seating including tree-shaded benches. There's a lot of green space, but perhaps almost equally, a lot of concrete, gravel, and brick. The trees and benches in the brickyard on the southeast end of the square are nice touches. A modern-looking glass building on the northeast side serves as an entrance/exit to an underground parking garage.

This park is also known as John F Kennedy Plaza.

Fun fact: Love Park was designed by Philadelphia city planner Edmund Bacon, father of Kevin Bacon.

This review is for our recent Delta Air Lines flights (two round trips) into and out of Philadelphia International Airport (PHL). In short, these trips were fine.

I checked prices using kayak.com and booked using delta.com. I flew with my fiancee. For all flights, our seats were assigned at the gate. In all cases, Delta automatically seated us next to each other. We flew coach so we always got one middle seat and one window or aisle seat. On one or two flights, we got the exit row, which was nice. I remember at least one of our flights was on a McDonnell Douglas MD-90.

For one of the flights, we boarded and sat at the gate in Atlanta for about an hour. This didn't bother me since we weren't in a rush. I just watched Pet Sematary (2019) on my laptop.

We flew out of and into Atlanta. Our first round trip, arriving on a Friday and departing on a Monday, booked about three months out, cost $303.60 per person. Our second round trip, arriving on a Saturday and departing the following Sunday (quick turnaround), booked about two months out, cost $360.60 per person. Same season. Delta-estimated flight times were anywhere from 1 hour 55 minutes to 2 hours 9 minutes. In actuality, I think one or more of the flights was slightly under 1 hour 50 minutes (in pure flight time).

On a flight into Atlanta, we were one of the last ones to board, so we had to check our roller bags at the gate (free). Unlike some gate checks where you can pick up your bag at the gate at the destination (usually, on smaller jets), this particular check meant we had to pick up our bags at baggage claim in Atlanta. The Delta app was useful in helping us keep track of our checked bags, letting us know the bag tag numbers and which baggage claim carousel in Atlanta to go to. The app also notified us when our bags were available for pick-up.

The Delta app gives you a bit of information about your flight including statistics such as the percentage of time your flight is on time. One of our flights had a historical on-time rate of 97%.

Our in-flight experiences were fine. No complaints. Each flight included a free drink and and a snack. The snack was a choice of a small bag of Cheez-Its, a single pack of those popular Biscoff cookies (my dad likes to buy boxes of them from Costco), a KIND bar, or almonds (I forget the brand, but it was one of those well-known brands). Not all the snacks I listed were available on every flight, but there were at least two choices on every flight.

We flew into and out of gates D12 and D14. Getting through TSA PreCheck at PHL Terminal D was super fast. https://www.yelp.com/biz/tsa-checkpoint-d-philadelphia-international-airport-philadelphia

How can you not like the Liberty Bell, a symbol of American freedom?

The Liberty Bell, which was originally cast in 1752, is located inside a building known as the Liberty Bell Center which opened in October 2003. The center is located next to Independence Hall within Independence National Historical Park, a park that consists of several blocks in Center City, Philadelphia.

Admission is free. The bell is owned by the City of Philadelphia and the center is run by the National Park Service. The center is open daily, except Christmas Day, on a first-come, first-served basis. There's not much to the place. You have to go through security (metal detectors, bag inspection) to enter. Once you enter, there's a hallway with various exhibits about the bell including a 10-minute video put together by the History Channel.

Of course, the main attraction is the Liberty Bell itself which is located in a room at the end of the hallway. The bell is roped off so you can't touch it, but you can walk around it. You can view and take pictures of the bell from 360 degrees. The room the bell is located in is cool because the backdrop is Independence Hall (https://www.yelp.com/biz/independence-hall-philadelphia). Admission to Independence Hall is free too. Whoever designed this center did a great job because the backdrop is perfect; very picturesque. The bell is attended/guarded by a National Park Service ranger.

We visited the center on an ordinary Sunday around 5:40pm. There was a line to enter the building, but it moved fast. We were through security in about 5 minutes. There was a small crowd around the bell, but luckily, everyone was polite and respectful, keeping their distance and taking pictures in turn. Our entire visit at the center lasted less than 20 minutes. We could have spent more time looking at the hallway exhibits, but were hungry and wanted to get to Jim's Steaks (South Street location, about a 15-minute walk away) for a cheesesteak dinner.

The center was clean, modern, and felt safe.

We're glad we came here. This is definitely a spot worth checking out.

Where do I even begin with this hotel? How is this a Marriott property? If folks from Marriott corporate saw the condition of this hotel during our stay, they would not be happy. This is easily the worst Marriott property I've stayed at. It certainly didn't live up to the Marriott name/standard. This hotel does have a few things going for it, but the cons definitely outweigh the pros.

FYI, this used to be the Sheraton Philadelphia Downtown.

We stayed in room 1426 on the 14th floor. This hotel has 26 floors, I believe.

Pros:

1. Excellent location. If you want to be close to all of the tourist attractions and hot spots in Philly, this hotel is central to it all.

2. Good value. We paid $119 a night, a wedding block rate, which wasn't too much cheaper than the standard rate. I think this is a good price for a hotel room located downtown in a big city.

3. Friendly staff. From the ladies at the front desk to our housekeeper, Gisella (not sure if I spelled her name right), everyone we interacted with was nice and polite. Even a restaurant server smiled at us as we passed by.

4. Big smart TV. Not the best picture quality or responsiveness, but good enough. It had all the major channels and streaming services. You have to use your own accounts for the streaming services.

5. Fast and free Internet. The Wi-Fi in our room was blazing fast. Great!

6. Good, basic amenities. Luggage rack, iron and ironing board, coffee maker, hair dryer, and toiletries (bar soap, body wash, lotion, shampoo, conditioner). However, they did not offer a couple common amenities; see #4 under Cons below.

7. Cool-looking, modern bathroom. There was a walk-in shower with a hand-held shower head. Both the sink and shower looked relatively new.

8. Elevators were fast.

Cons:

1. This hotel was old and it showed. We also happened to stay during the wrong time -- there were signs in the hotel that said, "Pardon our appearance as we reimagine our guest rooms." So we visited before/during a renovation. Everything, it seemed, was on its last legs and the whole place, from the lobby to our room, smelled funny.

2. Our room was in poor condition.
- All of the furniture was well worn, from the surfaces of the open closet to the edges of the dresser and bathroom shelving.
- The switch on one of three lamps in our room was broken. In order to turn the lamp on/off, we either had to unscrew the light bulb (which is what I think the previous guest(s) did since the bulb was unscrewed upon arrival) or unplug the lamp from the power outlet. We opted for the latter.
- The bed old, creaky, and not very comfortable. It was in worse shape than my 14-year-old mattress which I just got rid of recently. Yikes.
- One of two nightstands was super weak and wobbly. It felt like it was going to fall apart just from a gentle push. I uploaded a video if you want to see.
- One of two phones was missing buttons.
- The cabinet door in the bathroom was missing its knob. We couldn't even open it for the duration of our stay.
- The bathroom faucet looked relatively new and nice, but it wasn't seated/secured properly. It was very loose. Check out my video.

3. Upon check-in, our room was dirty.
- There was an obvious stain on the carpet in one corner of our room. What could it have been? Coffee? Bodily fluids? I don't think we wanted to know. Check out my photos to see it.
- The lamps were dusty.
- The power sockets at our desk were very dusty.
- The room had a decent view, but it was spoiled by the dirty windows. They were quite dirty from the outside and needed a good wash.
- The carpet was old, dingy, and frankly, gross. We didn't step on it with our bare feet and instead wore sandals to walk around the room.
- There were stains on both our bed skirt and comforter.
- One of two coffee cup lids was dirty on the inside.
- Perhaps the grossest thing were the tongs for our ice bucket. They had some nasty, brown, sticky stuff on them. It looked like dried-up syrup.

4. Our room did not have the following common amenities (for a Marriott or similar property):
- Mini fridge
- Safe

5. Our "king" room didn't even have a true king bed. It wasn't even a queen. The bed was smaller than a queen.

6. While the shower was nice, the water pressure was low and the shower head was placed awkwardly in the corner above the retractable seat. This made showering awkward as I'd have to lean over the seat to wash my hair. The shower space wasn't fully utilized. Weird placement.

7. The bathroom didn't have much surface space to put our toiletries, both inside and outside the shower.

8. The AC unit was old and loud. It was one of those wall units with a control panel on the unit itself. There was another thermostat on the opposite wall, but it didn't seem to serve a purpose.

9. There was no ice machine on our floor (14) so I had to go down to 12.

10. Poor security. Anyone could walk into the hotel from any door at any hour it seemed. No key card was required to access the floors either.

I love this place. I found it on yelp while in reno this past weekend. This has to be one of the best little places to have breakfast.

Its located in a tiny strip mall next to a bar. There are limited indoor seats so come earlier or you might have to take your food to go.

I had the "special" which was a rendition of eggs benedict. a piece of crispy toast, topped with a nice piece of ham which was topped with 2 over easy eggs. Instead of hollandaise sauce there was a great chorizo gravy covering the eggs. It was marvelous. It was probably the best breakfast I have had in years if not ever. My bf had the el jefe which was just a breakfast burrito with chorizo, bacon, ham, eggs and fresh salsa verde. 

Both dishes were spectacular. To top it off they serve coffee, fresh baked ham and cheese scones, croissants and even have gelato. The service was great also. The young lady was very attentive, nice and made us feel comfortable even though we were obvious out of townies.

Try this place out if you're in the area. You won't be disappointed

Came back here today with some friends and once again this place is nothing but amazing. Some of my friends are picky when it comes to food but everyone thoroughly enjoyed their breakfast! I highly recommended the 5th street benedict which I got last time and it didn't fail to impress my friends. The sandwiches were amazing and this time we finally got to get some chocolate croissants and ham & cheese scones. Once again, the service was great. Super friendly and made everyone feel comfortable. I'm so glad that we got the chance to come back here for breakfast because I probably won't be back in the area till next year (at the soonest that is).. I'll definitely miss the great breakfast that they serve here..

Come to San Jose and open up a location here!! Thanks in advance haha.

OK... Take it from a Korean.. an out of townie Korean. Best Jampong I have ever had. Now first of all, where the hell is sparks and why do they have a Korean restaurant here and WHY is it so far from me?! 

I live 7 hours away but I would DEFINITELY eat here all the time if I lived closer. I was pleasantly surprised that the jampong was that delicious. I've had so many different jampongs around the area (Bay Area) and we are Korean infested and if Ktown can't get Jampong right but Sparks, NV can get it right then something is wrong...

Jampong: Spicy Seafood Noodle Soup. 

I was in reno for the weekend and my bf and I were craving Korean food to save us from the blizzard and almost sub zero weather. We yelped Jampong and holy hell it led us to this place. YES, I was hesitant on trying this place but seriously.. SERIOUSLY the best Jampong I have ever tasted and I've been eating it since forever.

The Bibimbap was good also but I didn't try any of the "staple" Korean dishes like bulgogi or kalbi. If they can master Jampong and Bibimbap then I have no doubt that their bulgogi or kalbi are nothing but excellent. 

I also couldn't help notice that there wasn't a lot of koreans around the area.. or in that fact, asians so if you are looking to try Korean food this is some damn good Korean food. 

WHO WOULD OF KNOWN that SPARKS, NV would have the best tasting Korean food...

ALSO its super cheap. Jampong where I'm from is $12.. At Hana Garden it was around $8!! wtf...

We don't actually dress like this but if you live in New Orleans and are having a California-themed party -- go for it, just don't tell me about it and I won't tell you about what we wear when we have our New Orleans-themed parties. xo.

We went at the tail end of dinner on a weeknight and didn't have to wait at all for a table. Service wasn't slow at all considering that the restaurant was full, we had drinks right away and our food came out quickly enough that we weren't sitting there with our bellies rumbling.

Our server was super chatty and we loved her. The other servers also chimed in on our conversation and that was also awesome. Anyone complaining about how the folks here spend too much time talking instead of serving is in the wrong town and has a stick up their butt and doesn't deserve to eat here.

1. The fried pickles as recommended by Tim P. and my sister: the portions, as pretty much everywhere else we went, were ridiculous. We ordered the appetizer and received a giant bowl of these delicious bites. The couple at the table next to us had ordered the fried okra [also delicious], so we traded off and still had a full take-out container left over.

2. Daughter got a side of red beans and rice [e.g. a giant flippin' platter] and a sausage. Delicious.

3. Chad and I split the mixed plate. I can't even remember anymore what-all came with this -- jambalaya, gumbo, various fried seafood, beans & rice, corn bread, something else probably -- and of course it was a giant mountain of food that was far too much for us. All incredible. Oh! the mac and cheese! I'm not even a huge mac & cheese fan. and OMG BEST EVAR.

4. I'd get just what we had again, except I would bring a couple more people and skip D's side of beans & rice because she could've had some of ours.

5. I bought some pralines, haven't even tried them yet because honestly, New Orleans left me wanting to eat nothing but raw spinach for the next couple months. Hopefully they'll hold up in my fridge for a bit.

6. Super bonus: high school kids' brass band playing in the vacant lot cater-corner.

What everyone else has said -- cute trendwear that's total garbage quality-wise and probably made by small Indonesian children but you get what you pay for. Large selection, lots of frothy lacy things floating around this season, and a bunch of accessories are available. I did not see the Shoe Nami store, which I wanted to because WHAT AN AWESOME NAME.

I can't afford any of it but loved trying it on.

The shopgirls were total candy babes and even sweeter than that.
This is where you can get a bottle of water and candy bar at normal convenience store prices in the quarter.

I am from San Francisco, where all things vintage are picked over, overpriced, and generally straight tore up. I was delighted by the vintage offerings in New Orleans -- affordable! excellent condition! -- and Miss Claudia's was my favorite stop. She has a very nice collection of men's and women's, accessories, and a box of old postcards. I found my dream hat, can't wait til Easter to wear it. Thanks, Miss Claudia, we'll stop by again next time we're in town!

I am pretty sure that this is the place that has lots of beads and if it is, I loved it, they had a great selection of glass and gemstones  along with a bunch of local artist-made jewelry, and more local art in back.

Went to the Goleta location [on Hollister, there are actually two but this was the one that was next to the freeway] -- wow. Up there with SF Bay Area's Thrift Town in terms of AMAZING LEVEL OF ORGANIZATION. All the Pyrex on a shelf, all the traditional Mexi-wear on a special Spanish Days rack, clothes sorted by type/color etc. Loved it.

Minus a star because overall prices were kind of jacked up [I wouldn't have bought anything if they didn't have the half-off blue tags special that day and I didn't see a whole lot of higher-end stuff, much less anything with store tags still on as mentioned in Jillian's review].

First time eating here.  Two of us had the burgers and they were amazing.  The French fries are home made and delicious.  One person in our group had the chicken and waffles but did not like at all.  They basically give you a dry waffle with two dry chicken stops on top.  My husband had the Cubano and liked it.  Could use a dill pickle in it.  Service was good.

This steak house is amazing.  We shared a bone in ribeye and a add on small lobster tail!  The stark melted in your mouth. It was cooked to perfection!  The lobster was one of the best I have had. Sweet and delicious.  The potatoes that are pan fried with onions and gravy are quite amazing as well.  I am a baked potato person but these were better!  Ok enough about the food.....lets talk about the service.  We had Marcos as our waiter and he was point on!  Very helpful with us picking the right selection. He knew the menu well and guided us to perfection.  You won't be disappointed in eating here!  One of the best steakhouses I have ever eaten at.

I'm in Philly. I want cheesesteak. 

But with a limited time schedule and a requirement for credit cards accepted we took a crapshoot and went with Top Tomato for our work lunch delivery needs via GrubHub. 

And it was good. Really, friggin' good. My cheesesteak hoagie came with all the fixin's and despite the lack of Paesano's oomph, I scarfed that sucker down more than happily. Delivery was 15 minutes earlier than quoted and lunch for five landed under $50. Ain't nothin' wrong with that, son.

Nestled into the end of a strip mall in Montecito, Sakana is a true hidden gem of the locals scene in Santa Barbara. Pulling up to this unassuming and intimate restaurant right next to a Vons, you'll find a dim-lit and charming interior boasting incredibly creative sushi with picture-perfect presentations. 

Like Nicolette Sheridan, this is what we call a sure thing.

First, the menu is huge. If you're a strict traditionalist then you'll be disappointed since their spin on sushi is quite novel; combining fish, textures and flavors in ways I had never before seen. We ordered the Surfer's roll...twice...maybe three times because every time it hit the table everyone began using their chopsticks as weapons of war. We went on to devour the Red Dragon and Montecito rolls with impatient precision. The ahi tuna appetizer is also worth noting. The sushi is served in press box form so you won't find any seaweed holding things together or impacting the overall taste. Every dish is positioned like artwork with splashes of colorful sauces striped across and as you eat and dip the image on the plate transforms. 

It's not cheap but it's also completely worth the price tag. Plus, they are cool with BYOB so our feast for four ended at under $40 each. For a bonus, see if you can convince your dining companion that the HD fish screen is actually a live feed of the tank in the back kitchen. The fish is fresh enough for it to be convincing...

Is it sacreligious to say that the Philly cheesesteaks here were less than amazing? Perhaps I ordered wrong but then again, is that possible when you're ordering hunks of meat wedged between two oiled up halves of bread?

First off, provolone was an extra dollar which made me forget to order mine with provolone - lame. Then they didn't whiz our stuff like we had asked and PD had to go back for heaping cups of whiz for us to smear ourselves (free of charge thank you) along with hot sauce which didn't appear readily available (thought there were pickle slices galore). I ordered the meat with spinach which actually tasted a lot like meat and garlic bread...weird. The cheese fries were ok but Shake Shack's waffle fries easily kill Jrs. 

So needless to say I was underwhelmed. I love me a cheesesteak but I've had better from Jake's Steaks in San Francisco. Ok, now you 'delphians have at me!

Good place to catch a train if you're running late, great place to wait if you're running early.

Beautiful high ceilings and plenty of food options make this train terminal both quite functional and gorgeous at the same time. Unlike Penn Station (where I wait all too often) there is plenty of seating at 30th. The traffic at the front can get bad if your trying to get in or out during a rush or snow storm but ultimately you'll get in.

Coffee, tea, magazine or coffee. Despite the wait, the Philly folk at Amtrak will help you get where you need to go.

I love me some Philly. 

Sure, we've got gogo dancers here in NYC. And yea, we've got bacon mac 'n' cheese. But then again, I don't know where I can eat that and watch a bare ass jiggle and keep my appetite. Love the 60's inspired throwback dancers shakin' what their mama gave 'em on the lit stage blocks here. Throw in some awesome music, fans blowing everyone's hair back and it is instant music video time. 

And then I find out that drinks are $4 and I figure that I'll have to make a pilgrimage here at least every few months. Yep.

So good that in a short weekend trip for a wedding in Ventura I managed to visit D'Vine twice! 

A low key cafe complete with outdoor seating, a bookshelf of borrowed reads and friendly folks behind the counter; it was exactly what I needed when I was en route to my hotel. The D'Vine Wrap caught my eye and delivered an crucial combination of flavors: salami, turkey, lite ranch dressing, tomatoes, lettuce, cheese...all rolled tight in a spinach wrap. It lasted me through two light meals and was both healthy and satisfying -- not easy to do! 

When hunger hit the next AM I could only think of the speckled sunlight shining on the outdoor patio of D'Vine. A breakfast burrito and iced coffee later and I knew this was a winner. They'll have something for everyone; the worst part is that I can't bring them back with me to NYC -- along with the perfectly sunny weather!

With a 4-star showdown between my Philly phavorites Felicia D, Michelle C and Monica S ... I was shocked by the 3-star average on this über-hip Mex joint off Rittenhouse Square.

Formica countertops, wood paneling and all the other good stuff that makes up an old school side-of-the-road dinner is juxtaposed with a tasty, relatively authentic menu of Mexican eats available almost anytime (before midnight, that is). Full of twenty-somethings and hipsters, this is true Rittenhouse cool. The margaritas are solidly balanced and the eats are hands down delicious. The chips & guacamole is secretly pricey ($14??) but generally decent plate of food from the entree menu, won't run you much more than ten bucks. I noticed a pretty sweet 2-course lunch deal for $9.99 that I'd check out when I'm back in town. I can completely get behind the pollo verde enchilada that had me swooning, despite a late night lack of appetite. 

Sure, it's a little pretentious and gimmicky, but you've gotta appreciate the flair. And if you don't, then at least give a nod to the queso.

A classic surf and turf lunch spot right on the harbor is hard to beat. What makes Brophy Brothers a great choice is the laid back atmosphere, unpretentious style of the patrons and the inevitable feeling of relaxation that comes with a seat outside on a sunny Santa Barbara day. 

Since it's off the main strip it manages to evade the honeymooners, meat heads  and teen goth contingent of State Street. The menu is short and sweet loaded heavy with fresh shellfish options. The dungeness crab was good, as is the seafood linguini but don't expect anything genius coming from the kitchen. Same with the straightforward and simple approach to cocktails. A bloody Mary, oyster shooter and simple shot of tequila is about all you need from bartender.

Roll through for lunch and watch the boats rock in the harbor. It's hard not to have a good time here.

Out of town for the month and was craving a pizza. I was staying at the Hilton Garden Inn near the airport and called this Papa John's around 10pm. They couldn't deliver my pizza because of a high robbery alert in the area.. well... :(

YEAAAAA found the best pizza in Houston!!! better than p1nks & r0man0s.

Customer service is bar none!

Granted people have their opinions of their favorite pizza and get all butt hurt if theirs isn't the best. So you just have to try it for yourself and be a ponzo fanatic too :)
Great Tennessee wet ribs! I can't wait to go back. They also had live bands performing which made it fun.

I think this place will be much better once they iron the kinks out and the newness wears off.  Right now the seating capacity is no where near the demand and they seem to rush everything to turn the tables over.  We ordered 2 pies and a salad.   They had everything come out at the same time so there was no flow to the meal. 

The pizza where good the crust was good but the escarole salad was terrible.   The dressing was flavorless,  the anchovies were old and had been opened for a while but the worst part was the greens.  Escarole salads need to be the younger greens or the hearts.  They server the main leaves which are tough and almost inedible.

Honestly was excited to find an iron chef place in Philly.  I knew I would have to wait to get in but that is something you are used to when it comes to "hot spot" eating.   There was over a 2 hour wait which is not great but still doable.  What was unacceptable was the hostess at the front.  She was flat out rude, could care less about the customer.   No I am sorry about the wait or have a drink at the bar or anything. She never even asked if we wanted to put our name in like most other places in the area.   Someone should coach her to tell her she works in the service industry.  

Shame just a pure shame this hostess is the experience she gives customers when they go there to have an Iron Chef experience.

Fun little downtown cafe for coffee, light lunch, or gelato. I enjoyed a house coffee (served in a ceramic cup, not paper) and Caprese sandwich. It was not small or giant, but was filling and fresh. The interior is fun with art hanging and an all important fire place. I'll add this spot to my 'when nearby next' list for sure.

Cute coffee shop?  Yes.
Snootie attitude by coffee elites that work there?  Yes.
Great coffee?  Yes.
Comfy sofa by the fireplace in which I sat?  Yes.
Run back?  No.

For it's type of place, it's really terrific.  In my teens, my father owned a healthy food restaurant, and I helped to build it from the ground up.  We did a great job (I think), but didn't make it successfully...and closed after 3 years or so.  In our dreams, we would have liked to be as good and successful as The Natural Cafe appears to be.

Love the menu.  The energy is great, healthy, quality ingredients are used, and the service is so nice.  This location is new, kept immaculate, the portions are large, and they have the best ^%$# (darn) tofu ever -- that I can't help to order the Veggie Stirfry ($9.79) with Tofu (add $1.80) nearly every time, at any of the Natural Cafe locations.

This particular visit, I tried the Buddah Burrito with chicken.  Wow.  It was huge and really great with a healthy twist.
