The light beers are average at best (though I don't enjoy light beer, so take that opinion with a grain of salt).  The Oktoberfest beer was fairly average, the dunkel weizen was not anything I'd remotely consider 'dunkel.'  The Anvil ale, especially the cask conditioned version, was excellent, and the porter was good as well - dark, chocolatey, and with a nice bitter finish balanced by the maltyness.

The food was filling and tasty - sweet potato fries were fantastic, pork tenderloin was perfectly tender, and the catfish was delicious (though they don't entirely get the concept of red beans & rice).

There was also a suprising number of beautiful girls hanging out on their own or in small groups - looks like quite the place to go out drinking if you're a local.

Prices were perhaps a shade high, but the menu is enormous, and the service was stellar - fun, friendly, and very perky (but not annoyingly so).

Damn.
Yeah, the line will probably be long.  And slow.  But if you love you some taco deliciousness, it's probably worth it.
The tortillas are fantastic.  The bowls of meat & cheese are stunningly delicious.  The guacamole is great.  The chorizo was possibly the best I've ever had.  Seriously.  The tamale special was also damn good.

Tip: ordering is a bit weird.  You pick the meat from the menu, and it comes out with some tortillas for some build-your-own action.  That's how it works.

Cheesesteaks, and that's about it.  Yeah, you can get fries and onion rings, and chicken steaks, and I think they do burgers.  But basically - it's just cheesesteak.
The steak is thin-sliced on the spot (you get to watch the machine do the slicing while you wait in line, soaking in the greasy air), and is high-quality and very lean.  You've got your choice of whiz, american, or provalone, sauteed onions are free (and clearly required) and you gotta throw in the extra for the sweet peppers.
Steaks are big, juicy, and damn tasty.

It ain't especially clean or pretty, but when you want a cheesesteak, they serve it up right (though not necessarily efficiently).  There are also 2 tables outside if you catch them on a nice day.

Oh, and there's pretty much always a line.

I was in Philly for the weekend and friends suggested I check this place out...

Wow, pretty dam good in my eyes. We were even there accidentally when there was a casting party for Transformers II. 

Good service at the door and upstairs- check, attractive people but not over crowded- check, great music- check, the night too short- check. 

It reminds me of a place in Austin Texas that was a super fun hangout (Red Fez). Where they had great music and people just chilling and enjoying the night.

Related- to lounges (out of 5 possible stars)
Music- 5
Venue- 5
Service- 5
Overall exp- 5 
Drawbacks- I read about the food in the Sunday paper (yesterday) and it looks like we missed out on a good meal also.

I've been having a hard time finding a good brunch spot, until I found Jones.  Unfortunately for me, Jones is a 3 hour drive.   So I will not be frequenting it - but one can dream.

We sat upstairs, which I recommend - a little quieter & you can watch everyone below you.  We were there around 11:30 on a rainy Saturday, and were sat immediately.  Service was fine, and fast.  Decor is super cute.

I had the French toast with tater tots.  Tater tots, you ask?  Yes, because where I'm from, they are not quite ubiquitous.  My Philly friend (aka tour guide) also had the French toast, and my husband had the avocado sandwich with fries.   The French toast was thick and tasty, and probably the biggest piece of French toast I've ever seen.   I enjoyed the tater tots.  My husband liked his sandwich and fries, but the fries went cold fast.  

Perhaps a second location in DC or Boston is needed?

I don't always get drunk and go to clubs, but when I do, I like to make sure I'm on vacation in a different city and pay a cover.

I remember mostly EDM with some hip-hop, a lot of dancing, and it being super crowded. Floor was sticky. Definitely a dressier crowd. I don't miss my club days.

I had fun, but keep in mind, I was feeling the effects of alcohol. I'd probably not choose to go here sober, however, I didn't see many other dancing options in the immediate vicinity.

My iced almond milk caramel latte was fine, as was my friend's cortado and bagel. Four stars for the overall atmosphere, decor, and service, but three for the coffee. I've had better, and I've had worse. I prefer a strong coffee/espresso flavor, and my latte was missing that. It was more milky than anything, so the overall balance was off. Pastries (not bagels) looked tasty, and if I did happen to stop in again, I'd grab one.

Muriel's is a fine dining gem. I had been wanting to visit and finally, on my last night in New Orleans, I did. I enjoyed the fantastic service and delicious food.

I hadn't yet had a Hurricane and figured this would be the perfect place to get one. I definitely enjoyed it. The bread is addictively good and I couldn't stop eating it. I ordered my new standard--greens and redfish courtbouillon. I love redfish. Both the items were great. I loved the greens and the popcorn rice paired well with the redfish and sauce. I was too full for dessert, but I definitely want to return and will definitely be ordering dessert.

If you are looking for fine dining and excellent NOLA cuisine in the French Quarter, Muriel's is your spot.

This shop is fantastic. It's very welcoming and not gimmicky. I felt like the staff was really knowledgeable and helpful. You could tell they love talking about and teach about voodoo. My interaction was great--I told the super nice gentleman what I was going through and he recommended the perfect item. My Oya doll and I haven't been separated since. I really appreciate that he took the time to explain her protections and offer other suggestions as well. I'm looking forward to returning here on my next visit.

We all really enjoyed Pho Street. We didn't plan our visit, but were happy to have happened about this place. It's casual with plenty of seating and you can order at a kiosk, which is much appreciated.

I did a quick scan of the reviews to know not to order the pho. I ordered the grilled pork vermicelli bowl (bun thit nuong with cha gio), my sister had the Vietnamese hoagie (banh mi thit nuong), and my brother-in-law ordered the broken rice (com tam) with a cha gio side. Everything was excellent. The pork was super flavorful and there were tons of fresh vegetables and herbs in my bun. My sister said the bread on her banh mi was great. And my BIL loved his perfectly cooked and delicious com tam. We all appreciated the crispness of the cha gio. Even my baby niece enjoyed the vegetables we gave her. I love that they have a house-made fish sauce, which add depth to everything.

I'd stop here again if craving Vietnamese in Center City.

Our iced caramel soy lattes were OK. Something was missing--perhaps a stronger coffee flavor? Their hot lattes may be better, as some places are better at hot lattes than cold ones.

However, I did love the fun, eclectic vibe, and the food we saw looked delicious. I'd come back to try some noshes, keeping in mind that the line gets long and parking will take a few circles around the block.

This bustling station is beautiful. It probably works well if you know your way around, but as a visitor, it's frustrating, due to lack of available information. Directional signs are not clear. The website is basic, at best (given that it is run by Amtrak, that is no surprise), so finding information prior to visiting is a chore. A quick peruse of the food court options also proved to be basic and most close early. No place to grab a great coffee in the morning. Bathrooms are fine and at least there's an ATM and a convenience store, but this place could be better.

I could've skipped this and would've been OK in life. Anyone who tells you need to do a cemetery tour in New Orleans is lying, unless they are are really boring or really into history. The tour was good, but I was bored. You can walk around a free cemetery and see some graves--no need to pay. You can see a bit of this particular cemetery from outside the walls (this one you have to pay for and can only get in with an official tour) and that's all you really need in life. Save your money and your time for the important things, like drinking.

Hipster heaven, but my barista was surprisingly friendly.  Very good lattes, though I definitely needed sugar for mine.  Cool atmosphere, and the pastries looked amazing.   Definitely better than going to a Starbucks.

I was struggling with what was going to be review #1500. Would I go try a new place? Would I seek out something unique and fun to celebrate? I contemplated it. But I decided I'd rather review Wat Mongkolratanaram, a Buddhist temple in Tampa that offers a lovely Thai market on Sunday mornings. It's not something you come across too often.

I had been looking for cool things to do in Tampa, which are hard to come by, as I left the city somewhat indifferent about it. Luckily, before I left, I had found out about this place on the Tampa talk threads. From what I can tell, you need a car to get here.

I agree with much of what has been said: come here early (parking is rough and food runs out), bring plenty of cash, and plan to grab some small items to eat while you stand in line for the noodle soup. I missed out on the noodle soup because of poor planning. Do not let this happen to you. Also, come with people that like to eat and understand waiting in line for food.

Food wise, we tried various spring rolls and dumplings, beef satay, pumpkin curry, and chicken basil. Everything was great, and I'm fairly obsessed with the spring rolls. I also tried the papaya salad, and that was the only thing I did not really care for, and normally, I love it.

The grounds are idyllic, and the temple is gorgeous. There's really no other way to describe it. Ideally, when I return, I'll return alone, and be able to stay for services, which all are welcome to join. 

As a visitor to the area, I definitely recommend finding a way to get here. It was a highlight of my trip.

Not sure what else I can add, except the gelato is delicious.  A little pricey, but they let you try as many flavors as you like.  After trying a few, I had the bacio (dark chocolate & hazelnut) and cashew.  So amazing.  I also had a cappucino, which was good as well.

This Hyatt Place is fine. It's clean and comfortable, but not at the height of luxury or at all trendy. Beds are comfortable. Wifi was good. I was on a low floor, so it was a bit loud. Elevators are slow and constantly busy. Staff was super friendly and helpful.

The location is only good if you are going to a convention. It's not far from some good restaurants, but you can find hotels that are much closer to the fun. 

I'd not stay here again, but if you end up here (remember, for a convention only), it should be fine.

This was my worst JetBlue experience, and I normally love JetBlue. Curbside check-in is appreciated, though the staff does not speak well and was extremely rude. Gate staff was also impolite, while the flight crew were unprepared and kept barking orders at everyone. The on-time departure was nice, but I'd appreciate a calm, prepared, friendly crew in the future. I hope my future flights will be with a different Tampa-based crew.

Saint Lawrence is cute with a friendly staff but I was underwhelmed with the food. We ended up here due to location and the fact that it was open a bit later than other places. The food is fine, but there are better options. I didn't love my drink--it was a little sour. My red beans and rice, collards, fried chicken, and cornbread were OK, but a bit lacking in flavor. I needed hot sauce on everything. I'd go somewhere else before returning here.

Herbsaint is the first restaurant I visited in New Orleans and my first true experience with Cajun/Creole cuisine. It was an amazing introduction to the cuisine of the region. My only goal for my day was to eat amazing food (I left D.C. at 6 a.m. and was at Herbsaint by 11:30 or so--I literally flew to New Orleans, dropped my belongings in my room, changed, and headed here) and that is what happened.

This restaurant is exactly what I imagined a restaurant in New Orleans to be. It's hard to explain, but the decor and ambiance, along with the patrons (mainly a business crowd during lunch), created a charming, relaxed atmosphere. And the hospitality and service was amazing. From the lovely hostess to the skilled servers, everything was exceptional. 

I couldn't drink, which is too bad. I would have liked to try their cocktails, but will save that for next time. I ordered the gumbo, gnocchi, and fried apple pie. There was also bread and an amuse bouche. The bread was delectable. The amuse bouche, a marinated clam on a cracker, was the perfect morsel of deliciousness. And their gumbo remains in my dreams. It was so flavorful and so hearty and is definitely my favorite version of this dish. The gnocchi was light and tender and I appreciate the cloud of Parmesan. I couldn't finish it as I knew I wanted dessert, which I also couldn't finish. I had no idea what fried apple pie was, but it's basically an apple empanada, and since I love carbs that have been stuffed, rolled, and fried, this was a great dessert for me. It was definitely rich and I recommend splitting it with someone (though I mostly dine alone so that doesn't work for me). 

Herbsaint is fantastic and I highly recommend everyone experience it while in New Orleans.

Great museum for the little ones! We had so much fun here. My friend who lives in Philadelphia has two young children and has a membership, and I can see why. I feel like if you live close by and have children, it's definitely worth it. The kids love this place. And it works for a range of ages, from my then 8-month old niece to my friend's early school-age children, everyone had a good time. I think we spent ~2.5-3 hours there, and I was ready to leave (and drink) at that point, so it's a good amount of time. 

The exhibits are interesting and interactive. It really is a "please touch" place (I brought hand sanitizer and hand sanitizer wipes). It's also really pretty and well-laid out. A few spaces may be a bit cramped, but overall, it worked. You can park on the street if you don't want to pay for parking, which is great. 

I'd love to return to see the new exhibits and see the children in my life really enjoy themselves and run around and just be children.

I did not want to go to the Country Music Hall of Fame.  Truth be told, I didn't really even want to be in Nashville.  I mean, I'm a city-loving R&B girl, and had no idea why I'd want to learn about white people singing songs I can't relate to.  Watching trains go by in the middle of the night and drinking muscadine wine isn't even something I'm remotely interested in and I don't know all the words to every Tanya Tucker song (but, you can often find me drinking from a red Solo cup).

However, country music is part of the fabric of American life, and I loved the Country Music Hall of Fame.  You'd be remiss if you spend time in Nashville without visiting.  It's chock full of history and interesting facts, and it's great to see how and where country music started from, and where it is today.  The exhibits were very nicely done, with my favorite being the Crystal Gayle one (I will always want her hair).  They have a few of Elvis' cars, which are super cool and very detailed.  It takes a good 2--3 hours to get through everything, so don't go hungry (like we did).      

And while I didn't leave a lipstick tube on the bathroom floor, I was a bit sad to leave this place.  You definitely realize the significance part this musical genre plays in other types of music, and in American history.

The food and service at Melograno were great.  They open at 5:30 on Saturdays, and at 5:25, there were already people inside! Because we were early, they seated us with one person missing, but I hear that is not the norm.  It definitely filled up quickly.

Our server was friendly and good, though there were minor mistakes - automatically pouring the wine (not everyone was drinking), credit card slips in wrong jacket.  The decor is really pretty - we were seated right by the big chandelier.  

Food was great - my husband & I were still talking about it the next day.  Between four of us, two had the wild boar bolgnese, one had the mushroom app with the ravioli entree, and I had the ravioli special: cocoa ravioli filled with rabbit and topped with the brown butter sauce.  It was delicious.  Bread was also good, and you can't beat BYO.  I absolutely love the idea of BYO - it was the first restaurant I've been to that does that.

Why not 5 stars?  The foyer needs to be cleaned - I noticed spiderwebs (with spiders) in the corners.  My wine glass was dirty.  And one hostess was rude (though the first one was nice).

This was the closest Cuban restaurant to my dad's place, so we decided to check it out. It's definitely popular and does a good take-out business. We sat at the small bar, and became quickly disappointed to find they do not have liquor (only beer and wine). It took a while for someone to take our orders, but staff is friendly.

I ordered a chicken empanada and lechon asado with rice and beans and tostones. I was hoping for Cuban bread, and it actually comes on the platter, not before the meal, so don't get disappointed. The empanada was tasty and crispy. I was underwhelmed with my platter. The bread was good and so were the tostones. But the rice and beans and lechon were not super flavorful and sort of dry. I asked for a side of mojo, which made it better. I was also unimpressed with my friend's ropa vieja.

I might try a sandwich from here, as the bread was really good, and I noticed many take-out sandwich orders. But I wouldn't get a full entree here again.

I will visit Longwood Gardens anytime - it is absolutely beautiful. I was here in early November, on a rather rainy day, unfortunately. I had been wanting to visit, especially due to the perfume exhibit, and luckily, Ariela M. had the same day off as I did, so a quick trip to Philly & Longwood Gardens was in store for me. 

The outside grounds are gorgeous, even without flowers and waterfalls in November. The inside gardens were just as amazing. My favorite was the orchids, of course! 

I had been wanting to see the perfume exhibit, as I am obsessed with perfumes. It was small, but with nice information on scents and perfumeries, as well as a beautiful perfume bottle display of some of the most popular perfumes and prettiest perfume bottles. Though I had been to a perfume bottle museum before, I never tire of seeing the bottles and thinking about new fragrances. 

The cafe was nice and the meals looked tempting, though we only split a slice of pecan pie. The Pierre du Pont house was also nice to walk through, especially as we needed to get out of the cold. A really cute cat lives there! The shop had some really pretty home decor, if you are into flowers. I must get back in the summertime!

I really enjoyed Dook's Place. To clarify, since I couldn't find a website for them, the MSY website sucks, and Yelpers, per usual, are confused: this is NOT Dooky Chase's airport location, which is close to Concourse C. This is an offshoot from his grandson, and is before security in Concourse B, the Southwest terminal. It looks like the only good place to eat, aside from its more famous namesake.

Dook's Place is nice. It's well-lit with a nice bar and colorful artwork. The R&B was bumping and service was good. They kindly made the modifications to my chicken sandwich with no problem. I didn't get to try a drink, but from what I saw, they looked good. I loved my fried chicken sandwich and fries. That sandwich was on point--the chicken was hot, crispy, and flavorful. Fries were great. I'd be happy to return and try more on the menu.

MSY lacks in many areas, most notably dining. If you are going to be hungry before or after your flight, come early/stay late to eat here. The food and ambiance are great and it's also one of the only good options.

I've been to my share of convention centers and this is one of the worst. Yes, it's one of the biggest, but who cares? I never attend a convention here. The design, both interior and exterior, is extremely dated. The food court offerings are awful. In a city known for it's food, at least you could offer excellent food, but not here. And there isn't even any good food right outside, so if you are at the center, you can't leave to grab something good (unless you have plenty of time and can hit up Cochon). It's not in an awful location, but you do have to walk at least a few blocks to find some good food. 

A convention center, much like an airport, can really represent a city, and this one (also much like the New Orleans airport), does not. At least it's named for Morial (the first African-American mayor of New Orleans) and you can hire a jazz band. That's all I got.

I was super hungry and Royal House had no wait, so I stopped in. I was excited to try the shrimp Creole, as it was near the end of my trip, and this was one dish I still had yet to try. I thought it was was just OK. The shrimp were not the big, beautiful Gulf shrimp I was expecting and the sauce had little flavor. It also took a really long time to prepare, given that the restaurant was not that full. Those around me mostly ordered sandwiches, and I wish I had gone that route. Service was really good, though. There are better restaurants in the Quarter.

I was expecting greasy, lackluster bar food here and was very pleasantly surprised to enjoy delicious, creative, gourmet food instead! My favorite dish was the smoked trout wontons, but really everything was pretty amazing. Loved the chocolate lava cake. I'll definitely make a point to come back here the next time I take the train to Philly.

Beautiful place for a wedding. Parking right outside (first 75 minutes free) or park across the street in the parking structure (first 75 minutes free and $1.50 for every hour after).
There are many floors and hidden gems in this beautiful space. I attended a wedding in the Mural Room and it was stunning.  The judge who married my friends was stellar and even came around to say hello to the rows of attendees before the start.  They have a clock tower here and the history behind it is fascinating. You can also go to the very top and see a beautiful 360 view of Santa Barbara. Truly a great space for guests to entertain themselves and enjoy Santa Barbara. This is preservation and history at its finest.

This was my first trip to Eclipse Pizza and I was impressed. I bought a gift certificate on groupon. When we walked in the staff was very friendly. We ordered a Hawaiian calzone & Barbecue Chicken Pizza. The food was fresh and fast. I would definitely go back again.
The best Donuts in town. They have a great staff that will get you in and out in minutes. the Apple Fritter and Glazed donut holes are my favorite.

Great place to rent some bikes
What else can I say, being on a bike definitely can show you how beautiful Santa Barbara

It's a bit pricey but you can't really go wrong with much of the menu

The location on being near the train station is a big plus but the brewery across the street has a great happy hour(ie cheaper drinks)

$7.50 for a breakfast burrito?
Pretty pricey for a breakfast burrito but I guess that's the norm up here in Santa Barbara. 

Well was the breakfast burrito worth $7.50? Simply NO
I have eaten my fair share of breakfast burrito in my life time and this was nothing special that would garner such a steep price but as a post race meal it will do. I think everyone was starving when we came here and the service was good. I saw that they had a breakfast special that went up to 11am but it is not honored on holidays and weekends. Since we just came from the 4th of July Semana Nautica 15k, being a holiday, we had to settle for the full price. 

Would I be back?
I don't think so
The food is decent not too bad and the service was good but before coming here a buddy of mine actually asked me to look up some places around the race where we could grab something to eat. I found several but since this place was where they held their post race meal last year, we ended up here.

Decent quality. The Siu Mai does not look nor tastes like Siu Mai. The salad was drenched in dressing. The miso soup have a hint of bitter tasted but then I have very sensitive taste buds. I ordered the Chirachi bowl which lets me taste the quality of the fishes. Half of them tasted fresh. The other half was okay. So overall assessment... Eh... It's okay. Disclaimer: I'm use to the standards in NYC, and Los Angeles.
Amazing food and gluten friendly too. Go there with friends so that you can pig out on all the yummy appetizers. This is the first time that I had southern food and I am highly impressed by it.

This Target was far off in the distance in this strip mall but it needed the space because of the size of the store! 

Service was fairly friendly and most of the time the folks were more by the cashiers area. The aisles were clean for the most part and items on sale were displayed. 

My favorite part is the $1 (or not $1 section) and of course who doesn't enjoy their Starbucks while browsing through the Target aisles.

I thought it would be a good idea to come by here for dinner the other night with the family. It was so busy and the wait was rather frustrating. Otherwise, service was friendly and decent if you are forgiving that things took longer to come (or not at all) since they're so busy (food, water, extra utensils....). They also kept running out of supplies (kids drink cups, soup to go containers)... better stock up! 

The seating were great since there were booth and table seating. I had really wanted a highchair but gave it up for a booster seat when I found out that I was going to be put back on the waiting list. 

Their strawberry lemonade was tasty and I asked them to keep it coming. Haha. I ended up with the Mahi Mahi tacos (came with 2) and the side of chips and I was content. I just wished it didn't take forever for us to have the meal.

Service was friendly and nice. However, they got my order wrong when I asked for a plain sandwich. 

The bigger issue was the ants all over the drink area. That was a little disturbing. Also their water button doesn't work And that was all I was able to drink. 

A little disappointed.

Friendly staffed and always packed whether it is at the counter or the drive-thru. So far the orders have been correct which is more I can say for some other locations. 

It is connected to the gas station so you can walk right over if you need something. The ventilation isn't that great in there but if you can get in and out quick. There are great combinations and the usual list of Dunkin Donut favorites.

LOVE it here! It's clean, bright and happy feeling, waterfalls, outdoor music, plants, trees, and did I mention clean? What more can I ask for? 

It is set up like an outlet (the outdoors concept) but it a lot more pleasant feeling. You can walk around and enjoy yourself. Tired from shopping? Take a seat on the wooden benches or the rocking chairs. 

They have high scale stores like Williams-Sonoma, teen stores like Hollister and Aeropostale, department stores such as Macys and JC Penny, and a few special boutiques. Barnes & Noble is one of the favorites.

There are many delicious looking restaurants with beautiful decors scattered around the mall. There is even a late nite "club" that I have yet to visit. They do have food shops such as Moe's Southwest Grill, Cosi, a Teriyaki shop, and a Crepe shop. 

Looking for an evening or holiday event? They got it. Just look out for the large banners when you pass by and make sure you pay attention to the details (time and date) since I show up at the wrong times/dates sometimes.

I like this location and its usually tidy and clean which is why I enjoy coming here. 

The cashiers are usually friendly especially the guy with the great animated voice. 

They have everything you would probably need at these stores. everything for different holidays and greeting cards! Kitchenware, toiletries, food!

I've always liked Ker's Winghouse and this time it was no different. They opened in place of the Buffalo Wings that was suppose to open many moons ago and it's a great place. 

Service is fantastic and attentive. The managers were great and friendly. Everyone was there for anything that you may need.  

I always order my wings mild and naked and still love it. I like how their wings are mild and I get to add the amount of hot sauce that I would like especially if I am eating with people who do not like spices. Happy hour is great but beat the crowd! 

Parking is a problem now but I hear that they will have expanded parking soon.

I don't come to this location much since it's not in my neighborhood but it's one of the ones that play some independent films that other do not.  

I came here with some girlfriends the other night and enjoyed our time here.  Loving my large tub of popcorn and soda. A girl gotta splurge some time! The theaters were decently cleaned and the bathrooms weren't terrible even though it was the end of the night already. I was glad.

I've come here for the dim sum or some of the Cantonese dishes. The service is decent. 

However, some of the dim sum dishes aren't the way I remember it from NY or even close. There's been a few instances where I was sorely disappointed with the dishes. One time the sticky rice that just seemed undercooked. I was afraid to even have it. Sadly, I had given it more than a few tries and haven't been back since.

Great corner coffee shop. Friendly staff and nice seating area. I Wasn't up for the bar seating this time but maybe next time! It's all shared seating though so you're pretty close to the people around you.

They had some shirts and coffee for sale on the side but nothing like ordering a nice cappuccino for the morning and sipping it while being engulfed in the scent of coffee.

No wifi here though!

They are located in the GROVE mall towards the back. You can hit this and TJ Maxx back to back.

This old navy is usually a stocked. The service is friendly but the lines are usually long! The clearance section is always great but there is not much items there.

This market was small and had limited items. It was ok for some dry or canned items. Otherwise, I didn't find anything impressive. 

They have your snacks such as shrimp chips, and pocky, and mochi.

They also carried a variety of dry noodles and ramen. Canned vegetables available at most Asian markets. 

There were some prepackaged bags of vegetables in the fridge but I'm not sure how often their shipments come in. 

They also carried a few different cans of Thai curry and prepackaged teas.

We love this park! Discovered it when I met a moms group here and there is so much to it. They have areas where you can plan soccer or basketball or so many other sports. 

There are roads where you can basically go for a walk and circle the entire park. There's a section where there are benches and it's covered so there is plenty of shade and restrooms! It gets REALLY windy though so be warned.  The kids playground has a variety of things to play with for the younger and older kids. The downfall is that it is not covered.  The bigger issue I have are the large ant piles (most likely fire ants) which I am deathly allergic to. What if one of the kids walk through it by accident? One of my bigger fears.....

Do not allow yourself to leave St. Louis before hitting up a restaurant and having their fried ravioli with marinara sauce. This casual restaurant reminded me of a typical American eatery with a few outdoor seating on a nice day. The inside of the restaurant was rather spacious and dull. Don't forget to try the Creole Pasta with Sausages. The portions were pretty large but it was all worth the extra inches on the waistline!

I wasn't totally surprised when I went to Logan's Roadhouse. It reminded me of Texas Roadhouse. The deco was great with wooden furniture and neon lights. Each table came with a huge bucket of peanuts and peanut shells all over the floor. The staff was friendly and attentive. 

They serve a really large 2 pieces of bread that is light golden on the outside with a glaze over the top. The inside is SOOOOO SOFT... SOOO soft! I have never had such light and soft bread. They have a variety selection of appetizers, sides, desserts, burgers, salads, steaks, ribs, and combo entrees. The side of broccoli was VERY SAD and limpy. The half rack was fall-off-the-bone and the mac and cheese was comforting.

I am so happy that they came up with an outlet by the areas that I don't have to go all the way down past Brandon or to Orlando for an outlet! He gets super busy though especially during the weekends and holidays and there is plenty of parking. 

I like how there are seats everywhere along the way for people to either take a break or wait for their significant others.  There are lots of chargers and outlets everywhere and restrooms! Originally it was only a limited amount of food only in the food court but now since area has expanded tremendously there are a lot of restaurants and fast food choices surrounding it. 

There is also a cute little pirate ship play area for the little kids to play. Also reclining seats by some water fountains for more serene time here. There is even an area with seats and a fireplace.

There are many stores available here and you can still easily spend a few hours here.

The hotel is located right off the highway. Just at the front desk is friendly and usually knowledgeable. 

The lobby is decorated a lot nicer than many of the Hilton Garden instead I have been too. In December they had Decorated for the holidays and it was gorgeous! There is ice tea, coffee, tea, water with lemon and of course cookies in the lobby! There is also a little shop on the side for necessities and munchies. 

I have to say the restaurant food wasn't bad And I normally don't like hotel food. There was the shrimp cocktail which was fancied up. The short ribs are extremely pricey but there is a heap of it that they serve. There is also a hummus platter but the pita wasn't great. There was a battered shrimp salad which I believe was the Asian salad. That was okay. The chocolate cake is on the heavy side and the Apple and puff pastry was mediocre. They have a full meals and small munchies. A variety of things to order. The guy who brings up the food is very friendly. Tip him!!

The business center was always packed and also not always functioning. If you have a plane ticket to print, the front desk is always willing to help. Overall, one of the better Hilton Garden Inn's I have been too even though they are located in the middle of nowhere in Fort Washington!

Perfect location for the upcoming hospital that is opening up next year. The service was wonderful even though they were short of staff (it happened to be dinnertime). The prices were decent but expensive if you plan on eating here daily for lunch.

We had ordered the Steak with onions with black beans on rice. The kids menu quesadilla was mediocre. Overall it is good for the area we are in with limited authentic spanish food.

I come about every 12 weeks and always come back for more! 

It's a nice little place and I enjoy their pizza but is their huge salads that get me every time. 

I love the Cobb salad and their Greek salad but heck even Their simple garden salad is great because their is so much toppings on it and their dressing are fabulous.

Bonsai Sushi was good. I wouldn't say out of this world but it was okay. It helps with the craving a little since it has been several weeks since I had sushi. 

There are some typical rolls and there were many creative rolls available for order. Soups and typical hot dishes are available. What totally threw me off is that they serve Bul Go Gi and Kalbi.... ??!!  I'm going to have to figure out how that tastes...

Such a cute neighborhood café. She usually only open from 10-5 so swing by during your breaks!

I've been ordering the latte and the iced teas aren't bad. You can't go wrong with any of the choices really. Service is usually friendly and attentive. She usually had some scones available or light sandwiches. 

Everything in the store is for sale. Mostly. There are photos and greeting cards and jewelry and even paint for your walls. There's a cute little playroom so that your kids and play and let you relax for once! The furniture in the place is awesome and my favorite is the extra long table!

Always love my pottery barn and their products and set ups. It's at a great location at the Wiregrass mall away from people traffic. You're in another world when you step in. 

Staff is friendly and available for help. 

They have classes at this location someone's. Check their website.

I was super excited when I heard about it and it sounded so great. I was able to stop by one Sunday for their "brunch" prices which was $15 per person all day since they opened at noon. I like restaurants with lighting and natural lighting would be great so the mere fact that it was so dark in there even during the day worried me. Sure if it's the even and it's date night, then a dark ambience wouldn't hurt but it was lunch time. Hopefully they would consider some lighting but maybe I'm the only one... 

We had a good number of items off the menu and majority of them were pretty good. The soy paper off the American Dream threw me off a little though. I wasn't crazy about it. Otherwise, my usual rainbow roll, spicy salmon, alaskan, and California were decent. They fill a lot of the rolls with the imitation crabmeat tho and kept the Slices of fish for the topping. The sexy Girl was interesting and had a pretty presentation. I didn't see the nigiri until I was full but I enjoyed the salmon nigiri too. I'll probably be back to try some of the others and maybe try to get seated by the window. LOL.
They had Decent sandwiches and good service. Normal prices for a lunch Cuban sandwich. They have enough seating for one or a small crowd.

The restaurant larger than I expected. Many seats to offer guest coming thought the doors. Service was adequate and friendly but it was also early with few tables. They had booths and tables. 

The olive oil that came with the bread had extra herbs to it that make the dip tastier. The Linguine Pescatore (with shrimp, scallop, and mussels) was good with a side of salad or soup that came with it (all pasta dishes come w that option).

Located in a central location not too far from Bourbon Street and all the bars. Perfect for those days you need painkillers for your hangovers or maybe the extra mouthwash to gargle Or even a T-shirt to replace the one your friend puked all over.

I'm sure there are other locations where you can pick up cheap souvenirs or coffee from Café du monde or beignet mixes But a Walgreens will beat any other souvenir shops along the tourist roads.

There's also a few Chase ATMs in the area but this one is located inside the Walgreens.

We took the slice to-go so I'm not sure about how the sit down service is but the counter service was good. The place was large and had a few full service tables. I was a little disheartened to see that I could not stay there to eat my slice before I left. However, I think that is the trend in this area (no tables).

I wasn't disappointed with their pizza! I bought a regular slice and the crust was not too thick and cheese was just melted and oozed!

i love the south. i love southern food. i love delicious pancakes.  i love amazing  country ham. i love sweet tea. i love having a big booth all to myself.  i love nice waitresses. i love people who stand up to greet someone they run into at a restaurant during breakfast. i love waitresses that offer to give me a refill of sweet tea for the road.  l love breakfasts that cost $8.

i hate leaving pancake pantry.

Visiting Tampa for the second time, our colleagues here decided to take us out to Boizao.  I've never been to one of these Brazilian Steakhouses, but have heard a lot about them.  I knew that I was in for a lot of food.

Food - The amount of meat that you eat here is ridiculous.  14 different types of meat is offered to you throughout the evening.  There is a cardboard circle in front of your seat that is red on one side and green on the other.  If you place the green side up, they will offer you a piece of meat....if you have the red side up, they will pass your table.  I had the green side up most of the evening. I think I sampled everything except one or two types of meat.  Here's what I tasted:

Filet Mignon
Filet Wrapped in Bacon
Lamb Chops
Leg of Lamb
Pork Tenderloin
Ribs
Prime Rib
Picanha
Picanha com alho (with Garlic)
Top Sirloin
Bottom Sirloin
Brazilian Pork Sausages
Chicken Legs marinated with beer

Yep....I pig'd out!  I passed on the salad bar though....as I knew I would have to save room in my stomach for all of this food.  I even had a little room for a Tiramisu for dessert.

Service - I thought the service was excellent.  There were 7 of us and we never had an empty glass of wine, water, or food.  The servers were very attentive and cordial.

Atmosphere - The dining room is large and dark.  Nice setting for a dinner.  The tables are spaced appropriately....what I mean is that they aren't too close together.

Parking - There is valet parking that's available.

Special Offers - I hear that kids under 7 eat FREE.  That's what my colleague who lives in Tampa tells me.  He says they come here once a month with his 5 kids.  That's a great deal.

Will I return?  Only when I'm in the mood for massive amounts of meat....which is not too often.  That's not because I don't like the restaurant, it's because I don't eat meat that much.

This place is a dump.  It's basically a gutted warehouse that looks like it was built in the 1960's and hasn't been updated since.  We came here for a gun show, which had very few vendors.  The parking is small and the entry to the expo center is weird....it's on the right side near the back of the building.

If I was a meeting planner, I wouldn't hold any meetings here unless it was for a swapmeet.

Return Factor - 1%

Ok, so I found this place using Yelp.  I was in town on business and my hotel was only a couple of miles away.  After reading the excellent reviews, I decided to give it a try by myself.  Here are my thoughts.....

Service - Everyone was friendly and knowledgeable.  I was greeted by the host and seated immediately.  My waitress was on top of things and the food came out on time an fresh.

Food - I had the Tomato & Feta Bruschetta w/Baked Tortilla for an appetizer....it was awesome!  I highly recommend it.  The bread was fresh and delicious.  For an entree, I had the cheeseburger....I would have tried something else, but I really wanted to try the bruschetta appetizer and I didn't think I could eat that and an entree by myself.  The burger was excellent....just the right size, not too large and not too small.  The fries were steak-cut fries and cooked perfectly....not too hard/soft.

Atmosphere - I was here in the Spring time and the weather was awesome....so I ate outside on the patio.  I'm glad I did....it was very relaxing.

Wine - The wine selection was decent....not great, but decent.  I had a glass of the Malbec....don't remember what the vineyard was though.

While I was dining....there were no more than 5 tables occupied in the joint.  I heard that lunch and brunch are much busier.  So, I guess if you want to enjoy the place and have a nice, relaxing time.....go at dinner.

Will I return?  If I'm in the area.....For Sure!

Stayed two nights here.  Rooms are very nice, but the bathroom is a little small.  They're modern and clean, which is very important to me.

They have a very good selection of restaurants.  We dined at the Buffet, Steakhouse & Mexican joint during our stay.  Reviews on those are here:

PY Steakhouse
http://www.yelp.com/biz/py-steakhouse-tucson#hrid:8KJbPpTCgqNlNOgIBiLAWw

Tequila Factory
http://www.yelp.com/biz/tequila-factory-tucson#hrid:32_J-W-4rNrDap9JNFCmog

Festa Buffet
http://www.yelp.com/biz/festa-buffet-tucson#hrid:bGixUWahY--pO_K9AC42-w

The staff is very friendly.  They greeted you at every guest touchpoint and asked if you needed assistance.

Overall, this was a very cool place for a short weekend getaway.

TIP - Be careful of the speed traps on the road to/from this place.  There are photo/radar speed traps that will nail you if you are not careful.  Signs warning you about it are small and difficult to read...easy to overlook.  A friend got a ticket during our trip

Return Factor - 88%

This bar was located in the lobby of the hotel I was staying at.  The place is decorated with sports memorabilia and the banners of the local teams. 

Food - The food here is ok.  I tried the Angus Sliders, which were good and the nachos, which were bleh.  The menu is an extensive bar menu with all of the typical bar menu items.

Drinks - It is a full bar, so they can make all types of drinks.  The one thing that surprised me was that they didn't have Shock Top....which is a wheat beer.  You can find Shock Top all over Tampa, but not here for some reason.  Instead, they have Blue Moon....which is very good, but I enjoy Shock Top when I'm in Tampa.

Service - The waitresses and bartenders here are very friendly.  However, at times they can forget about you and leave you with an empty glass for a while.  One good thing is that there are tons of TVs in the bar, so if there is a game you want to watch that's not on one of the TVs, they will put it on one for you.

Will I return?  If I'm staying in the area.....yes.

Amazing find on Yelp....my business partner and I were in Tampa for a business meeting and decided to get some Italian Food....found The Laughing Cat and were glad we decided to take the trip to Ybor City.

Food - I had a Caprese Salad for an appetizer while my friend had the Mussels with Marinara sauce.  The portions were huge.  

For entrees, I had the Lasagna while he had the Veal Parmigiana....again, both huge portions.  The Veal was really big....there was no way we were going to finish.

The food was excellent.  The only thing that I would have liked done differently is that I like my pasta al dente.  The Lasagna was a little overcooked in my opinion.....great flavor though.

Service - The service was awesome.....can't complain.

Atmosphere - The place is a hole in the wall.....not upscale by any means, but the food is worth it.

Will I return?  If I'm back in the area....you bet!

On the way back to Phoenix, I searched the Yelp app for a Sandwich joint nearby to grab some lunch before the trip.  This place had 4 & 5 Star reviews, so I thought I found a winner.  I ordered:

8" Deluxe Grinder, $4.89
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/eegees-tucson-4?select=5GUDytvicuMtazmAP7_uhg#5GUDytvicuMtazmAP7_uhg

French Fries, $2.29
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/eegees-tucson-4?select=hUcEgMIuvWuP_URura7TAw#hUcEgMIuvWuP_URura7TAw

The Grinder was just ok at best.  I thought the Bread was too soft and sweet for my tastes....almost like Wonder Bread, but shaped like a Hoagie.

The Fries were nothing to brag about either.

Overall, it's a 3 Star joint for me....would have given 2.5 Stars if Yelp had 1/2 Stars available.

Return Factor - 10%

On the second night of our trip, we decided to give this joint a try.  The standard complimentary Chips & Salsa are served when you sit down.  We asked the waiter for extra spicy Salsa and he gladly obliged with a Habanero Salsa that kicks your heiney....yum!

After browsing the menu, we decided to order:

Cheese Crisp, $3

2 Crispy Tacos & 1 Bean tostada, $12
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/tequila-factory-tucson?select=pCI5eN2ZiGzVnJl7ppauDg#pCI5eN2ZiGzVnJl7ppauDg
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/tequila-factory-tucson?select=pufGHErnon1I3FlCCnL8Eg#pufGHErnon1I3FlCCnL8Eg

Chicken Arizona (Chicken Breast, Avocados, Tomatoes, Green Chile, Pepper Jack Cheese, Veggies, Spanish Rice), $10
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/tequila-factory-tucson?select=mTrEqN0RXH7ONKqdI2B6Yw#mTrEqN0RXH7ONKqdI2B6Yw
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/tequila-factory-tucson?select=OIhripvCwd2wcqxbnsUTtQ#OIhripvCwd2wcqxbnsUTtQ

Number 6 - 3 Soft Tacos (Carne de Cabeza, Trepas de Leche, Chicharron), $12
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/tequila-factory-tucson?select=WozpsO6J77Zhvwx6PblT8Q#WozpsO6J77Zhvwx6PblT8Q
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/tequila-factory-tucson?select=hcM2oHdeErA9yjzcjf2vIw#hcM2oHdeErA9yjzcjf2vIw

The Cheese Crisp was ok.  So was my Tacos & Tostada.  I wasn't overly blown away with it.

The Better Half had the Number 6 combo and it was a little to exotic for her.  She didn't realize that she was ordering Cow Brains, Cow Stomach, and Pork Skins....LOL  

Kiddo had the Chicken Arizona and he was very pleased with it.

Overall, it's an OK dining experience.  

Return Factor - 60%

Located near the Tucson airport, this casino is nice, but very small.  Self parking is kind of far from the entrance.  We walked from the hotel to the casino and it was a bit of a walk....not sure why they didn't make it closer.

The machines were so/so...it's all luck anyway, but the selection of machines were quite limited.

Return Factor - 50%

I am visiting Tampa for a week on a business trip and asked the front desk clerk at the hotel where I'm staying where I should go for dinner.  She referred me to The Green Iguana, which is located near the Football and Baseball Stadiums.  I decided to go check this place out.

Food - I asked the bartender what their most requested dish was....she said the "Cheesiest Cheeseburger"....so, I decided to give it a shot.  Here's what the menu says about it:

"CHEESIEST CHEESE BURGER - $7.49
Nobody - but nobody - puts more cheese on a burger than the Green Iguana. Triple-cheesed with American, Cheddar, Provolone and mayo."

The burger was very good.  Not the best I've ever had, but very good.

Service - Since I was eating alone, I ate at the bar.  The bartender was very friendly and was very helpful in helping me choose.  She made sure that my glass of beer was never empty.  Overall, the service was above average.

Atmosphere - From what I've heard, this place can be really fun.  But since I went there on a Tuesday night, it was relatively calm.  It reminded me of a bar you would see in Mexico or somewhere Tropical.....kind of like a Jimmy Buffet meets Cabo type of thing.

Would I come back?  Yes, but would prefer to be there with some friends or my wife.....felt kind of uncomfortable being there alone.  Although, I overheard some interesting conversations at the bar...LOL.

One of the worst airports I've ever been to.  Main reason is because it's $7.95 for WiFi here....#fail

If it wasn't for the food & music in the bars/restaurants, I'd give it 1 star.  The worst part is that I actually like Nashville the city, so I'll probably have to come here again.

Return Factor - 90%

We passed on the seafood buffet and came back the next day for the brunch. Me and my BF loved the food.. it had a great selection. There was fresh seafood, chicken soup, salads, pizza, and MEXICAN food. The tacos were to die for.

One strange note.. the lady kept saying bye when we got up from the table..even though we were heading for my food. After we got dessert, she said bye again.. it was getting kind of irritating.

$40 for two to get in
$30 cab ride 
$30 drinks

partying with the "wolfpack"... priceless. JK, but seriously the taxi cab drive was so excited when he told us that the wolfpack was going to be there. My bf thought he meant the rap group..I thought he meant the cook LOL

This club was vegas-esque but a bit on the smaller side. The bathrooms were super nice and the music was okay.. and the crowd was really diverse. Apparently UNR won the football game so the school was out celebrating. I wonder how dead it is when they don't win..

I have been having my nails done for some time now.  I am an esthetician and my hands are often abused and in water.  I need my nails short for my job and polish doesn't last.  I started having gel manicure several years ago and while I loved them at first the love affair didn't;t last.  The gel would lift and I would peel it off. Over time this caused damage to my nail and I had given up being told that the gel "just wouldn't stick" and that "I would need them done weekly" After being with Verla for several months now I can say I won't go anywhere else.  She offers a wide variety of brands of gel manicures and after hearing my story we decided to try another brand.  Who Knew??  so now I am back with one of my all time classic favorite colors: ESSIE BALLET SLIPPERS. She has a magic touch and while I haven't changed jobs or anything I am doing at home; the polish STAYS PUT! The gel Mani includes cuticle work, filing, and the best hand massage ever! Try a pedicure too. My polish doesn't chip even when my toe nail does :-)

We love visiting our local bakery!  My oldest is anaphylactic to dairy and eggs and going to a bakery is a very special treat. We always find something safe and served with a smile. I can't recommend them more :)

Def the place to go to get a taste of all local brews. Also a small wine selection. Being small as it is and unfortunately they were out of one ( only 6 total ). Great selections for veggies and vegans. Impressed by the selection actually!  Keep it up. This was my second visit and some of the kinks have been worked out with staff. The first time it seemed disorganized. But I'm always for giving a great local place a second try. Nice neighborhood feel. Smoke free.  Bar seating separate from the dining area. I have high hopes for this little place!

We dined as a party of 6 at 5:30 on a Saturday. The service was ok. Food slow. With 6 people we had an assortment of items. 2 entree salads 1 deep dish 1 specialty 1 sausage pizza 1 wrap   The salads were the last to come out. About 5 minutes after everyone else. And of course they waited. The salad description called for two types of nuts and feta cheese which were left out. The specialty pizza was nothing like the description. If you want a deep dish with meat toppings then this is your place. Anything off that path is probably not going to meet the description.

I recently ate at blu moon with a friend for lunch, after having passed it several times.  I have to say that I will go back!  I too was somewhat confused on the ordering, paying, cleanup process but basically its cafe style where you order at the counter and have a seat.  They bring the food to the table and speaking of the food!  I am taking on some healthier patterns of eating and am having a bit of a hard time eating out.  but they were happy to help when I presented my (list of) needs.  I ended up with a very nice portion of spinach and lentil salad and a lovely bowl of spicy vegan tomato soup!  the price was right: $6 bucks give or take. the soup alone will take me back!  its hard to find a vegan tomato soup and this was full of spice!  I will say that they have a flyer for vegan gluten free yummy sounding sweets and nothing to show!  these items were not available the day I dined and my mouth was kind of watering at the thought!  oh well , maybe next time ;)

I admit I kind of stopped going here when ownership changed. I gave it another try on my birthday. My 40th!  Now while some may look at this a an opportunity to tie one on, my birthday is in the middle of December and along with all the usual 'extras' it's one of my busiest months. And did I mention it was my 40th?  Partying isn't in my vocabulary anymore. Not calling myself a old lady but ... Anyway. The review:  I was exhausted from a 14 hour day. Looked like a drowned rat as it had rained and snowed that day. And the server absolutely made my night!  I think her name was Sara but maybe Rebecca ( it was almost 2 months ago :(
She was very friendly but not in the fake " I just want a bigger tip" kind of way .. all suggestions were outstanding and I even tried her suggestion of sparkling saki after my glass if champagne. I had the h2o version of a BLT called the ELT. Eel lettuce tomato. Soooooooo goooood!  The eel was smoked in a way that certainly reminded me of what I remember bacon tasting like and I used to turn my nose up at eel. !  Try the Tuna appetizer even if you don't think you like raw tuna!  It's worth a trip just for that. Oh and the cookie and espresso dip   !!!  Oh and the coffee is served with your very own coffee press ( although you can share if you want ). I have been back recently just for the coffee and cookies for desert ;)
Well done!  Glad the ownership issues seem settled! 
Fun. New. Great art!  Don't let the contemporary feel scare you away. The servers are witty and smart and very good at making suggestions!

Yum. Great burgers. My favorite is the chicken lettuce wraps. I've even gone during the middle of 'whole 30' and stayed in the program. Great service and I love the little patio in the summer. Great for girls night out. Lunch date or impromptu date night. We've never had to wait for a table.

Major props to these guys. I had to rent a snowboard for my 10 yr old.
We were charged for an adult setup & then the sweet cashier couldn't figure out how to credit back the difference to my credit card. They asked us to resolve it when we were done skiing & brought the equipment back.
When we got back there was a bit of confusion about why we were requesting the refund, but all in all what they gave us was a free rental for next time, so all is good.
The service is always good. Everyone who is fitting renters seems to know what they are doing and I appreciate the quality of knowledge about the area and skiing/ riding in general.
Plus, the equipment is great. I couldn't buy such awesome gear for my kids (nor would I) so it's nice to get to ride something amazing every once in a  while.

Well, the decor was cool. I love rich decor. I love russians. I love vodka.

BUT, this bar and the people in it were a little stuck on themselves.
It's like the hot girl at the party that won't talk to anyone because she thinks she's too hot. 

Maybe Pravda is too hot for the quarter, but I beg to differ.

They do serve drinks though, so I won't go on.

This is a standard classy joint.
The bartenders are cool, professional gentlemen.
Mr B's caters to a sophisticated business clientele, but still has the New Orleans flavor.
I was lucky enough to be sitting at the bar next to a self proclaimed, "conservative bastard". Awesome! Welcome to New Orleans.

The seafood gumbo is delicious(bowl licking good). I didn't, but I thought about it. Solid cocktails - an enjoyable experience whether there for business or pleasure.

Don't want to be in the Quarter?
Don't want to listen to drunks and clowns all night long?
Great location - walkable to the Quarter and Convention Center, and the trolley.
Good rooms, but bad beds. I don't even know what to think about the beds except they felt like prison beds with an extra coverlet. Major Fail!
But, Staff was amazing - every single one! The bellmen, the front desk ladies, especially the server who came out and made us bloody mary's before the bar opened. I am telling everyone I know about this location, because not only am I a loyal Saints fan and a loyal Hilton member, I love this location. Boom!
They have a breakfast buffet, free wireless, and fridges and microwaves in the rooms. A decent workout room and pool.
This is a good spot for grownups.

Let's start with slowest free wifi ever.
But, as I sit in my room, which over looks the ocean and the best sunset I've seen in a  very long time, and I listen to covers of Bob Marley being sung from across the water, there is nothing better right now.
This is a cool spot. The location is righteous. Average restaurant attached, but great happy hour, and good snacks. Very reasonably priced.
The rooms are dated. but clean. Old school and prob perfect for a family vacation. Each balcony which overlooks the water is superb. The view is money. 
If you face the parking lot...so sad, too bad. 
Even the shittiest hotel is most awesome with a waterfront balcony, reggae music, and a glass of vino.
Done!

My bff recommended this place and I was so excited to get my NoLa eat ON.
Alligator cheesecake. Watermelon mojitos. The lamb sirloin entree with greens and mashed potatoes on the side. Honestly, one of the best damn meals I have ever had.
Great service. Charming environment. Off the beaten path location, uptown on Oak St. Took the trolley back down to the Quarter easily.
Not only a recommend, but a Must-Go!

Fantastic service!
You can choose between bistro (bar) seating or the fine dining area. You can still get the fine dining menu in the bistro area but there are plenty of choices on both menus.
The lamb lollypops were delicious - the pesto was a nice touch.
The crab cakes had a spicy kick. Great for a little snappy appy with a glass of wine.
Te chicken mushroom Caesar  salad had great flavors and was plenty for one or two to share. Good wine list and   plenty of options for steak or small plates.
Good variety. Good westport option.

Quick service and good food.
We ordered toasted ravioli (Oh I miss you St Louis!), and then each had the soup/ salad combo. Great prices for good food. 
A few soups to choose from, we had clam chowder and chicken tortilla soup, which was prepared with actual tortilla chips (not strips), but had a cheesy bottom and was really good. We chose caesar salads over the house salad, and it was a good size - great lunch portions.
Pleasant staff. Great location - a quick walk to the arch grounds - right on Laclede's Landing.

Day trip. Average girls...almost too young to look at.

I got carded and I know I'm old enough to mother the bartenders. The theme is the same as the rest of the chain.
They did have a super cute collection of hard hats which I wanted to take home. 
Other than that, it's a pit stop on the road to live music.

It leaves a lot to be desired, but the food is good. Cooked right in front of you on one of those grills I don't think ever gets really cleaned, that's probably why the food is so "tasty".

They have something on the menu called "scrapple". Described on the menu as sausage & hash browns dipped in pancake batter, fried & covered in gravy.
I had a ham and tomato omelet, with a side of hash browns. You can pick items ala carte to add to your 2 egg/ cheese omelet. Very good.
Very small, limited seating, but a family atmosphere. The bar seating was a tad too close to the griddle for me, but again, a family feel.
It almost reminded me of a truck stop without the showers and convenience store registers.

Listed as one of the top 25 things to do in St. Louis...Amazing!!
Great for kids of all ages. A brilliant, clue finding, Sherlock Holmes exhibition with secret hideaways, double mirrors and hidden laboratories.
This is only one section of one wing.
There is history, games, all interactive fun times and frolic.
Climbing and discovery - a full afternoon of fun.
Super cool music displays - all interactive. Kaleidoscopes. Train exhibits. Dress up bays. Science corners. Slides all over this house.
An entire wing modeled after the Oval office, a courtroom, and the senate. Tons of information on the House and Senate, Presidential trivia, and podiums for kids to stand up and speak up!
This Magic house is brilliant.

This place reminded me of an old school, Boston mafia restaurant where the big boys hang in the back room smoking cigars and drinking hard liquor while the music out front keeps their tales hushed. ha!
But, the boys in the back weren't that cool.
The music is great - Frenchman St at it's best.
Cool atmosphere for grownups.
Nuff said.

LOVED IT!!
Frenchman Street at it's best. The music is consistently good. Love me some horns (and horn players).
Great energy here.
Good people.
It is probably one of the places I will remember as a "must-go" next time I am there. 
OUTSTANDING!

Gotta love live music...

New Orleans does it and does it well.

This is an upscale (pricey) experience for Frenchman Street. The band that was playing had a $30 cover. Downstairs, you could sit and watch on TV what was going on in the other room, but it doesn't compare to the other venues along the same Avenue.

If it's a special occasion, do it, but just wandering around...pass.

One thing I noticed about St. Petersburg is that there are more ice cream stores than people it seemed, but they were all busy. Weird.
I walked in initially because it had a serious Italian feel, and I thought maybe there would be some pizza in there too. ha! 
Not my lucky day.
This ice cream shop had wonderful flavor choices, and a sweet, funny staff. I appreciated the independent shop feel. Great location and a great people watching patio.
I am not a fan of ice cream, but if I was this would be where I would always find something good.

Great rate thru expedia.com. The staff was courteous but not overzealous about their job. The room we had was huge and had a long hallway reminiscent of the old movies where someone gets killed in the Quarter and a fine mystery ensues. 
More character than most places I have ever stayed. Traditional southern charm and architecture made me really happy we chose this place.
The courtyard was sweet and there was so much appeal to stay here over the chains in the area that hold no charm whatsoever.
Sits on the riverfront, and walking distance to everything in the Quarter, Frenchmen St, and the financial district - including access to the trolley stop on Canal St which will take you uptown for something different.
The bed was comfortable, the rooms were cool and dark, like I like my sleeping quarters to be.
Perfect.

3-4-1 hh whoa!
Karaoke
Cool crowd. Fun times in the Quarter! 
There are so many bars to choose from, but this is one of the good ones.

I haven't been here since I was a kid, and to be honest I was not looking forward to going up in the arch. I had slight memories of it being shaky and creeping me out. But, my kid wanted to go up in that tiny little elevator to the top of the arch, so we did.

The TSA reminiscent line out the door of the Memorial was almost a deterrent.
Especially after coming back from D.C. and not having these lines or the premise of terror in the nations capital, I hardly expected this here.
The lines moved quickly but the times were off after entering the hold stations for the ride to the top.

The grounds were clean. The view was amazing. It is a mini historical tour of the St Louis landmark. Well worth seeing, but be prepared for unnecessary hassle prior to entrance.

The room was comfortable. Close to the airport, with  free shuttle (always a bonus). Unfortunately, the days I was there, the van was without a/c, and it was about 99 degrees at 5p. Hot and sweaty is no way to kick off your New Orleans adventure.
It is about 20 minutes to the French Quarter via cab.
The staff was a little tense, may have been the heat, but very informative.
It was a pretty quiet location which is always my choice for any hotel.

I was really excited to stay here due to the hotel being located in St Louis Union Station (because of the history and architecture). 
We entered the hotel from the surface lot, and as a result had a hard time finding our way to the front desk as this is a very large property. A helpful customer saw us in the hallway and informed us that we would have to ride the elevator up two floors to check in.
The hotel itself was quite nice. Our room had a couch and queen sized bed and the bathroom was roomy with the toilet in one section, the sink in another and the tub/shower in a third. There were a lot of hairs on the bathroom floor along the wall, which is the first thing I noticed when I got in to the room and used the bathroom after the long trip.
The toiletries were nice and there was a Keurig brewer in our room with coffee and tea.
From the surface lot, in which we spent about 20 minutes in cruising and waiting for a parking space to open up due to the restaurants on site being popular, it was a long walk from the parking lot into the back of the hotel and to the front desk or to our room. Maybe there was a shorter way, but we never found it. If you or your group has a difficult time walking, it might be a good idea to check with the hotel about options.
Also, we had our dog with us and the parking lot and back of the property are somewhat limited as far as grassy areas. 
The highlight of the stay for me was that after a private party ended in the lounge, it was opened up to the public and it really is a stunning place. We enjoyed drinks in the lounge as well as the light show they put on.

To me, the Waffle House is a pretty much a George Webb plopped down in the south.
The food is OK and reasonably priced. We sat at the counter and had breakfast menu placemats, but later I noticed that those at tables had three menus and a lot more to choose from.
The counter area was understandably noisy due to plates and pans being stacked up there by the employees.
The manager was expediting food and overseeing prep quantity, and all of the employees we encountered were very nice.
The coffee was OK, the bacon was OK, the grits were well made and I had an obligatory plain waffle, which was OK as well. All in all this was an OK experience.

For a "hotel bar" May Bailey's is great. Dark, Victorian atmosphere, seating for twenty or so, and a decent drink selection.
This lounge may be a well-kept secret in the French Quarter, but some of the local service industry folks are onto it for sure.
I found it to be a perfect spot to wind down each night after exploring the French Quarter for hours, so much so that I ended up there every night I was in town. It was a nice break from the hustle.

This shop was one of my favorite stops on Cherokee Street. I got the feeling that a lot of the things I admired were not for sale because they didn't have prices on them, but it was great to just walk through and see things. It was like walking through an awesome quirky museum of americana, but keep in mind that I love old signs.
Definitely check out the outdoor area, which has a neat little bridge and is filled with trinkets, statues and cool signs, including a few hotel/motel signs. 
Yeah, I would live there.

In my opinion, the reason go to the Bayou Club is for Cajun/Zydeco music. The bar is kind of a dive and the bathrooms are mostly functional, not fashionable, but you'll be able to find something to drink, and if you're there at the right time you can hear some great live music.
There is a one drink minimum, but it's worth it.

Their gelato is really good and they carry an abundant amount of flavors. They do offer non-dairy items in the sherbet section. Two things that would improve their business: they need a punch card system to encourage customers to come back and their prices are a little high, compared to...no other gelato shops in Tucson -_- Makes sense. For two smalls, can equal up to $9. My fave is always Pistachio and Coconut.

This is our favorite place in Tucson. I love that it's a scratch kitchen and that the menu changes all the time! The cooks and owner are so friendly and personable. The food is always tasteful and fresh. They are so baby-friendly and always provide a little side of food for our 9 month old, which I think is so sweet of them. We feel comfortable eating here as a family rather than some other places who aren't so baby-friendly. We are vegetarians and like that they are conscious of gluten-free and vegan platters. They also offer cheese and eggs if you'd like. We highly recommend this place, but want to keep it as a hidden local gem for ourselves because it's getting very popular!

Friendly, excellent, reasonable prices, very clean! I usually use my own tools but I didn't with them because I trusted how well they clean their equipment. It's a family owned and operated business, which means better customer service. Walked in without an appointment and waited less than 2 minutes to be seen. Parking is free and open. Jimmy worked on me and he is very detailed and thorough from cleaning to polish. Highly recommend. So happy they're only up the block from me!

The best and only place to get an organic mani/pedi for pregnant women! If you're worried about harmful chemicals and fumes that may harm baby, GreenToes is the only salon that can rest assure be the safest and cleanest place to get your nails done. Plus, the techs are very nice and polite. It's pricey, but you pay for quality. In addition, I can't review on whether they do any designs or not - I haven't tried that yet, but I'm assuming you can't get Pinterest-worthy designs here.

Pros: It doesn't smell like formaldehyde like other salons. And they offer other services such as massages.
Cons: They don't have "spa" massage chairs.

Walked in for lunch in their new location and establishment. The place was a mess, the chairs were everywhere, the place was dirty, and there was no one inside the dining area and there were three people ahead of us waiting. After 5 minutes of no one paying attention to all of us, we all left. This was a bad move - they're trying to make this place a higher establishment. It's not functionally going well and the place looks like a dump. So sad for this restaurant. We miss the older location where it was thriving. They should take down the "now open" sign and work on their management because right now, it looks horrible.

Tried this place twice in a week! I tried the pretzel-encrusted chicken the first night - it was the perfect combination of tender, moist chicken breast encrusted with crispy pretzels and a sweet mustard sauce (drizzled on top for aesthetics/taste and definitely not too heavy on the drizzle). It was an excellent combination! The second night, I had the chipotle black bean burger with sriracha mayo and gouda. Wow. Totally flavorful and the right texture (not too mushy and not charred on the outside of the bean patty. 

In addition to the food, I also had to try the beers! I tried the hefeweizen, winter ale ESB, and the coffee stout. All of them were different but delicious. The hef would be a great, refreshing drink in the summer. The winter ale is a light amber and has a subtle spice note. The coffee stout was my favorite - subtly effervescent with a wonderful coffee taste and aroma. 

Overall, great food, great beer, and great service!

I almost don't want to write this review because the owner is so nice... but, I feel that I need to give a non-biased opinion of the bad as well as the good on Yelp!  

Let me start by saying that the suite we stayed in was HUGE - 2 bedrooms, living room, kitchen and private balcony... right on Bourbon Street... $150 per night... sounds too good to be true?  Yup, it is.  It is horrendously noisy!  Kind of run down and not the cleanest.  It was fine, the owner is very nice, but I wouldn't stay there again and certainly wouldn't recommend it.  

But, if you are going to be drinking until 4:00 am and just want a cheap place to crash that is centrally located, then this might be just the place for you.
Oh, Ragin' Daisy had the perfect leopard print coat that actually FIT!  I wish I would have bought it, but I knew it wouldn't fit in my suitcase for the trip back home.  Regret!!!

Friendly local hang out, quiet.  I came here because it was close to my hotel.  They have a big TV if you are into that.  I enjoyed the eclectic music playing when I was there, vintage Madonna then Joy Division.  

Bartenders are really nice and the food was a pleasant surprise.  I had a great burger and fries one time, the mac and cheese special with a salad another time, and the tomato basil soup the last time.  All were really well cooked and flavorful.  It kind of became my go-to for a tasty, casual meal.

An old school steakhouse in an office building!  Let's go tiki!

I was bummed that they could seat us right away, because I really wanted to have a Mai Tai in the vinyl-padded-seat type bar.  God, I love a comfy padded barstool.  

We are guided to our table through a large, low lit room.  Copper lanterns are on every table and the menu is printed on an old Lancers bottle!  So cool, except that there's only one menu and we were a party of five, so it was a bit awkward.  

I ordered a steak and it came with a basic baked potato and salad bar.  The salad bar was simple but really good.  And I got bacon bits for my potato.  Everything was really good, the Mai Tais too.  And not all crazy expensive.

We had such a nice time this evening chatting, drinking and eating.  I really love places like this and I would definitely come back!!

I had my first po'boy here.  It started as a typical tourist experience:  we heard from a local that we met at a bar where to go, then proceeded to find it.  Took the Magazine St. bus there, walked through the charming neighborhood, then thought, "okay, what was that address..."

So, we realized that it really was that little house-looking place on the corner with no visible sign (coming from where we were).  Walked in and sort of watched what other people did.  Realized that you take a number from the wall, then they call you to take your order.  Okay, all good now.  Found a table, ordered some red cream soda from the bar and hung out.  I watched the ladies dip and fry each order as it came in - oh so fresh!

Then..."#35" Oh goody!  Fried oysters on a soft, toasted roll.  Umm, umm, umm!  Put on a bit of hot sauce, and there was little talk as we chowed down.

The best part was when I realized that the little steps going up the side of the place actually led to the owner's house (dur, I said it looked like a house).  Too cool!  I love that family thing!  God bless New Orleans!

Let me just start by saying that I recently moved to the area from LA and my review may be a bit biased because of the caliber of Thai food that I am normally used to.  I should also note that I frequent some of the better Thai establishments around LA county so my review is probably bias.

Meun Fan Thai simply fell on "ok" status for me. My girlfriend and I went here to have lunch one weekend and we were really disappointed by the limited menu offerings and the quality of the food after we had ordered. Sure this place is nice and clean, but just because you have a gold elephant on the wall, it doesn't make your restaurant legit Thai.
One of the first things that I noticed about the menu was the lack of noodle soups. Sure there are hot pot and tom yum but where's the boat noodle? That should be a simple thing to have on the menu and is usually a staple item on just about any Thai menu.
My girlfriend ordered the Pad Thai and while the color and flavor were present, the noodles were a shame. They were more pho noodle than typical rice stick noodle that pad thai usually is made with. This made it more soggy and not as good to eat.
My order of curry noodle had a brick of noodles sitting in curry sauce.  It was sad. How does one overcook a brick of pre-prepped noodles?

Anyway, needless to say, 10$ per dish was not pleasing. Sure we pay higher prices due to location and area but dishes of this quality and caliber would not have been any more than 7.50 on any other menu.

I've passed this place many many times and normally wrote it off because it was often not busy inside and it is at the tail end of the Albertson's parking lot where nothing is open.
