Um you could say we left full.  Salsa bar is a nice touch and the covered patio seating is awesome.  This place is always packed especially during lunch and it's funny to watch the locals practice their Spanish with the man in charge.

One of the prettiest malls from the outside however there aren't many stored there that I frequented when I went to UCSB.  Now State street has had an Extreme Makeover.  Tons of brand names stores right on State like Juicy (but who really shops there now? even though I think there stuff is adorable), surf shops galore and Betsey Johnson.

It isn't always the cheapest (quite the contrary) but I used to have a Chevron card so this was a no brainer.  Not only did I come to this location for gas but for food, Reality Bites style.  No joke.  I remember coming home with bags full of groceries.  Snacks more like it...

I was a regular here and it is the most convenient place to fill gas whether you want to admit it or not.  I always stopped en route to go home to Monterey.
My sister and I played Nationals here for Junior Tennis in '94 or '95.  Of course, with my luck I would lose to a girl from Mexico living in Fresno, I mean Fres-yes.

Yes, I liked this place when it was Anthropologie more... however it is hard to dislike a place that sells adorable clothing for cheap (and it's okay that the quality is cheap because even if you get one or two "wearings" out of your outfit it is worth it).  Once I start making $$$ again I will like this place less but for now, I heart F21 but this one is not as organized as several of the others I have been to.

10 years ago when I was 20, I walked in with another female companion with a group of 6 or 8  guys (I don't remember) .  It was a Bachelor Party and they prettty much dragged us innocent girls in.  I'm pretty sure we weren't served although I don't remember (this is becoming the theme of this evening)...

Next thing I know we made it to her apartment and I had thrown up as I opened the door of her 325 ti... who drives a 325 ti... baby hatchback BMW?!?  (No that is not nice Shiho!)  It was a very cute car and a lovely birthday present she got when she was 16.

I rarely threw up back then so something must have gone done during the night.  I do not recall all the details but thank Sandbar for getting an eventful (unfortunately not very memorable for me) evening started.

Initially I sat down to kill some time while I waited for my friends to arrive from their United flight from LAX.  I didn't have many options so I sat down at Outpost Cafe with my large check-in bag and my ski bag and got a glass of Pinot Grigio.  Why not.  

Now I know the elevation of Boise is nothing extreme in fact it's probably sea level but Google just said they are about 1/2 mile above sea level... maybe that's why the wine hit me so hard?!? Probably because I'd neglected to eat my honey roasted peanuts and pretzels on my Southwest flight, lunch and breakfast.

I ended up ordering the wings because I felt bad for just sitting there... I ordered another glass of wine and this one was a big girl glass and I had a hard time finishing it...almost.  The wings were good but not as good as they were the day after.

Yes, I had 8 leftover so I took them with me to McCall, reheated and served them with fresh celery sticks and their ranch and my friend and I thought we had the best wings ever.  Seriously, they will be my Wingstop moving forward but unfortunately they are in Boise and I live in California.  Not lovely.

I like this Chevron (which was under construction) not for their gas but their mini mart.  They don't offer a lot but this is one of the last stops before Mt. Rose so it was conveneient to pick up some ice for our cooler to keep our beverages cold enough to enjoy post skiing... tailgating style.

Clean new smoke shop in a convenient location (if you are going to school at UCSB and have a car that is) offering all of your smoking supplies.  Cigs, cigars, cigarillos, pipes, tobacco etc...

Kind gentleman owner behind the counter who looks like he'd be happy to help you but usually you know what you want when you are hitting up these type of places.  This shop just opened its doors 3 months ago so hit it up if you are into this kind of stuff.

I don't smoke, nor do I socially smoke (smoke after drinking) because some people think those two are different but I heard my sister make a comment of pooping and cigarettes and as a person who always had a hard time pinching a loaf, I thought hey why not(question mark).  I'm not promoting smoking but am promoting healthy and regular bowel movements.

Special: Marlboro Menthol Lights 2 packs for $8

Back in the day I would coe here with some of my teammates after a grueling session on the court.  We'd hit the salad bar and grab a refreshing beverage and call it a day before getting ready to go out.  Gelson's provides good quality food and they are known for their great customer service and friendly faces.
Funny or not I didn't frequent this place until after I graduated and left UCSB.  It wasn't until I went to visit my sister did I get to enjoy a cold brewski and some bar grub.  Fun dive joint.
Opened yesterday!! Finally an actual Chase Bank in Nevada and boy just an ATM. Californians thank you!

Even though I didn't have the best of luck with my entree I'm giving this place 4 stars for a killer ambiance in downtown Boise.  This place was happening Thursday night after we trekked into BOI from LAX, IAH and SJC, we were tired and a bit hungry and definitely parched. 

We wanted to grab something before heading up to McCall so we ventured into Bardenay.  This place was alive and they don't mess around on their drinks.  Especially their vodka in gin which they distill...

I got the Bardenay Bond... which was gin & vodka shaken and served up.  I love a fat stiffy but this was almost too much for me... or maybe it was because I've had so many bad experiences with gin that we don't mix well anymore?  Regardless, my friend finished it for me.  

I did something that I have never done and ordered that lame entree that one would if you don't have much of a palate or in some cases culture and got the Fettucini Alfredo... only putting it out there like that because their menu is extensive and impressive.  They have a whole section devoted to Satay Sticks which I found so sexy.  

I didn't have it in me, I wanted something plain, simple and comforting.  I'd been craving Alfredo Sauce all week so I just went with it.  Stoked I did as it was simple yet pretty tasty.  The only problem was that it was cold.  Not warm but borderline cold.  I had it taken back ( I rarely have things taken back) and it came out within minutes and it was still cool.  Not warm but cool.  Strange.  I should have said put it in the microwave for 60 seconds, that would have done the trick.  I pretty much ate it all anyway, I was hungry and it was solid.


Calamari was ordered as well as a deep fried Chimichanga among others.  My friends were enjoying the selection of beers as I worked hard on my Bond.  If I'm ever in this neck of the woods again, I'd definitely hit them up.

I still get giddy when I step foot into Woodstock's.  Although I grabbed lunch down the street, I ordered one of the Specials (we didnt' have those options when I was a student)... a Med. 1 Topping Pizza which comes with a Cinnabread for $14 or something... you save a few bucks... but I opted for the Wildbread with Ranch.  They have Killer Ranch and I got a Med. Mushroom Pizza... oh this was to-go so I could enjoy it with my friends in Monterey that have never experienced Woodstocks.

The man that helped me out must have been the owner or manager as he was definately there when I was (class of '02) and he grabbed a cup for me to put ice in for my ranch... I nearly teared up.  So smart and sweet!

The pizza almost didn't make it through the 3 hour drive.  See I gave my sister and her roommate a slice and I ate 3... It actually saved me from getting a speeding ticket.  I knew I was going way too fast so I pulled to the right lane and stuffed my face with a slice and let the PoPo drive past me on my left... I figured the faster I drove home, the more pizza and Wildbread there would be for the others.

I love you Woodstock's.  Thank you for the good memories.  My favorite is still the one of my friend Nini eating someone else's leftovers...

Four stars only because this quickly became my favorite late night study spot.  Library is great but too eerily quiet for me and at Denny's I could study for finals while being served coffee, salad with ranch and chicken tenders if I wanted.  Service was what you'd expect... young college students trying to make a dollar, service was slow at times but in general that was fine since I was there taking advantage of their 24hours.
I've been to a hanful of airports in the states.  And this is the least memorable. I love how it is an International Airport.  I was told that they only fly to Canada... does that count?

Figured they were open but there wasn't a hostess since we crept in before 11pm on a Monday night.  I can see this place "happening" if there were people there but not so much tonight. The outside ambiance reminded me of a small condensed lounge in Vegas or South Beach but just for a minute... I enjoyed the loungy vibe outside, firepit and the outdoor bar makes for a perfect place to host a celebration like a birthday party or a fun party during the day.  Drinks were on the pricier side with the house Sangria being over $10+ per glass but we had just finished dinner up the street so we went in for desert.  The Chocolate Bread Pudding was perfect presentation wise but failed in taste.  It wasn't really warm or chewy and gooey.  More like dry, stale and reminded of an old cupcake.  The whipped cream was refreshing and the caramel created a beautiful design on the white plate but tasted off... over burnt or something.

Our server was sweet but our experience overall was not lovely.  The only reason why I'd ever come back would be either on a Thursday or Friday pre-partying to go out to a club or something on State Street which isn't in my plans in the near future.
Oh man, I only rememebr being here for a few minutes but I'm sure I was there for an hour or so.  Trendy nightclub and sushi bar a little drive away from downtown.
Always a pleasant experience here and I'm pretty sure I bought all my readers here.  Super convenient especially if you live in IV.
Love and miss their smoothies.  Always hit up the one in IV and if I went downtown to run errands I'd usually have one of these in my hand.   Enjoy Blenders more than Jamba.  Sorry JJ.

Stopped in briefly on my way home from LA.  Friendly and they offer fresh organic produce and goods.  I was impressed with my Vegan brownie and Kombucha tea (the first time I bought although my sister makes a pretty mean batch).  In the state I was in, I should have saved the Kombucha for another time as it felt like it ate my insides.  I was hurting from 3 night bender in LA.

Any who, when I got the cash register I noticed someone behind the counter who looked just like me.   My little sister works there and she loves it.  I can see why.

When Costco ran out of LEIS... Albertson's came to the F-ing rescue with a fresh batch of leis scattered on a table by one of the doors... we were stoked!!!  We would have felt naked and worthles without a lei for our tropical looking sister.  Thank You Albertson's for having our back this time around (my sister's college graduation) but NO Thank you for the freshman 30 I mean 15 (back in 1998)!!!

I think this is the bar with 2 stages in 2 different rooms.  I knew I was in Nashville when I experience my 2nd culture shock of the day...

I had to tinkle and I walked straight into the bathroom.  There was a trough for men to pee in a plastic shower curtain for the ladies to pee in private.  Well the shower curatin really didn't cover the stall so it was hard to pee standing up crouched over the toilet with my thighs burning all the while holding the curtain up.

I thought it was a unisex toilet... I don't know, it was my first time in Nashville. 

Um... apparently it was the Men's Restroom and none of the 5 men lined up around the bathroom had the balls to tell me.
Stern's Wharf and the beach along Cabrillo is a nice stretch of palm trees and sand.  Catch people playing volleyball, rollerblading and cute boys skating their hearts out in the skate park.

Yes!!! I am a fan!!!

Me and my dogs love visiting this location :) 

I have always saved coming here, between coupons and their sales! Last bill, I saved $35 off my bill so I am not complaining! The staff is always there to assist you with questions or concerns. The cashiers are so sweet and friendly!

The selection is endless!!! I have NEVER not found what I was looking for. Located in a great location and easy to find! The store is clean and I love having my babies with me to shop for new toys for them.

The bling dog tags are too cool also!!!!

I just enrolled my pup in training classes so i will see you guys soon :)

I guess we got spoiled in Seattle on Thai food. I was very excited about eating here based on the reviews. They are always busy. My taste buds for Thai are much different to what I have had in Michigan, California and Washington State compared to here. Many Thai restaurants have a different flare. Their is a great Thai population in WA, maybe that's why.

The reason for the low stars, I gave was based only on how cute this place is and my husband did enjoy his Pad See Ew. He however did say they go a little over board on the garlic, and had slight heart burn. I however had the Pad Thai. It was very good going down, but a hour later I started getting hot, stomach ache, horrible heartburn and then spent the last 6 hours running to the bathroom. NOT A PRETTY PICTURE!

I am sorry but this was a big turn off for me. The food wasn't to spicy it was just over powered with garlic. Good thing I am not a vampire. I think this place is dang cute so I am SO upset that our experience was a dud here (sad face).

This is the bottom of the trash can of all Walmarts!! 

Place is so all over the place I get confused. The selection is awful and good luck trying to find 2 of anything. People just throw anything anywhere and the employees never address this issue. 

Now, don't get me started on the cashiers....wow!!! First off they look like they lost their best friend. No personality and act like you are bothering them. I won't return here! 

I need a shower and a drink after leaving this location! Uggg!!!!

Oh, and my check in's where to return the crap I bought that fell apart the moment you opened it!!

Okay, everyone complains about the line! It moves pretty fast so don't sweat it! Trust me it is well worth the line. Not to mention they have coffee out there for you while you wait. :)

Upon entering the place is one floor and very cute. Kind of has a Europe kind of feel to it! From the moment of entering to the moment you sit down you are greeted with TRUE southern hospitality! The waitress is quick with your drinks. 

Now to the food:
1. Coffee is strong so beware!
2. Apple Juice is good, but not pure juice.
3. The sweet potato pancakes are SERIOUSLY OUT OF THIS WORLD!
4. Wild Blueberry pancakes are AMAZING.
5. Hash browns are ok, nothing to write home about. 

Upon leaving everyone from the waiter to bus boys make sure to thank you for coming and thank you for your business! Love that!! 

The things that prevented me from giving them 5 stars are:
1. Our waitress waiting on 2 tables before us that arrived after us.
2. Their food arriving well before ours and them being done eating by the time we got ours and they arrived after us. 
3. Bathrooms, need cleaning and toilet paper. 2 stalls had nothing. 

Other than that, I WILL be back!!!

Okay so I have been ordering the same coffee the same way for years!!! 


So here we go folks:

I go thru the drive thru, I place my order... And what do I get in return, a lecture on how I don't need to say this when I order it, and how I only have to order it this way...and on and on for 2 minutes to only confuse me...I was so irate and confused...I will NOT return here!!!. I think this guy working here either takes his job too serious or needs another job where he can tell people what to do. When I want my coffee, I want it with a total and a smile...no lecture on how to order a Starbucks coffee, when seriously dude, I come from Seattle where Starbucks was established!! Gezzzz...annoying!!!! 

FYI: a iced coffee means cold, not luke warm... That means you serve it cold, shall I lecture you on how to make a iced coffee???

Servizio Scadente!!

Well I have to say I am very disappointed. Communication and service play a big factor in this review. The food is saving them from 1 star to be honest. 

First off I made reservations via their website. I asked them if they could do cakes? They contact me 2 days prior to our event saying no, try calling this place. At that point I already ordered one elsewhere. 

Secondly, I made reservations for my hubby's birthday. This was such an important day as we are expecting and he had to leave the next day for training out of state. I asked for a romantic spot. They sat us just anywhere and not one person said a thing to him regarding his birthday. Glad I didn't bring his cake there cause I think they would of just brought it out any slopped it down in front of him! Very very disappointed on how they could of cared less if we were there or not! 

Lastly every time I asked for something they gave it to my husband. I am looking at the guy, like HELLO I asked you for the drink NOT him! This happened I think 3 times! 

I been to MANY Italian restaurants and being italian I can be very picky on the food. I will admit the food is great. The service needs work! If you have a piss poor attitude it's going to reflect on your customers and they won't return! There are many italian restaurants to choose from so I won't be returning.

Look for a sign "Pet Supplies" that's this place :) 

Super cute shop. They took the time to go over recall on foods with us. What food they recommended for helping our one dog loose weight 2 months ago and he has lost 6 pounds so far so their selection was right on!! I could be happier. 

They have cute items for you as well. You will get lost in here looking at all the cute stuff. So come and spend some time here, super fun find! They also do grooming here! :) 

They also carry frozen buffulo bones for your dogs, which I was looking everywhere for!!! My Golden is so very happy again.

Okay, bye bye GNC!! This place proves how over priced you are!! My same dairy free shake is $7 less here!!! For the same size, same thing, same brand!!! $7 LESS!!! A few bucks, ok fine, but $7, seriously?? GNC will soon go out of business if they keep jacking up their prices!!! I now will only go here for everything! Being healthy and buying healthy products should not brake your pocket book. Oh, and the same rosé petal witch hazel was over $3 cheaper at Whole Foods and here!!! So do your research before you buy. I highly recommend The Vitamin Shoppe!!!!!

We had a lovely time! Drinks were great. Bands were outstanding. Waitress was ok, but not the best. Some staff really lacked the southern hospitality. Very dry. 
As far as food:
Kids chicken nuggets were a hit! Tarter tots over fries!! Way better! Nachos are amazing but SO BIG!! This is enough for 3-4 people! Burgers I thought were ok. Nothing like the waitress went on and on about! 
All in all, I enjoyed our time here. Would come back again.

I honestly come here for the bread!!!

Hands down the best bread!!

THREE WORDS: TOMATO BASIL BREAD!!!

If you haven't tried this bread you are SO missing out.

WI-FI is great, never have a issue. My man loves the salads and soups and I have to admit the soups are pretty yummy. French Onion is his fave!!!

Not big on coffee but he states it is pretty good!

Went here for an Elite Yelp Party, I have to say that the place is cozy and very welcoming. The staff is friendly and helpful. Only had a chicken taco, but they were wonderful. I would go back to give this place another chance to earn 5 stars, I just need to taste more of that menu. :)) 
Oh and the margaritas are outstanding. :))

Best service and best coffee!

Always greeted with a smile and a hello. Coffee is always fresh, donuts are always fresh as well. I come here a lot to buy for my offices and I always have the most pleasant experience!!

Love going here. The food bars always have a great selection and the penna chicken pasta salad is YUM YUM YUMMY!!!

I never have issues finding what I need. Layout is great. I even found the clam sauce in bulk this time. The staff is great, super helpful and cheerful! 

He salad bar had my 2 favorite olives so I stocked up!!! 
Somedays they have some great deals if your lucky to find them. I suggest calling before hand to check if something u need is on sale.

The bad out way the good here. For starters, the organic veggie selection is horrible. Everything is half dead. Even the regular non organic items aren't all that great. I always have to find stuff I missed on my list somewhere else as they never have everything I need.

The pharmacy is useless in helping you as well. Them assisting you seems too much work.  Sticking with Publix.

First off walking into this place is like walking into a classy French furniture store. They have the most beautiful chairs & sofas to sit on while you wait. One of thee most classy waiting rooms I have ever been in!!! You feel like royalty. SERIOUSLY!! 

Dr. Anderson is outstanding. I really like her and I am very pleased with her!! 

The staff is overly friendly and wonderful! I was blown away on how nice everyone was. I have to say, the wait to get in was well worth it. 

Ladies, this is the place to go for all your lady needs. Perfection

Fast seating and fast food....not a very friendly place though. 

I gave our waitress a $11 tip on a $18 meal for the holidays and no care. She took the bill and looked at it like she expected more. Really???

Food is equal to Taco Bell. I have had much better Mexican. I won't return, only went here cause our Thai place next door was closed. 

I gave them 2 stars because the decor inside is lovely.

Got a little lost lol, they helped me find where I needed to be. So kind and beautiful airport. Simple to find what you need inside the airport. Clean and decorated very nice! Everyone is very helpful. :)

They screwed up my ugg & gucci boots! So pissed! They also put oil on a pair of $1000 boots that don't require oil and some how shrunk them! They are ruined! First round here they did great, 2nd round they ROYALLY screwed up!!!!! So very mad!

Applause!!! 

Okay, I am a Dunkin Donut kind of gal, but I think I found heaven! Yes this place is a little slice of heaven!

Treated myself to the old fashion chocolate donut, which was amazing. Also got the glazed donut holes for my pa, who LOVED them. Gone in less then 5 minutes. Hubby got there cinnamon twist and he can't stop talking about it. 

A MUST go!!!

I've been in here a bunch recently due to getting some dental work. The office is pretty no frills, but I've almost always been in and out of here pretty quickly (no excessively long waits, hurray!) The practice is very much a family business - the older Dr. Leggio practices here, as well as two of his children. I've been going here ever since I moved to New Orleans 5 years ago, and have always had a decent experience.

I can't believe I never wrote a review for this place! I recently moved away from NOLA but I used to live in the Lower Garden District - walking distance to Lilly's. Lilly's was a great place to call in an order after a crappy day when I wasn't up to cooking or for pho when I felt sick. Normally I find banh mi sandwiches really underwhelming, but Lilly's helped change that (though the tofu banh mi was sometimes on the slightly salty side). 

Also, the folks who work here are some of the nicest restaurant staff in New Orleans. I remember one time when I stopped in for take out after a long and exhausting flight back to NOLA, and the lady gave me my order and said "WELCOME HOME!!!" How nice is that! 

When we return to visit, Lilly's will be at the top of our list for Vietnamese.

I really like il Posto, but it had been a while since I'd been there. I picked up one of their Groupons recently to have an excuse to return. il Posto is a sweet little spot Uptown with sandwiches, soups and salads. They also have a handful of selections for wine by the glass, and a few simple desserts. I think we got the carrot cake cupcake, which was tasty.

I've belonged to Reily on and off over the years. I'm back as a member right now, and I still can't decide whether I'm really getting my money's worth.

Pros of Reily center:
*Convenient location (for me, at least)
*I like the indoor running track
*It makes me happy that the TVs on the 3rd floor are usually tuned to MSNBC and not Fox
*I haven't used the pool in ages, but I remember I used to really like it
*Probably the cheapest gym membership in the New Orleans area

Cons:
*Not enough self-serve lockers. You often have to go ask for a key because all the keypadded lockers are in use
*It's not a huge gym, so often at peak times it can be difficult to find equipment you want
*I really wish that all members had access to a once a year fitness consultation - I could use some advice on my workout strategy, and don't really want an ongoing trainer. I think it'd be a nice perk to offer to members once a year.

Surrey's is a great breakfast/lunch joint. I've been here several times, and while I wouldn't quite put it in the same category as Ruby Slipper or the Country Club (no booze), I kind of think of Surrey's as similar to Satsuma - some solid breakfast items with a lot of interesting juices to try out. Sort of like a diner, but without the 'greasy spoon' part.

Surrey's is one of the places that often pops up on lists in magazines such as "Best places to eat Breakfast in America," and I think this is thanks to their grits. I didn't have it this time around, but the first time I had their grits I nearly burst into joyful tears of adoration. I flagged down the waitress and asked her what the secret was. Turns out it's half and half and cream cheese. YUM.  

On my most recent trip, I got the biscuits and gravy. It frustrates me that biscuits and gravy options are few and far between in New Orleans. And while this is not the best biscuits and gravy I've ever had, it's pretty damn awesome. The gravy has a nice spicy kick (I got the meat-based gravy, though apparently I think they have a vegetarian mushroom gravy), and the biscuits were tender. I got a juice blend - mango, orange and pineapple. Delicious. 

Pro tips: They're cash only and the wait can take a while on weekends (it's a small place). I went on a weekday morning and had no problem finding a table.

I went to a conference recently at the Indiana State Library. It was a wonderful space, with a grand old reading room we used as a meeting place. I loved the stained glass windows and the ceiling paintings of printer marks. The bathrooms were a little far away from our meeting room, but clean. Good location if you have a small conference.

Tip's is a legendary institution (and if you need a quick lesson why, just look at all the old posters they have hanging up. My jaw fell open when I saw a poster showing Fela Kuti had once played here...!) in New Orleans. I've been to tons of different shows here - the weekly Cajun fais do do, funk and brass band shows, and even a Gillian Welch concert. 

The stage floor level can get pretty crowded (this is a standing room only kind of place), so the upstairs part can be nice (though sometimes it's hard to get a good spot near the railing). The bathrooms on the second floor are a little neater, and there's also another bar on the top floor that didn't seem super slammed during the last show I saw here. 

Tip's is one of those places that everyone should go to at least once in their lives. But the difference between Tip's and many other venues is once is not enough - true appreciation comes from repeated visits.

City Park is utterly massive. I've driven around tons of it, and I still always have the feeling I haven't seen half of it. In City Park you'll find all sorts of diversions, including walking and bike paths, a kids amusement park, the art museum and sculpture garden, tons and tons of beautiful live oaks, a pavilion, and more. My favorite new additions are the Morning Call beignet stand and the mini golf course. There are some very cool bench swings as well by the mini gold course. 

City Park is definitely a must-see... less cozy than Audubon Park, but also tons of room to do whatcha wanna.

It's a mall with a bunch of stores you probably want to go to if you're going to a mall in the first place. I did enjoy the DJ spinning tunes in the Macy's women's shoe department recently. There's always good people-watching at this mall. But the parking is a total cluster! Be prepared to spend a lot of time waiting in line in the garage.

I've been to Maison during a few different times -- general barhopping on Frenchmen, brass band shows on Mardi Gras weekend, and most recently during the 610 Stompers auditions. Maison has a few decent beers on tap -- usually for around $5, which is very reasonable by New Orleans standards. Last time I went they had PBR ($3) and a couple Abitas, Blue Moon and Sam Adams. They had some house infusions, which were intriguing but I didn't try. 

They have food, too. Don't confused by the specials board -- there are also laminated menus by the register. I got an order of chicken wings, which were just fine (but really, no celery?)

Only quibble is the bathroom is a little bit meeeehhhh (mysterious puddles of water on the floor, and bathroom door locks are unpredictable)

While it doesn't have as much charm as Spotted Cat or as coolness as dba, Maison is still  worth stopping by if you're traipsing around Frenchmen.

I'm sort of conflicted about giving Lee Circle 4 stars, since I'm a born, bred, and proud Damn Yankee who thinks such a giant statue of Robert E. Lee in the US is the sign of some serious Lost Cause-shenanigans. But I like Lee Circle for the following reasons: 
A) It's a freakin' roundabout, and every good old-school city in the world (Boston, Dublin, London) has at least one roundabout
B) That exciting moment when you take the streetcar and you're like WHOA IS THIS ACTUALLY GOING TO MAKE THIS TURN and it does
C) My boo has a long-time tradition of watching the Sunday Mardi Gras parades here with his friends. It's a really lovely event in which we catch up with people we haven't seen for ages, enjoy the crowds, and attempt to pace ourselves through drinking for several hours.

If I had my druthers, I probably rename Lee Circle to be "Spike and/or Bruce Lee Circle" but until then I'll have to deal with the Reb not turning his back on the North.

What a great local branch library! I had some time to kill in Mid-City the other day, so I stopped by this branch, which I hadn't been to since it moved over from nearby the Carrollton Rouses. 

Browsing the stacks, this branch has an excellent non-fiction selection, and a pretty decent fiction selection. Only one bathroom I could find. A small DVD area and magazine rack. Although this library isn't in an area I'd normally go to, I'd definitely visit again if I had time to burn around here.

I took last year off (I think? I don't remember going) from po-boy fest, so the last time I had been there before returning this year was the 2010 fest - this was when the lines really started getting crazy-insane. I'm not too claustrophobic, but even the 2010 lines made me a little queasy and panicky. 

Fast forward to 2012 - I'm not sure whether all these changes were new to this year or in 2011, but I really appreciated that they did away with having a main stage right at Carrollton and Oak. Really seemed to cut down on the bottleneck at the very beginning. Also, the mobile beer vendors were excellent! Anytime I needed a beer, I never had to go more than half a block. 

I LOVED that Bike Easy provided free valet bicycle parking. What a fantastic service. There were even some nice guys who helped me out with a quick pro bono tire tuneup, which was much appreciated. I'm not sure how widely advertised the valet service was, since I saw tons of bikes locked up on fences around the fest. 

There are still damn long lines and big crowds at Po-Boy Fest. If you truly get panicky around big lines or crowds, Po-Boy Fest is probably not for you. That said, I was in an epic long line (Jacques-Imos) that actually moved pretty fast. 

One suggestion: I wish there were a few more sweets vendors. It was hard to find a way to satisfy my sweet tooth after chowing down on po-boys.

I think this is one of my favorite festivals in New Orleans, but then I'm a glutton who loves excuses to eat anytime, anywhere.

Love Thoth! If you've felt a little sad because of how few beads you've received during Mardi Gras, well make your way to Thoth so you can acquire a bead-induced neck ache. We took some MG noobs to Thoth who were really excited about bringing beads back to their classrooms (out of town teachers). They left with four tote bags worth of beads. Beware of heavy objects - Thoth is a huge fan of throwing giant unopened bags of beads. 

Although I never catch it that early, I really like that Thoth rolls near the children's hospital and some other spots not on the regular route so people can enjoy the parade.

Whenever my boyfriend and I are lucky enough to see out of town friends who say "Let's do dinner! You make the suggestion!" we invariably take them to Maurepas Foods. This means Maurepas Foods has become one of the only NOLA restaurants we go to over and over again. Since we have a restaurant bucket list about 3 pages long, the fact that we keep going back there ought to tell you something.

You can never go wrong with the greens, grits, or goat tacos here. The last meal I had here was very (very) slightly less impressive than my many other meals, but I'll mark that down as simply an off-night. The dessert though was INCREDIBLE - an ice cream sandwich with mint chip ice cream. The ice cream had to be home made, because it  seriously tasted like they just whacked some mint from the garden and mixed it into the ice cream that day. Very, very good. 

Maurepas should be on everyone's to-eat list, whether you've lived here for years or are only in town for 48 hours.

Love the staff (so nice!) and love the location. Great outdoor seating when the weather is nice. 

That said, I need to agree with some of the other reviewers that the food here is hit or miss. I've had great sandwiches here before, but the most recent meal I had was pretty "meh"... it was a breakfast sandwich on an English muffin. Only the eggs and bacon were heated up - the cheese (sort of sad generic bright orange slices) and English muffin were pretty cold. The pumpkin pie was pretty good, though.

The St Charles streetcar is by far one of my favorite things about New Orleans. In the five years I've lived here, I've never lived more than a 5 minute walk from the streetcar. I hate driving through downtown and the French Quarter and would rather gnaw off my own toes than to try to park down there. As long as I'm not in a hurry, the streetcar is often my best bet.  

What everyone says about the inefficiency (you'll wait 20 minutes for a streetcar and then 4 will go by you), the confusion (sometimes one that's almost but not totally full will pass you by on the assumption that an emptier one is on the way), and slowness (I can bike faster than the streetcar) is very true.

But everything else - the nostalgia, the moving history, and the pure FUN of riding the streetcar is very true. I love what a part of the landscape the streetcar is. I often run down the neutral ground, and the streetcar creates this really peculiar metallic smell as it passes by. It's unforgettable and sort of gross, but I love it anyway. During times in my life when I've lived near railroad tracks, I've always enjoyed the whistle and rumble of the trains. Now I've listened to the distant grinding of the streetcar on the neutral ground rails for the last 5 years. Beautiful.

Milk Bar has awesome sandwiches but what's even more ridiculously tasty are there milkshakes. I'm now several hundred miles away from being able to swing by Milk Bar for a milkshake, but I can dream. Highly recommend the banana, caramel, or butterscotch milkshakes - with malt added.

I recently attended a wedding here. Really interesting venue in an old mansion. So much interesting random art on the walls -- a carved wooden crucifix! A slightly scandalous Art Nouveau lady! An oil portrait of a man with the largest pocket square ever!!!!! Food was darn good, ladies bathroom was tres elegant, and the staff seemed to have everything down really well. My only regret was that the rainy weather kept us from experiencing the beautiful grounds.

I love this place - it's a very glossy high-end candy, dessert, and gelato shop. My mom goes nuts in here whenever she visits from out of town. I don't go here very often - it's more of a special treat place. Got the lemon curd gelato and a salted caramel macaroon during the most recent visit - both delicious. Small boxes of Sucre chocolates make great gifts!

Excellent concept, but very incomplete execution. The beer lineup was better than expected. Sadly, several of the games either ate our money and/or were completely non-functioning. My dude and I shared a burger, and while it was decent, if you're going to charge $11 for a not-huge burger, have some generosity and throw in some damn french fries or something. 

Staffing here seems a little... off. Our first bartender wouldn't open any tabs for us since she said she was getting off her shift (totally understandable, and something I would have gladly offered to do anyway), but then she was still there tending bar an hour later. A guy who appeared to be the manager was there too, why didn't he just let her go home? Seemed kind of ...odd to me.

I think they have some growing pains right now, but I'd go back eventually because they have a DOLLY PARTON PINBALL MACHINE.

I love Molly's! One of my favorite bars in the Quarter, and really, just anywhere in the city. Molly's is not the place to go for some fancy-pants drinks nor do they have live music. But if you want to drink a couple beers and have some great people-watching, this is the place to go. Molly's is ground zero for some great events in the Quarter, especially the Halloween and St Patrick's parades. One time I even got to see Edwin Edwards as a grand marshal of a parade just outside Molly's.

A tasty treat Molly's serves up is the frozen Irish coffee. Exactly what it sounds like, and more delicious than you'd expect. My man and I recently stopped by Molly's before Hurricane Isaac blew in, and it was just the last hurrah we needed before losing our power for 5 days. They vowed to stay open the entire time, though we were too hunkered down to go back and see if that was true.

Edited to add: Hat tip to the dude below me who mentioned the ashes set up above  the bar. SERIOUSLY YOU GUYS I have been to Molly's so many times, and didn't notice it until last week, when the lady sitting next to me was like, "Uh, are those really someone's ashes up there?" According to the bartender, they're from an old regular whose body was never claimed from the morgue. Molly's owner offered to pay for his cremation provided he could keep the ashes at the bar.

And the rest, as they say, is history...

We brought our twin toddler girls here last week (7/26/15) and had a blast. Being a weekend it was very busy and the staff & parents, (mostly parents) could do a better job of controlling their kids and paying attention to age groups are in the appropriate areas. For example there are few 3 and under areas and there were kids obviously much older than three in some of those areas. It might not be an issue when the museum is not that busy but the weekend it get chaotic quickly. Still, it was fun for the girls and convenient to get to. There is a parking garage across the street.

Tiny house converted to a tiny restaurant. Seriously, they only have like 4 tables so if you can get your food to go. The young man at the register was friendly and took the time to explain the menu. I've had mexican from San Diego to Las Vegas to Yuma and Texas and this place in Tampa ranks up there with the best of the southwest. I had a tamale, two tacos, and a quesadilla. They were all delicious the al pastor was the star. Get here early or be prepared to stand in line!

This is a great place for piercing!! I had a TON of questions and I was kind of a wimp but Johnny was patient, helpful and fast. I got my nose pierced and despite my whining, it didn't hurt a bit. This place is clean, knowledgable and the perfect place to go.

I had a scheduled appointment no one came to greet me as I pulled up which was fine as I was. 15 minutes early.  I waited a total of 50 minutes still not one service representative met with me.  I had made this appointment a week and half prior.  A service tech came by and asked that I move my car to make room for others this is waiting 1 hour 37 minutes to get waited on .  I said sure and just left as he had no idea when someone would meet with me.  The last thing I get is a voicemail saying I missed my appointment if I wanted to reschedule.  No wonder this dealership has so low ratings.  I will call Honda customer service and voice my concerns next week.

Customer service is very rude.  We reserved a room on one credit card and paid with another.  Two charges on both.  Placed a call to management and no return phone calls.  Bad faith business practices.  Wish we would of stayed on Clearwater beach.
Update 30 days later the charge for the second amount removed.  Poor customer service had to have Bank of America handle.
This is my fifth time here.  I highly recommend as not only did I bring my car but the wife's car as well.
Great service and unlimited fries.  You can not beat this.  I will return. We arrived on a Saturday afternoon with no wait.

I would recommend Dr. Castellano  and his staff to anyone.   My wife Myla and I have been going to him for years.  We found him when we moved from ST Pete to Riverview.  We found his office near our home and they have weekend appointments.
This past week I went in for a crown and a filling.  I mentioned some other problem I had with a old filling he was able to take care it right then and there.  He is also a perfectionist in his craft.
This is definitely a great dentistry for any one who needs a great dentist.

Great local roaster boasting a cozy coffeehouse vibe reminiscent of Seattle in the 90s. There's no formal register and the one or two employees running the show seemingly hang out in the open area where you get your fresh cup of pour over style coffee.

Great spot to work away the afternoon.

I could basically copy/paste Jason F's review into the box I'm currently typing in. I too went to Bitar's in search of that perfect falafel sandwich. What did I find? Bland falafel balls overly drenched in hummus and tahini. Talk about a messy sandwich! I actually had to change my pants from all dripping that went down. 

I still look to Maoz as my favorite falafel sandwich. Perheps Bitar's can satisfy on the meat end of things? What say you Philadelphia?
Back again to Honey's where not a thing has changed and thank god. Huevos rancheros still better than any other version I've come across in the great U.S. and enough flannel to screw a lightbulb.

A particular morning found me a dejected, poor, unfortunate soul with no promise of fortune and no care in the world. So I wrangled up my favorite Bay Area heathens, Dusty Muffins and Winnie Bago. "We need a change," I urged. "We need to kick these small town blues and dive deep into the heart of something sinful, degenerate, and downright depraved."

With a nod and a sock, Dusty mounted his hog and tossed us eagle monogrammed leather jackets. "Lasso up your gumption, Sharon and Winnie, we're hightailing it to the biggest little city in the world." 

And so we descended upon the Peppermill. Italian busts, Julius Caesar, a bronze fountain in the swimming pool, poolside pina coladas, flatscreens in the bathroom, and more bikers than you could fit in a sombrero. We were slingin' 5 dollar chips with reckless abandon, chumming up to the dealers, and striking gold. Our money won was twice as sweet as money earned.
 
When you're in Reno, there's just no reason to leave the Peppermill. It's got more class than Venice. Just like taking an Italian voyage to the Bahamas. That or straight to hell.

Last night might have been my favorite dining experience to date. My 3 friends and I took over a downstairs booth and indulged in far too many dishes. Everything was absolutely perfect - from our server to our food to the cocktails. The dishes came out in excellent timing and with all of the items we tried, not one fell short of amazing.

What we ordered:
Cazuela de Chorizo y Papas - chorizo and potatoes with kale in casserole form. So hearty and delicious!

Tostadas de Tinga - shredded chicken served cold atop a crispy tortilla. These were heavenly.

Ensalada - something light and fresh to cleanse the palate. I loved the jicama!

Atun ceviche - buttery chunks of yellowfin tuna ceviche. Yum.

Platija - maybe the favorite. Fluke ceviche served over those same crispy tortillas. The mild fish was so simply prepared but oh so good.

Carnitas de Pollo - we were really full by this point, but I loved that they embraced the crema for these baby tacos. 

Carrillada de Cerdo - pork cheeks

All in all, you should absolutely go to Xochtil.

Being in the business of event planning, you deal with all types, but ultimately it's the efficient nice folks who get my company's hard earned dollars. I've worked with Mike and his team twice now and both experiences have been filled with quick, efficient, and personable service.

For an upcoming event, Mike came out to the site, measured all the rooms and is in the process of entering the info into a program that creates a basic blueprint of the venue. He's figuring out where all the tables are to be situated, he's helped me visualize where the vendors should go, and even offered to deliver and pick up the tables, chairs, linens, and other rental stuff during non-business hours. 

Being a one-woman operation, it's really wonderful to have someone like Mike on my side. He's taken a lot of stress off my shoulders and I gave him a muffin for that.

I ordered this expecting nothing more than wet socks served over dough. Meaning, just something to fill my stomach. Much to my surprise, what came delivered to my door is now amongst my favorite pizza in this city. What? Really? Yes! Favorite pizza in this city.

Were it not for the fact that they forgot to add chicken to the "Chicken Garden Salad" I'd have awarded them 5 stars. Nothing really notable about the salad except for the fact that it's not as fattening as the pizza. 

Order this tomato pie and you won't be sorry. Unless you're a sorry kind of person...in which case I can't help you and neither can pizza.

Last night, the cozy yet bustling ambiance of Xochitl really shone through for me. Maybe it was all the new people I met, or all the faces I hadn't seen in a while, or exchanging a game of footsie with my friend - whatever it was, Xochitl really came alive.

The experience began by sitting at the bar (often a wise decision) under the care of Eric. He's a pro and just before you've cleared your last sip, he's at the ready with a new drink in hand or a quick recommendation. Eric is fast and efficient without being unnecessarily chummy but don't let it fool you, you'll be exchanging high fives after your 3rd or 8th drink. He also happens to be one of the most respected bartenders in Philly. 

New chef Lucio Palazzo has maintained many of the old beloved dishes while adding some excellent new choices to create an accessibly smart menu. 

Some things you should check out:
-La Chilindrina (blanco tequila, blood orange, lime, canela, chile)
-Chespirito (poblano-infused blanco tequila, green chartreuse, St. Germain)
-Cazuela de chorizo y papas (caserole of chorizo, potatoes, and kale)
-Queso fundido

Regretfully, I did more drinking than I did eating, but the little I did have definitely piqued my interest for some more. Perfect spot for a date or a late night drink. Actually, it's just awesome all around.

You can tell by the austere, wooden interior. You can tell by the unpedestrian beer options. By the barista with a hidden smile (only to be shown for those "in" folks). And last but not least, you can tell by the references to indie music, bike culture and flagrant love of cool bluegrass. If you were to equate a bar's clientele to music, let's just say you won't find a Creed fan in this room. The Independent is where the cool kids fetch pints and later down them with a dose of sick tunes.

There's a food menu too should you be so inclined and wine's not lost on them either, there's a decent selection of adult grape juice for winey wanderers.

Large, clean Chinatown haunt with food that everyone can enjoy. From picky eaters to adventurous ones; vegetarians to carnivores, Vietnam satisfies every palate. Meateaters shouldn't miss the BBQ platter (which is more than enough to feed 3) and then wash that down with a steaming bowl of pho. 

You've also gotta love their flaming punchbowls filled with liquor to the brim. My vote goes to this Vietnam over the across the street neighbor...especially if you're on a date.

If you like babies, this is the best place to baby watch. It's a true melting pot with tikes of every ethnicity! If kids, adults, waiting, and bureaucracy  doesn't suit your interests though, you should probably go around 9:30am Tues-Thurs. I was in and out of there within 15 minutes.

Despite finding the most hideous 80s prom dress ever (this was a success, actually), I simply couldn't get down with the curtained dressing rooms. Sure, they're nicer drapes than what you'd find in grandma's attic, but (un)dressing in them caused me to hit the peaks of anxiety - and I'm not an anxious person.

Public nudity aside, the prices are reasonable, the selection's name-brandy, and the merchandise is well-organized. Now if only I wanted to try more things on.

Talk about a convenience store. This is more like a smoker's post-toke dream. 

If you're looking for smoking paraphernalia, this store comes stocked with pipes, hookahs, grinders, screens, papers, loose tobacco, flavored cigars, all sorts of snacks, and even "Irish" food. Not sure what really constitutes as Irish food since all I really found we items to satisfy the most serious munchy craving. 

You'll also be pleased to know they take credit cards with a reasonable $5 minimum. I'm pretty sure this store knows its niche.

When I was searching for some 3.5-4 star level hotels in downtown St. Pete, I was surprised to find the Courtyard as my best option. In most other cities, it isn't too hard to find an under-$200 locale but to be accessible to downtown, I sacrificed a moderate upscale experience with this middle-of-the-road option.

If you're driving, you'll find there's only 2 hour street parking outside. Meaning: valet will park your car for $12 overnight. I found the hotel lobby to feel a quite dated and certainly teetering quickly towards a no frills experience. Up the elevator to floor 7 revealed a slight improvement in the room. Flatscreen TV, partial view of the water beyond, a king size bed and a large bathroom. While I still couldn't shake the feeling of being in a creaky, old hotel, I slept with the TV on to dissuade phantom visitors. 

Should you rise early, the modest gym on the lobby level has what you need and the small indoor pool adjacent to it adds a little perk. Breakfast doesn't come free, but it comes relatively cheap. Grab a free apple on your way out and opt for the free shuttle to take you around downtown!

There's no man who could ever endure the pain associated with a Brazilian wax. If there were such a man, or woman for that matter, looking to experience the most painless and satisfying procedure, (s)he better look to Kim at bluemercury. 

She wielded that wax with the utmost precision and grace. Unlike, other hair removal spots that use duct tape to strip away the unwanted comrades (*ahem International Salon), Kim applied the gentleness of a lamb and stripped away with the force of a lion. 

She was so great that I even got a facial afterward. In our dimly lit room, she massaged the chunks of cheek on my face and even gave me a shoulder and neck rub. The only awkward part was when I put the robe on as a cape, to which she exclaimed, "it's not meant to be worn like Batman, Monica." I may never feel totally comfortable naked before a stranger's eyes, but Kim put me right at ease and got the job done quickly and painlessly!

The food was ok, the service was abominable, but thankfully, they're open late. My mom, brother and I arrived at 10pm on a Saturday night to a near empty restaurant and it took our server a solid 15 minutes to show face.

Once it was all said and done the food was just ok. Sushi was toothsome, but my brother's chicken teriyaki (I don't endorse this order either) was dry and bland. Soy Vay could've done a better job as a sauce.

Why Haru wins: smart, casual sushi joint in Old City with a full cocktail menu and a decent wine line.

Without wanting to drive well out of the city, Sammy's proved to be the nearby Chinatown option to cure our afternoon Korean craving. 

We were one of very few occupied tables, but that didn't bother us -- the ambiance however was lacking (but no surprise there). 

We started with the complimentary banchan and I found the kimchi fresh and fermented, just the way I like it :) The pot of barley tea warmed us up on the cold and rainy afternoon, but it didn't help that heating/insulation seemed to be non-existent. 

The food is what really impressed though, my dish in particular. I'm a fan of dolost bibimbap and galbi, but I'm always torn on what to order. Here, there was no need to choose; my galbi came served atop my piping hot bowl of bibimbap! It was magnificent. Similarly, my date's bean paste soup was a winner. 

Come for the galbi bibimbap!

After trying just about every vet there is in the city, I've -finally- found the one. Tucked away in the heart of South Philly is a state-of-the-art, environmentally conscious vet hospital. 

I called this morning looking for a quick appointment and to my surprise, they were able to see me just an hour later at 10am. The facilities are really impressive. The room was spotless and felt less like a sterile vet's office and more like a cozy little holding pad. 

Dr. Majeska saw Giles (my pup) within 15 minutes of us getting there and get this, she sat on the floor with him. She gave him a very complete exam and talked me through every step of the way. There was never a feeling of being rushed out so she could get to another patient and her placid, conversational demeanor instantly put us at ease. 

Just as much as Dr. Majeska cares for pets, she's clearly got a thing for the environment. This brand new facility boasts a green roof, environmentally sound architecture, reused plastic bags, and paperless billing, to name a few features. 

After diagnosing the pup and suggesting a system of attack (he's got a growth on his paw and his ears are chronically itchy), we proceeded on to the medication I should start giving him. I agreed with all her suggestions, which sounded totally logical, and upon paying for all the antibiotics, pills, ear cleaner, ear medicine, and doctor's exam, the total came out to $150. Seriously, that's nothing compared to what I had calculated in my head. 

The staff was beyond cordial and Giles and I couldn't have been more happy. So I think: amazing service, amazing facilities, thorough exam, AND affordability - I wish she could be my doctor.

Affordable fancy cocktails, gooey homemade bacon mac n cheese, and retro go-go dancers shimmying in their fishnets atop glowing boxes. Yes, The Trestle Inn is in a league of its own. 

Just over a year ago, I'd heard sordid stories of the elicit acts performed in the once bar that'd turn strip club. It was a roughneck sorta place that only my most adventurous friends would frequent, but today, the scene couldn't be more opposite. The once seedy rathskeller is now a sleek red-light speakeasy minus the sex for pay.

The only downside is the bathroom situation. Later in the night after the crowd's had a few, the line will likely build up in the middle of the room. Great spot after a show at Union Transfer or if you're on a bike bar crawl.

What's my favorite indoor/outdoor Sunday brunch Tampa retreat? Clearly, this place. I hung out around the Seminole Heights hood to find a smattering of spots that were obviously established to attract people like myself. Among them, Ella's. With its wonderfully stocked bar, live jazz, hand muddled caipirinhas (although you won't find them on the cocktail menu), sprawling tree laden deck space and comfort food options, I was instantly blissful.

We bellied up to the stools surrounding the massive tree and sucked down a handful of muddled beverages. First mojitos and then caipirinhas. Nearby, I couldn't help but be completely awe-struck by the Bloody Marys. Where a celery stalk should be, is that a pork rib? Yes, that's a rib in your Bloody Mary. 

Despite not liking Bloody Marys, I can't turn down ribs and so our half-buzzed group occupied a booth space. Everything was awesome and Ella's is definitely going to happen again.

All I wanted was 7 margaritas last night, but after a number of "closed" signs reared their ugly heads, my friends and I settled on Moriarty's. We all walked in grumbling a little under our breath (this isn't even CLOSE to being Mexican!) but my former roommate/friend (who's ever so hard to please) got excited about being able to watch the Phillies. So we stayed.

Lindsay (friend) waited and waited for the bartender to change channels so she could enjoy the game...but it wasn't until the 3rd inning that she switched it on. Lindsay got dangerously close to smashing pints, Mutton Chop ordered far too many genetically enhanced chicken wings, and I didn't really enjoy the cheese fries.  

As far as Irish bars are concerned, Moriarty's gets 2nd place in Center City (McGillin's gets 1st). But then again, I typically avoid places like this. And no, not the best wings. Hooters still takes the cake in that department :)

Like a poor orphan I entered Soy Café with a mere 8 dollars to my name. I examined the menu and carefully selected what I thought was my best option for a lunch meal. 

The Funky Monkey called my name. Bananas, peanut butter, oatmeal, soy milk, and honey blended in smoothie form? Yes. I might say it's been the best $3.75 I ever spent...and now my new favorite smoothie in all the Philadelphia land. At 5:55pm though, I'm hungry. A blended beverage is no meal replacement unless there's whiskey involved.

With all the traveling I've done and all the food I've enjoyed, I always miss Cantina. Nothing quite beats the mista salad paired with platanos machos, a platter of nachos with shredded chicken and a blood orange margarita. This remains my eternal order and, with a bullet, Cantina takes a spot in my top 5 favorite restaurants you wish were always near. 

Since I no longer live in Philly, opening up my own little version of their successful recipe might be the closest thing to comfort.

Ok, I'm not about to take credit for this, but a number of months ago, I suggested (in a review) that DJ Deejay retire Michael, Madonna, Prince and adopt himself some new divas. Last night at Sister's, he did just that.

It went a little something like this:

Clock strikes upon the hour and the sun begins to fade. Still enough time to figure out how to chase my blues away. I saw the sign and it opened up my eyes, so here I go, here I go, here I go again, girls what's my weakness? Black, white, Puerto Rican, Chinese boys.

Straight up now tell me whether we could have a bad romance. Steal the night, kill the lights, feel it under your skin. Time is right, keep it tight, cause it's pulling you in. Wrap it up, can't stop cause it feels like a overdose. Evacuate the dancefloor. I'm a slave for you, cause you're hot then you're cold, you're a cold-hearted snake. 

Whitney Houston, Paula Abdul, Ace of Base, Katy Perry, and more? DJ Deejay is just what Sister's needs and vis versa. Well done, chap!

When my dinner date-friend exclaimed, "take me to pleasuretown...and make it Mexican," I knew just where to go. I grabbed a bottle of tequila and down the street we hopped. 

I half-expected it to be crowded, thanks to the night's lovely weather, but thankfully there were tables abound! We were seated outside and within minutes, we placed our drink and appetizer order: Blood Orange Margarita, traditional guacamole, pork carnitas. With speed, the items dropped like kisses on my forehead. Except they dropped on the table, not on my face, and they were delicious. The guac maintained the perfect salt balance; the carnitas were served in a lovable DIY sloppy fashion; and the pitcher of blood orange margaritas took us to where we needed to go.

We split the short rib entree and found ourselves scarfing down every last bite...but it was just enough to leave us feeling full and bloated, but not the uncomfortable variety of bloated. 

Um, what else. Oh yeah, we got dessert. This was sadly very disappointing. The Tres Leches came out very stale and hard to gently scoop into the spoon and then chewing took a bit of effort too. 

Nevertheless, Lolita scored...and then I did too. 






j/k

Even if this were the most amazing breakfast sandwich, I could never give it above 2 stars. Why? For the egg white portion of my sandwich, dude pulled a solid, white pancake-like object from behind the counter (that was the egg white) and cut it into quarters. 

Then he nuked it in the bizarro half microwave-half monster. When it was all said and done, he forgot to add the Black Forest Ham to my sandwich. The only thing that was probably made out of anything real was the bread. I'll probably get these every morning though.

I love the art house cinema vibe: the selection of imported chocolate at concessions, the hot chocolate + tea beverage options, the film bill for current and upcoming features, and the carefully curated films. It's here where I've seen some of my favorites. 

The only thing missing is a liquor license, oversized leather chairs with movable arm rests, and eardrum blasting surround sound - then I'd really be able to get comfortable. 

This is a great place to go on a date by yourself.

If South Street is a sea of philistines, Hoof + Fin is the lucky piece of driftwood washed up on shore. Tucked away from the madness, H+F sits on 3rd between South and Bainbridge. A spot like this would seem better suited for Rittenhouse, but maybe that's why I liked it so much. It's something awesome in the least likely of areas. 

Surf and turf menu with simple but inspired dishes. Spotless aesthetic:  vintage prints of animals in gold frames of all different sizes, hung on a large wall to create a giant collage of cute. I was originally drawn to this place weeks ago when I admired their sign: a wooden slab and the haphazardly carved, "Hoof + Fin."

Armed with lots of cheap wine and a bunch of gays, dinner at H+F was already off to the right start. To begin, someone ordered the calamari. Each ring was lightly fried and glazed with a sweet and tangy orange sauce. Delicious and we fought until the very last one was had.

I went with the whole fish special - a perfectly prepared mild, white Mediterranean pesce. This being the first whole fish I've ever ordered at a restaurant, one of the servers was kind enough to debone it for me. My friend's skate wing was awesome, she mentioned never having had this kind of "bird" before. Oy. All the gays on a diet ordered the mahi mahi - really awesome - and my final friend went with the short rib pappardelle - my favorite pasta dish. Sadly, we didn't have room for any of the homemade dessert. 

The best part? Towards the end of dinner, a man and his guitar hopped on a stool and started serenading guests with lovely little flurries of background music. 

What a hidden gem you are, Hoof + Fin.

Years after being a regular at Zahav and then moving away, I came back to Philly to find this sacred Old City food temple to be just as fantastic as I remember it. Worried I'd be the victim to high expectations unmet, I cozied up to the bar and found the cocktails are just as amazing as I remember them, the hummus and laffa is the best my life has ever had and the service is similarly as pleasant and smart. 

I pretty much managed to sum up my experience in the first paragraph, but in case you're wondering what my favorites might have been, I started by ordering the restaurant's darling cocktail, the Lemonnana and followed that up with one (and then another) Desert Rose (gin, hibiscus, grapefruit, cucumber). Both cocktails are fantastic, but the second one really satisfied the well-balanced, fruit cocktail lover in me. 

As for the food, we didn't eat much, but the Hummus-masbacha (hummus with warm chickpeas) is a game changer. You'll compare every inferior hummus you've ever had with their superb rendition. Then there's the laffa that served alongside. This on its own crushes any bread that ever did happen. After Zahav laffa... well, there is no after. Whether it's to snag a seat at the small bar or go all out for dinner, and regardless of whether you're a vegan or carnivore, Zahav does certainly satisfy.

As I gingerly cut through my helping of not 2, but 4 balls, I thought, what better way to enjoy these little chicks than by spreading them on pita, smearing hummus all over them and tenderly biting inch by inch. I caught a little hummus drip on my lip, but waste it I couldn't - so creamy and delicious it was! The right balance and salty and spunky! 

Too soon?

Ok, seriously, the falafels came served over a base of hummus with drizzled tahini. I've been forever fond of Maoz falafels, but these puppies make the aforementioned look like the McDonald's of the Middle East.  What I hoped would be an entree felt more like an appetizer though. They forgot to bring me the promised pita bread with grilled vegetables and rice. Bastards. I'll just have to dine in next time with a hidden machete. You know.

Through the doors of El Rey and you're suddenly transported to LA or the desert. Starr really sets the mood here and you feel like you're stumbling into a roadside diner somewhere near the border of Mexico. 

Mexican prison artwork hangs on the wall across from the bar and the small, yet careful selection of tequilas (and only tequila) does the authenticity of a Mexican diner experience justice. 

My dinner date and I tried to sample as much as we could from the menu. The short rib enchiladas were good, but the gorditas stole the show. Make sure you don't miss out on these. The shrimp and whitefish ceviche was not good though. It came tossed in Mexican ketchup...ketchup with ceviche? No no no. The empanadas were a bit too salty and greasy, but I really enjoyed the fresh guac - delicious chunks of avocado assured the freshness here.

The food was good, the tamarind margaritas were great (a better bet over the traditional ones), and the ambiance was A+. The only thing amiss were the guys in suits seated in the back who looked like they were checking the books and going through the numbers. After watching them grill the servers, I'm guessing they were Starr's business partners? Isn't there an office for this kind of thing? Anyway, I wish they hadn't ruined the mirage of cool this place exudes. 

I'd definitely come back for more of those tamarind margs and the gorditas.

Ok, here goes. My favorite cheesesteak in Philly? Yeah. Sonny's.

Contrary to popular (tourist) belief, a typical Philadelphian's breakfast, lunch, and dinner is -not- comprised of a cheesesteak. If it were, however, I suppose Sonny's is where I'd go. Not Pat's, not Geno's, not Jim's, but Sonny's. 

While the aformentioned hot spots cater to visitors, Sonny's feels a bit more local and genuine. There's no colloquially forced ordering procedure ("wit," "witout," "whiz" - I'm pretty sure Pat's/Geno's/Jim's does that to suggest local flavor) and they offer more sophisticated toppings. After all, a cheesesteak is just like any other sandwich, one that's not limited to just onions and cheese. 

So if you're in the neighborhood, hopping off your Olde City carriage ride or walking out of the Constitution Center, Sonny's is a sure bet. You won't find a line trailing around the corner and you won't find a bunch of tourists reciting the proper way to order their cheesesteak in line. No pretension, no bull, just good meat and cheese sandwiches. 

Holla.

Great spot for lunch. $6 beef and veggie burgers, Anchor Steam on draft, and the veggie burgers are actually homemade and slapped together using actual vegetables. It almost looks like shoestring veggies pressed together into a patty. Top that off with cheese and it's awesome. 

Their house infused liquors are killer as well.

Coolest bar in Old City if you ask me.

We were in Reno on vacation and checked with Yelp for a pizza place. We chose this place based on the great reviews. Yelpers do not disappoint! Small place that makes awesome pizza! We sat out on the patio and had a great time. They don't have a huge beer selection, but they did have about 5 different beers on tap. A good variety though. My wife wanted to try the salad, but was not hungry enough for pizza and salad. She ate more pizza than she normally does, since it was so good! If you are in Reno and looking for great pizza-look no further! Go try it for yourself-you won't be disappointed!

What a fantastic stay!

Imagine our surprise to find that this is the same place we attended another conference more than a decade ago - when it was the Adams Mark!

I was easily amused by the funky key-thing that is just waved in front of the door. Our room was comfortable and cleaned adequately while we attended our conference during the day. 

There is an uneven spot on the floor in the lobby - watch out for it. My friend stumbled and lost an earring :( And one night at the hotel bar, security got totally in our friend's face and accused him of being loud (which was completely untrue, as witnessed by us and the bartender, thank-you-very-much). Apologies were made at length by the bartender, as well as promises of later follow-up so that never happens to anyone else!

Watch out for the elevators - you need to remember which side to ride to get to the right floor ;)  And park at the Mansion House Garage instead of paying the ridiculous valet fee at the hotel.

Luckily lightning didn't strike ;) The inside of the church/steakhouse is beautiful! We had a table near the front of the sanctuary, and had previously waited at the bar for the rest of our party for a bit. 

At the bar, my friend had a honey/whiskey something that nearly knocked her on her butt pretty early. I think that drink lasted her all the way through dinner. I had an orange martini of some sort, I think. It was delicious.

I had planned what I was going to eat earlier in the week, and nothing strayed me from my original plan. I had a crab-cake appetizer, then the filet medallions, followed by creme brulee. It was all completely delicious. 

If I ever bring my husband to New Hope, I'll certainly have dinner at Marsha Brown on my agenda.

I'm from Los Angeles where Mexican food is as common as coffee shops, but these tacos beat any LA Mexican I've had. They're served on small corn tortillas with cilantro and lime (same as in LA), but also with a side of a creamy sauce. Make no mistake, this sauce is HOT. The horchata is a little sweet for my liking, but is obviously homemade and has excellent flavor. I'd eat here every Taco Tuesday.

Used to be my favorite place to grab a snack at the airport, since it's pretty far down and therefore less busy than the other places, but I received awful service. My cashier, Hanaa, was okay, but the woman working with her was horrible. I feel guilty that I ordered a sandwich that she had to microwave. How dare I! She's openly exhausted by her job, and clearly would rather work anywhere else. I did only wait about 30 seconds for my sandwich while everyone else was waiting several minutes, so my apologies that you had my food ready before everyone else's and that confused me. Truly, I apologize that I was a patron of your business, and was so intrusive by ordering and paying for breakfast.

ML Rose has been one of my favorite neighborhood bars for years. The beer selection is always right to my taste, and the servers are friendly. I went for one of the first times in months (since dining out has been lessened with COVID), and learned they shifted from the corn slaw to a superfood slaw. It was not at all what I expected. When I think "superfood," I think anti-oxidant rich fruits and vegetables with a light dressing (most places do a lemon vinaigrette), but this was so extremely overdressed with sriracha mayo. I asked my server to check and see if they maybe did triple dressing on accident, but the kitchen confirmed they made it to recipe. It was inedible, and I hate that for ML Rose. The ultra understanding "No problem, I'll get you a side of fries" response leads me to think they're pretty used to people sending it back. Bring back the corn slaw!

We went to three different places to try beignets while in NOLA.  We were on a mission to find the best place. 

I was a bit skeptical when my friend told me that her friend had recommended Morning Call to us and said that it was better than Cafe Du Monde.  So as we set out on our beignet journey, we tried Cafe Du Monde first.  

We actually went back twice just to see if there was a difference and each time we were disappointed.  We were even more disappointed after trying Cafe Beignet.  

On our last day in NOLA, we decided to try this place out not having high hopes at all but we were proven wrong.  They had the BEST beignets ever.  The inside of this place had a very old feel to it.  I think it was purposely decorated like you stepped back into the 1920's.  It was packed but not crowded where there was a line out the door.  We were seated quickly and ordered our coffees and beignets.  We could see the guy making the beignets behind the counter and he only made them when they were ordered so we got piping hot fresh beignets that were chewy and crispy all in one.  We ended up ordering three plates to split between four people because we loved them so much and had to have it before we left.  I had only wished we went here first as we would've come every single day during our stay.  I miss you Morning Call and wish you were in LA!

Greatness! 

This was the best meal that I devoured during my NOLA visit! 

We came across this place totally by accident. It was a rainy Sunday, and we were taking a walk down Frenchmen Street. It was lunch time, we were hungry, and The Praline Connection happened to be right in front of us! We hadn't heard of it before, but we took a chance and entered. Not only did it turn out to be a shelter from the rain, but a haven for gorging and overeating. 

The wait staff was excellent, very helpful and friendly. The establishment is separated into two parts, the candy store where they sell pralines, and the restaurant. The walls were decorated with antiques and paintings, it had a good vibe. There weren't too many people inside at the time, so I was kind of wary...but that all changed once the food came out. 

I had the seafood platter...shrimp (great), oysters (great), catfish (great), deviled crab (great), half of my friends bread pudding (OMG sooooo awesome!). The seafood was seasoned perfectly and the bread pudding had a praline sauce on it that consisted of pralines and bourbon I think. She had The Taste of Soul platter that consisted of ribs, chicken, catfish, etc... When I think of the amount of food that we both ate that day, I almost get sick. The words gluttony and greed come to mind. So, my lesson for you, the reader, in this review, is please try to not overeat during your visit here. It not hard to do!

After a night on Frenchmen St., hanging out at the Spotted Cat, we decided to call it a night and head back to the hotel. As we ventured out onto the street, we heard music. Granted, on Frenchmen St. at that time of night, it's not abnormal to hear the sound of jazz music coming from every direction...but this was different. As we approached Maison, the sounds of The Jackson 5 poured out of trombones and saxophones, and onto the busy street. The open doors and people dancing inside the large windows beckoned us to enter. When we went inside, we had one of the best experiences during our trip to NOLA. 

That night happened to be a "open mic" night. A night where locals brought their own instruments, jumped up on the stage, and joined the group, ad libbing and free styling r&b, jazz, and any other genre that was requested. You could tell that these were regulars, some of the musicians on stage would call others in the crowd, asking "Where's your trombone?", and telling people that they need to "Hurry up and get up on the stage!" The jam session quickly turned into a trombone vs. trumpet battle. Both sides taking turns trying to top each other....blaring notes, clapping hands, and shouting filled my eardrums as the audience watched. 

This is a part of NOLA that I always heard about, and was so happy that I got to see. I heard that the food was good as well. I didn't try it, but next time I definitely will. Great spot!

I stumbled in today, sort of by accident.  What a pleasant surprise!  It's the Subway / Chipotle model, but for pizza and salad, and it's FAST; only FOUR minutes!   They have a more-than-ample selection of toppings and quite efficient!  The prices are great, too: under $7 for a 10-inch personal pizza with THREE toppings!  I'll definitely be back!

When the boyfriend told me that we'd be making the trip to Philadelphia this winter, I just knew I needed to fulfill my girlish dream of seeing the first Anthropologie store. I had seen photos of the building online before and was curious to see this fancy shop's flagship location. Located in an old granite mansion in Rittenhouse Square, this location is seemingly large but seemed to have less than the locations I have visited in California. However, 4 floors of adorable (and expensive) clothes, books, and sundries is fun to wander around in and the architecture alone was worth the visit. There was a beautiful stained glass dome ceiling inside (see my photo) and the sale section located on the basement level featured everything under the sun. I grabbed a couple things (at 75% off!) then bid adieu to possibly the only girlie store I really love.

Holy Macakarel! John Yi's Fish Market  is my favorite fish monger in all of Reading Terminal Market. Great prices on incredibly fresh seafood and a selection that makes me weep-- and I live in California!
