As we got ready to leave, we realized that we were the last one in the restaurant and the last one in the entire pier...

Does Angry Chair have the most comfortable tap room in town where you want to sit for hours sampling the entire tap list? Nope. Are you guaranteed to find a wide variety of styles that will satisfy everyone in your party? Nope. Is parking plentiful and easy? Nope. Can you growler the more coveted varietals? Usually not.

So in spite of all this, what is the appeal? Simply put Angry Chair makes some of the best beers in the country. Whether you're looking for a mouth puckering sour or a dense pastry stout, Angry Chair can and does knock it out of the park. Producing some of the most flavorful and unique barrel-aged beers I've ever tried, Angry Chair sets the beer game bar high. Burkitshi, an Imperial Sweet stout with cacao, toasted coconut, and Japanese sea salt remains one of my penultimate favorites, rich and laden with flavor it reminds me of an Almond Joy. Another winner, Barrel Aged Popinski with Peanut Butter & Marshmallow tastes like a fluffernutter. A bottle we got lucky enough to enough to happen upon by pure happenstance, Bourbon Barrel Dave's Barleywine, had an excellent malt backbone and tasted like toffee.

The taproom itself is trendy and industrial, with cool metal bone seats that are more decorative than comfortable. Funky art scattered about, and of course the many references to "angry" chairs make for a laid back atmosphere. While by no means a spots bar, they do have a couple of televisions as well should you want to watch the game with a cold brew. Be warned though, the space itself isn't particularly large, so it may not be the best spot for a big group (although occasionally you can snag one of the coveted few more sizable tables).

While unfortunately I don't live close enough to synchronize my visits for every release, Angry Chair is my "must do" brewery every time I'm in Tampa, just in the hopes that I will strike the jackpot and pop in when they've just released something sinfully delicious. If it isn't already on your brewery bucket list make sure to put it near the top, Angry Chair produces the kind of stuff that both well seasoned beer geeks and novice drinkers will dream about.

A girl walks into a bar right as a band prepares to play, and goes to take a look at the drink menu. Vintage and seasonal cocktail options? Check. Interesting ingredients (like eucalyptus or Thai spice bitters)? Check. Then the music starts, upbeat and jazzy, and it feels fitting for the French Quarter. So she decides she should order a drink...

Quite some time later and I must admit, I was sold on 21st Amendment at La Louisiane. The drinks are solid, the atmosphere is lively without being raucous, and the music is exquisite. While it is a more intimate venue, seating routinely becomes available as the crowd ebbs and flows, making it a comfortable spot to hang out for a spell. 

Come with friends, come for a date, or come alone just to hang out at the bar, indulge in a cocktail, and enjoy the performance. 21st Amendment at La Louisiane offers a seductive scene with the winning ingredients to make a delightful night out in The Big Easy.

A small city unto itself, Gaylord Opryland is a sight to behold on par with some of the larger resorts in Las Vegas. A conference center and hotel, Gaylord Opryland offers ample walking paths, multiple restaurants, a river boat ride, a salon and spa, and now a water park as well. It is quite the labyrinth and is easy to get lost despite the signposts peppered throughout, although this often makes for the best exploration. While the hotel isn't located in the heart of downtown Nashville, it isn't a terribly far drive either.

Taking a stroll through the atriums is like being in a tropical oasis. There are multiple waterfalls, streams, and lush foliage. While I have no idea what any of it has to do with Nashville itself or its history, it is quite lovely. The strategically placed oversized guitars feel a bit out of place, and yet seem more authentic to the local flavor. Compared to Gaylord Palms in Orlando which actually has decor centered around Florida (Evergaldes, Key West, and Saint Augustine), I felt less of the connection to the city here. However, I can't deny that the hotel is still quite picturesque. Visit around Christmas, and the entire hotel is bedecked in holly and strings of twinkling lights as well.

Like any major hotel, Gaylord Opryland  comes with its pros and cons. The parking is high on my annoyance list, because although it is ample, it is pretty steep extra on top of the cost of your actual room. Whether you are a short term visitor, or a hotel guest, expect to pay around $32 a day. Also the restaurants are plentiful (think Italian, Mexican, sushi, and a grill), but none are particularly great. They do have Starbucks on premises if you are short on time, but walk or drive across the street to Nashville Coffees for a better selection and more interesting options.

If you are staying on business or at the hotel for a conference, the conference center is massive and quite convenient. There is more than enough space for an exhibition hall and smaller rooms for more intimate talks. WiFi is available throughout the area if you need to sneak away to get work done on your laptop. Speaking of the WiFi, you can also connect throughout the grounds or in the hotel rooms, and they have a direct wired connection if you need something faster, which makes a better choice if you need to connect to a VPN or are on a call.

The rooms themselves are comfortable, although certainly some sections are better than others. For example, a room in Magnolia may have you in a fairly basic look (your standard outdated hotel) and a view of a courtyard/pool, whereas in Delta the rooms seem to be a bit more modern, and if you're lucky you can get a view of one of the domed areas, which makes for great people watching.

Worth visiting at least once, even if you aren't a hotel guest! At the very least make a stunning venue to get some steps in...

Honey + water + yeast= mead

What seems simple enough, a historic combination standing the test of the centuries is still a popular beverage in modern times. However, Garagiste is not your average mazer, and the meads they produce are anything but ordinary. Well balanced Reboog Vitis is an elegant take on a peanut butter and jelly sandwich. Other varietals include adjuncts ranging from vanilla beans to maple syrup to raspberries. If that weren't enough to entice, then they add barrel aged versions that add additional complexity from Madeira to Cognac.

Many of the meads take on almost a wine like quality, balancing honey laced sweetness with a biting acidity. For those unfamiliar with meads, or those just wanting to try more of their masterful libations, I highly suggest grabbing a flight. The menu is ever changing, and often includes limited offerings that may not be available otherwise. Each mead is quite distinctive and may range from fairly dry to on par with a Sauternes. They do offer some snacks as well, which can provide balance to an otherwise saccharine tasting.

Truly one of the best meaderies to be found, Garagiste is undoubtedly worth a visit when in Tampa. Even those that think they may not enjoy sweeter drinks may find themselves a convert.

Okay, I'll admit it. I may enjoy an art project here or there but I have zero woodworking (or power tool) experience. Zero. Zilch. Nonexistent. I am also pretty klutzy in general, so the idea of making anything using sharp objects vaguely terrifies me. That being said, the Florida School of Woodwork in Tampa is outstanding. A valuable resource for fledgling newbies (like myself) and for those who are more advanced.

I signed up for the cutting board course with my mother. Apart from both leaving with all our fingers and toes present and accounted for, we learned a lot and had fun too. Our instructor walked us through the entire process, and allowed us to flex our creative muscles (within the scope of the intended project). We glued, sanded, cut, and other far more technical terms I cannot pretend to recall. Even better, we left with two beautiful and functional cutting boards (complete with my own pyrography pen design) and a lot of great memories.

Book in advance for an afternoon, or even a weekend workshop, their classes are outstanding. Very well organized, and safe too. It is also a delight to work alongside instructors who are not only knowledgeable but truly passionate about their craft.

As St. Pete continues to develop and thrive, it is really nice to see the influx of some great bars and restaurants.  The Mill is one of my brunch go to places when in the area, offering some of the more innovative items I've encountered. 

First, you should know that they do not take reservations, so if you would like a table, I'd highly recommend arriving early.  The only tiny niggle in an otherwise perfect plan, is that you cannot order a cocktail in the city before a certain time, so although you may be guaranteed a seat, their delightful libations may be out of your reach.  I actually first tried some from this restaurant at a cocktail competition in Miami, and they definitely know their stuff. So for the drinks at least, you may want to make a return visit. 

As for the food, I typically struggle with what to order as the changing menu is filled with tantalizing dishes. Typically I end up sharing with the table so as to increase the number of options I can sample.  If they have it let me just say that the Vegetarian Crack cakes are sure to hook you whether or not you actually are a vegetarian.  A combination of zucchini and squash pancakes, topped with preserved lemon crema, guava onion butter and a sweet pea salad, they make me believe that I could give up meat and still be blissfully unaware of what I'm missing. Thankfully this item seems to be a menu constant.  Although the sweet options change too often to recommend a particular choice, I'd like to note that options like the banana bread french toast with rum raisin compote and coconut dulce are worth ruining your diet for. Although not every selection is total nirvana, you're more likely to find hits than misses, so be sure to give them additional chances if your first experience seems to be a bit lackluster.

Whether you are a local seeking for your regular breakfast place, or a visitor looking for a high caliber new choice, The Mill is undoubtedly the restaurant you want.

Wine bar meets restaurant, it sounds like a perfect match.  

After doing some research, I discovered that this is a Illinois based chain, where they produce their own wines, and then serve them in the restaurant as well.  If you want a table, I would recommend making reservations in advance, or just resigning to sitting at the bar.

 The wine tasting room is right at the entrance, and is definitely a lovely piece of tasting room eye candy. Style-wise it competes with any number of higher-end wineries.  Wine tastings are fairly inexpensive, and ranges from $7-$12.  They do seem to offer quite a broad range of wines, with an especially large number of sweet wines.  Personally, I decided to spring for the "Lux" flight and found almost none of them to my liking, but everyone has different preferences.  I don't think there is anything wrong with cheaper wine, and in fact, I believe there are many great wines that are relatively inexpensive.  That being said, there just wasn't much complexity, and there seemed to be unpleasant lingering aftertastes with many that I tried.  I also didn't appreciate that my entire tasting was a sales pitch for my server, during which time I was forced to endure endless droning about the perks. 

When I finally got around to dining, the menu seemed on par with your average chain.  They have a variety of options, and large portions.   The food is quite competent, and will definitely satisfy hunger.  Cooper's Hawk isn't organic, gastronomic, or tapas-style, so don't expect it to be.  Also, yes, they only serve their own wines, but this makes sense to me considering that is the whole point of the venture.  Additionally there are some cocktails if you really are not feeling wine.    

The pretzel bread that is served before the meal is a bit more interesting than the standard crusty Italian bread loaf.  It is a large soft, pillowy bun of pretzel dough, which can then be slathered with the slightly sweet butter.  Also, I did receive excellent service throughout my meal. 

Cooper's Hawk is not the place to come for wine experts, nor for a truly gourmet dining experience.  That being said, it is a fun girls night, or a unique venue to go with friends or on a date.

Oh Cigar City. You lured me in with your beers and special releases at Hunahpu Day, tempted me with rotating taps in your cider and meadery, and now, a brewpub? You're on fire.

Reservations can be made online, although there is seating at the bar if you can snag a spot as well. While the brewpub does offer some of Cigar City's brewery beers, they also have a selection of their own unique beers as well. Not only can you drink a cold brew there, but you can also fill a growler to take home later. In addition to the standard Cigar City fan memorabilia, you may also be able to snag a bottle of something special (read "rare") from the fridge on your way out.

Not really in the mood for beer? No problem, they have wine and cocktails as well. You can even combine the two with their beer cocktails. 

Feeling hungry? The food menu is quite varied, with some Latin-flair and plantains thrown in for good measure. Burgers are offered a couple of ways, or you can chart your own destiny and choose the toppings. The Cuban (Ham, mojo pork, Fiorucci salami, Swiss, mustard) is a great version of the classic sandwich, and the upgrade to yucca fries with aioli is well worth it. The Chicken Saltimbocca delivers grilled chicken breast wrapped in prosciutto, fresh sage and smoked gouda, served over a wild mushroom risotto with a choice of vegetable. I thoroughly appreciated the addition of the sage, and the creaminess of the risotto. They also made a very tender Ropa Vieja (a slow stewed flank steak with peppers, onions, and tomatoes served over black beans and rice, with sweet plantains). For dessert, Hunahpu's Imperial Flourless Chocolate Cake is quite dense, but the acidity of the berries cuts through some of the richness nicely. I wouldn't say all the dishes are the best I've ever had, but they are solidly enjoyable and better than your typically bar fare.

The venue is very laid back, with a cool use of Cigar City beer cans and barrels turned into lighting fixtures. Definitely a cool place to grab a bite with friends while watching a game, and I'm sure we will be back to see what other bottles they've got stashed in that fridge for sale.

Johnson's is a nice spot to take the kids for any seasonal activity, but jeez, it's a racket, price-wise.  We took my son to do the Easter Egg hunt last week, and for a twenty minute hayride, as well as a three minute search for eggs, it was $16, for two adults and a child.  That didn't get you access to the animal farm area, or to the jungle gym, each of which has signs up that if you don't have a wristband, you'll be asked to leave.

The egg hunt itself was in a grove of trees, and they basically just took a couple hundred eggs of different colors, dumped them in the trees, by color, and told the kids to grab one of each color, then get their prize back.  Nice, but $16 nice?

The animal farm area looked nice from behind the fence, as did the jungle gym, but I'm not sure that they were worth paying the extra cash to get in, especially when there's a park with a huge jungle gym just a couple miles away.

It seems like there are a lot of very varied experiences and reviews of this place, but I thought it was solid, and as my first Nashville culinary experience, set a high bar.  We ordered the nachos, and I had their burger, which was advertised as being voted the best burger in Nashville.  It did not disappoint.  It was cooked rare, the way I asked, was well seasoned, and was just a damn good burger.  The nachos were pretty solid, albeit small.  I wish we'd have been there for some live music, but it was noon on a Friday, so it wasn't really prime time for bands with day jobs.

Prices weren't bad for drinks, service was prompt, and they have a nice beer selection.  I'll come back!

So apparently, Meghan C and I are now social pariahs, since we have a baby.

We went to Ponzio's last weekend, because Meg's sister is OBSESSED with diners, and they don't have them in North Carolina.  We get there, and they stick us in what's obviously the 'families with loud children' area.  Since Paxton is only a month+ old, he's still in a carseat, and doesn't make much noise, but because of this, we needed a place to put him.  The tables are too small to fit four people, plus a carseat, and we couldn't slide him onto the bench seat.  The one table that had an extended bench was open, but wasn't cleaned, so they said we couldn't sit there.  Fine.  We perched him on a chair at the end of the booth.

Five minutes later, the host comes over and says that we need to move, as we're a 'fire hazard' then he proceeds to put us at a four-top table, with no additional room to put the baby.  Where did the baby end up?  In the aisle, in the same 'fire hazard' manner as before.  Whatever.  Let's freaking eat, I'm starving.

I ask the waiter for the lunch menu, as it was almost 11, and I don't like breakfast foods.  He says that most of the food won't be ready, as they hadn't prepped the vegetables.  Really?  It's nearly 11 AM!  You're a diner!  Anyway, he says he'll bring the lunch menu, then never returns.  When he does, the wife and I want Bloody Marys.  We order, they come out, and I ask for the lunch menu again.  He says he'll get it.  We wait longer.  He comes back and takes the order from Meg's sister and her fiancee, then asks me what I want.  I tell him that I want the lunch menu.  Now, he's got to go find one, which took another give minutes.  It's almost 11:30, at this point.  It finally comes, and I have three seconds to look over the menu before he bails on us again.  I order a chicken club sandwich.  It was terrible.  At least my bloody mary was good.

What I'm more annoyed about, and marking them down big time for, was the fact that they couldn't accommodate four adults with an infant, and we were hassled because we were a fire hazard.  All they had to do was clean off the booth with the extended bench, but no...that was too tough for them.

We hopped into this place based on their billboard that advertised the best Bloody Mary in Nashville.  Obviously, I had to test them on their bold assertion.

They did have a damn good Bloody, which came with celery, olives, tomatoes, and a nice crispy slice of bacon.  Yeah, I was down.

We only had one drink here, and it was early on a Friday afternoon, so it was empty, but this seems like it would be a really fun place on a late night.  The bartender was quick with the drinks, and the prices were decent - for two Bloodies and two beers, the tab was like $20!  I expected to spend more than that, just on the Bloodies!

Oh, the jukebox gets loud, but the tender adjusted it as songs came on.  Don't expect to have a nice, quiet conversation here.

Had waxing done by Raine during a visit to New Orleans. She was professional, made me feel completely at ease, and did a great job. She also seemed very straightforward and down to earth, in a friendly way... like, if you didn't feel like making mindless small talk, you wouldn't need to, cause she's just doing her job, but if you wanna chat, she's also happy to do that. Basically, the type of esthetician you want!

I really liked the vibe of the place, too - super welcoming, NOT a bunch of over-manicured people staring down their noses at me as I rushed in with minimal makeup and with my hair still slightly wet. It also seemed like an efficient place, where you can get in and out and on with your life if you're just looking for a quick service (although I'm sure they could do pampering if that's what you're looking for, too. I was just there for the waxing).

Loved the live band on Saturday night! The trumpeter in particular was phenomenal at both trumpet and singing. As others have noted, this is around the corner from Bourbon Street and much classier than anything you'll find there.

Had fun dancing here late at night on a Wednesday. It wasn't very crowded, but my friend and I had fun since there were maybe 2 dozen other people there having fun. It's a dance bar in New Orleans and is exactly what you would expect in that category.

Very very impressed by my stay at Best Western. Although this was the most I have ever paid to stay at a Best Western, this is also the nicest Best Western that I have been too. The rooms had a very big layout, there was complimentary bottled water and fruit. I was on the bottom floor so my door faced the parking lot, and the sliding glass door faced the pool. The pool area was well maintained, the grass was healthy, and lots of beautiful plants. The only unusual thing about the hotel was the windows in the bathroom. The windows were high so people could not see in, but they were slated glass so you could hear everything outside. Although this is on the opposite side of downtown, I would stay here again if the price was right.

Amazing warm chocolate nut cookie when you check in, and they gave me another when we left. Super comfy bed, I wanted to go out and buy one for my house. I loved the Crabtree Evelyn bath products. Great location downtown, there was a subway stop directly outside the hotel. The only other strange thing was that our room was located by the ice machine, I have never heard such a loud machine. It sounded like a glass table was crashing outside our room every half hour. Overall great location/hotel/room but no free wifi, so minus 1 star!

Great location, very clean and updated. Free breakfast consisting of fruit and pastries from a local bakery to bring back to your room. There is no pool or outdoor community space. I found it very difficult to sleep on our king bed. We were given one pillow each, but they were extremely lumpy. For the size of the bed, it seems like we could have been provided with more than one pillow each. In addition, although I love shutters, there are some security/parking lights immediately outside of the room, so it never got completely dark, and light creeped in all night. I would recommend bringing an eye mask, so that you are not up all night. Also, when we got to our room we had a used toilet paper roll, which is fine, but we did not receive a back up new roll which it usually the standard when you have a used roll, and was annoying the next morning when there were only a few squares left.

This review is for the short female bar manager and her HORRIBLE customer service on 7/30/11.  My boyfriend, another couple (SB locals), and myself decided to go to the bar while we were waiting for our table upstairs.  The bartenders were very friendly and handed us a menu and were in the process of taking our order when the bar manager stormed in and announced that they were closed (9:10pm).  The bartenders looked surprised and took our menus back and we went back upstairs to check on our wait time.  We walked back downstairs (literally 2 mins had passed) and there were 4 new people in the bar being served.  I went in and asked if they were open or not, and the bartenders looked like deers in the headlights and the bar manager replied that they were closed.  When I asked why there were 4 new people in there that were being served since we were just there, she quickly changed her story and said that we could have drinks but that the bar food was closed.  What a B*TCH?!  She turned us off of the place for being treated so rude and we decided not to eat there, plus our friends who are locals said they will never return and plan to share their horrible experience with their friends as they said that they have been treated poorly here before!
I appreciate that the owner contacted me regarding my previous bad experience, it demonstrated to me that he was concerned about his business was being run (see below).

Great experience, a fantastic way to have a more intimate experience whale and dolphin watching! We had actually planned to go on a competitor, but they were sold out and thus we were directed to reach out Sunset Kidd, which ended up being a blessing in disguise. There were only 11 guests on the boat, plus a well behaved dog. We had a morning excursion, which was a lot of fun. They provide blankets, as it often is colder out on the water, as well as they sell a variety of beers, which you can either pay in cash at the end or go back to their office and close up via credit card. As I'm from the bay area, I wasn't as excited about the sea lions, which delighted everyone else, but we did have the unique and special experience of seeing many dolphins first off in a distance and then swimming right next to the boat, it was amazing. We were also fortunate enough to see some whales tails and the blow holes. The 2.5 excursion time was the prefect amount of time to be out on the water, be interested and not be bored. The whole experience was very relaxing, and with the size of our group, it was nice because everyone had the ability to see everything, no blocking of view, or stressing out about where to sit. Great experience, and I highly recommend.

I couldn't have been more excited to stumble upon this darling wonderland on our humid explorative trek around Nashville.

I felt like we were experiencing a sliver of San Francisco at Kellie's healthy delectable oasis. I especially appreciated all of the gluten free options on her menu. I don't have a gluten allergy, but i always find myself having an easier time digesting things, when things happen to be gluten free.

Our first meal here we had the  Mediterranean Vegetarian Sandwich (sans feta cheese) on fresh Gluten free bread - consisting of eggplant, roasted red pepper, sun dried tomato, and freshly made pesto, and the Spinach Salad (sans feta cheese) consisting of spinach, dried cranberries, sliced almonds & balsamic vinaigrette. Kellie even went out of her way to replace the feta cheese with some additional vegetables like tomatoes and cucumbers. Both were excellent, reasonably priced at $6.00-$7.00 and you could taste the love embedded in each. We washed down both with A Matter of Taste's cold refreshing fruit tea.

We were so impressed with our experience at A Matter of Taste that we decided to venture out here again the following day. We decided to try their regularly rotating lunch specials. We went with the Pumpkin Brittle and Watermelon adorned salad, as well as their Fish Tacos. The salad was outstanding. A Matter of Taste makes their own salad dressing and you could tell. The fish tacos were also very flavorful. 

A Matter of Taste's eating area is intimate, but if you take a look in the back you can see their sprawling immaculate kitchen where all of the magic happens.

If you're looking for quality and healthy food for reasonable prices - A Matter of Taste is outstanding. I recommend them wholeheartedly. My only regret is not sampling one of their gluten free desserts - ranging from moist looking cupcakes to large rockin' cookies.

Trust.

Bliss.

Absolute bliss.

Thanks to Katie B's gushing recommendation - we joined her, Farrah A, and Tomas R at Bacchanal for the most delightful afternoon - full of chilled rosé, stunning cheese plates, and beautiful music. 

Sitting in the comforts of the shade beneath elegant overhanging trees - while beaming faces - enjoyed the enclosed oasis of fantastic wine and wonderful company - I felt abundantly thankful.

Bacchanal is worth the Uber ride. It's non-pretentious, full of great vibes, and it's always graced by lulling live music.

I recommend coming on the earlier side- since I've heard it does get busier later on in the early evening. But definitely don't sleep on this New Orleans gem. You could easily spend all day here.

Trust.

It was late. We were headed back to our hotel, when my husband spied some people devouring pizza slices. Our hotel plans were momentarily dashed - as we embarked on a new mission to hunt down after-hours pizza. We chased down some at Outlaw Pizza. We showed up just in time to buy their last slice.

My husband said the pizza was solid - in between taking big bites of his pepperoni slice, as we headed back to the hotel. Just then -we heard someone running up behind us. It was the gentleman from Outlaw Pizza who had sold us his last slice. He had run all the way from Outlaw Pizza to give my husband back his forgotten credit card.

Thank you Outlaw Pizza for saving the night - when it came to greasy evening sustenance and for allowing us to make future late night purchases for the rest of our stay in New Orleans.

Trust.

We'd heard from a number of in-the-know locals that The Bluebird was a sure thing for an intimate encounter with great musicians. 

On one of our last nights in the city we took a pricey cab out here for their open mic night. 

We were advised on the phone to arrive early, due to the intimate size of The Bluebird. Walking in around 6pm - we grabbed a table, just as two guitarists finished their set.

The whole place was full, so we were lucky to snag some seating. A waitress quickly came by to take our order. We ordered some sweet potato fries, the blackened sandwich and the chicken sandwich. The catfish sandwich was great. Spicy and bursting with taste.

The Bluebird Cafe is a big deal in Nashville. If you have the opportunity to play here - you savor it. All of the performers were so genuinely honored to be playing at such a love filled spot, in which people give their full attention to those playing. Everyone around the room appreciated the talent that glided around the room in smooth chords and octaves. 

While we had a great time here, I wasn't always fond of some of the more new-country ballads that were performed during the night, and preferred more of the closing soulful country stuff. I would definitely love to come here again, but would maybe try to go on a different night other than the open mic. A good time, but sometimes it's nice to know what kind of music to expect when you make a night of it.

Trust.

Desperate to bounce out of Bonabooooooo on our epic Tennessee adventure we scanned Yelp fervently on my dying Iphone for a hotel room.

With no battery and only seconds to spare - Club Hotel Inn came up on my phone screen and I just dialed. Their room rates were reasonable considering the busy week that we were inquiring about (CMA awards, Fanfare, as well as Bonnaroo all happening around the same time) and they had a room available that night.

We booked it. And then my phone died.

With no expectations -  we rolled up to Club Hotel in a dusty cab. Despite sporting unwashed clothes and hair, the staff were exceptionally friendly. We were led to spacious room with a comfortable bed, comfortable couch, big screen TV, a mini fridge, a microwave, and some standard toiletries. 

The first thing we did was shower. After washing off all of the Bonnaroo yuck - we began to explore the place. Club Hotel Inn not only has a convenient work-out area, but it also has a great outdoor pool area. Our second night there - we asked for a room with a balcony and were able to perch ourselves on it, read, and overlook the pool. So relaxing and such an exhilarating feeling after grueling Bonnaroo. 

Some of the exciting perks about Club-Hotel were their mini fridge and microwave, which allowed us grab some groceries and make some make-shift lunches for ourselves, their on-site laundry facilities - which allowed us to bring back clean smelling clothes for our journey home, the complimentary shuttle which took us back to the airport, and their complimentary wowing breakfast spread.

Each morning we would tiredly drag ourselves downstairs to indulge in a breakfast display that made our hearts beam. With a waffle maker on hand, hot eggs, sausages, homefries, cereal, muffins, bagels, fruit and more - we would go to town every morning - fueling ourselves up for mid-day pool lounging. Definitely key for those on a tight budget.

The only drawback for this place was the location. It's convenient if you want a spot near the airport - but if you want to go downtown - expect to pay about 25 dollars for a cab ride over there. Other than that - it was perfect for our needs and a much needed break before we headed back to SF.

Trust.

I felt so fancy in my silk dress and perched upon Virago's bar stool. 

Virago's interior design is jaw-droppingly sexy. From smooth-soft-to-the- touch wood accents. Sleek bamboo tables, low lounge-y booths, to come hither lighting. Their newly added bar rooftop - is just as stunning as the evening Nashville view from it. 

It was our first night of vacation, and we were with folks who knew Virago's menu well - and so we went big.

We ordered:

1.) PISTACHIO HAMACHI 
crushed pistachio, maldon sea salt, serrano, yuzu, unfiltered olive oil

2. V2 EDAMAME 
wok-charred, togarashi, sweet soy

3.) CRAB AND SHRIMP DUMPLINGS 
carrot-ginger sauce

4.) BLACKENED AHI 
sushi-grade tuna, mango vinaigrette

5.) BIG ISLAND HEARTS OF PALM 
spiced Marcona almonds, strawberry papaya, mojito vinaigrette

6.) RISING SUN 
crab, salmon, shrimp, tempura crunch and spicy mayo rolled without rice, tempura-battered and fried, topped with pepper tobiko and honey fire sauce

7.) EQUADOR 
tuna, hamachi, cilantro, cucumber, avocado, chives, jalapeño, masago, tempura crumbs, wasabi mayo, sesame seeds and sriracha

The Blackened Ahi, the Rising Sun, and the Crab and Shrimp Dumplings were the standouts for us. Each melted in our mouth with pronounced flavor. The Edamame was also excellent - spicy and sweet and the perfect way to start our dramatic feast of quality sushi.

Our meal at Virago was a tremendous was to start our blossoming Nashville adventure. If you're in the area and looking for a swank spot for the night - be sure to make reservations at Virago. 

My only advice is to ask the server for recommendations  - since some of our ordering items, though tasty, didn't wow us - as much as others. I would also recommend trying to check out Virago during the weekdays, since like all hot-spots - the weekends are the busiest. Also, while it's often suggested to sit at the bar at sushi spots, I would suggest holding out for a table. Our server - was traditionally a bartender at the space, and though he was friendly enough, he didn't seem as well versed in the menu as he could have been.

Trust.

The impressive array of diverse flat-breads, convenient outdoor seating, and massive interior here - should be enough reason to check out Urban Flats Flatbread.

Urban Flats carries everything from spicy Thai flat-bread to lobster mac and cheese and a wealth of other colorful dishes as well. 

If you have a big group - Urban Flats is ideal. They have a wealth of big tables and their menu is big enough to accommodate all particular food fancies.

I just wish that I'd stuck with the straightforward sure thing items such as hummus and the veggie flat-breads, instead of feeling adventurous and ordering the salmon. My bf looked at me hard and even politely challenged my order. 

"Are you sure you want to order fish? Ya do know that Tennessee is land-locked."

But I was not to be swayed.

He was  - of course-  right. My salmon was dry, lacked pronounced flavor and was dwarfed by a strong tasting mustard sauce. Fail. That being said  - his Spicy Thai Flat-bread was quite good, and the chocolate lava cake we had to finish our meal - was decent.

Sitting outside on our last evening in the city - we wished we'd been more adventurous with our final Nashville meal, but the warm friendly service and the easy walk to busy-tourist-filled Broadway for some live music was worth it.

Trust.

My husband lived off of the frozen Irish Coffees here - during our New Orleans stay. While I didn't partake myself -  I always enjoyed the walking adventure of getting to this quaint bar.

Molly's At the Market is perfect for reviving the tired, hot and thirsty on a busy New Orleans day. The staff are always quick and welcoming, their customers are always laid back, their bathrooms are clean, and their frozen Irish Coffees are beyond dreamy.

Like others have recommended - if you stop in here - for a frozen Irish Coffee - get the large. Just do it. Everybody that we took here during our stay - was so thankful for their caffeinated treat - and it proved to be a perfect sustenance pick-me-up for strolling through the humid New Orleans streets.

Trust.
My room was clean, staff was friendly.  Plenty of parking.  My big complaint is the wi-fi is very slow, and that is a MUST for a hotel (traveling on business!)

Meh. I had heard good things about this place, but I feel that it's overrated. The patio area was cute, but the chairs were pretty uncomfortable. Plus they sat us right in ripe smelling distance from the porta-potties (I think they're remodeling their bathroom or something). I had the huevos valenzuela-- meh again. It did the trick but was a bit bland. I don't know. Service was pretty good. Maybe this place would have warranted 4 stars if it weren't for the wafting breezes of urine stench.

My small circle of good friends venture onwards to our second New Jersey vineyard tour at Hopewell Valley Vineyards, which surely brings life from "From Crisis to Triumph" Exodus (13:17-14:31). 

There are ample outdoor seating with shades under large umbrellas where my small party of four enjoyed our meal with Brie cheese and other munchies. With excellent company in the presence of good friends we had the pleasure of Hopewell's wine barrel tour which is included in the $6.00 tasting. This same $6.00 tasting enables wine connoisseurs to go further with their dollar especially in today's ailing economy of "permanent decline" noted by Huffington Post to keep their tasting glasses. Staff fully exercise their wine knowledge and visibly hone their interpersonal skills to demonstrate quality customer service. 

Personally, I enjoyed the Sangiovese 2008 for it harness a nice fruity and light acidic flair without overpowering too citrus. The Vidal Blanc was very enjoyable to be sweet for the light and very airy crisp. My favorite was the Spuma Rossa Red Sparkling Wine which makes a delightfully seductive sweet dessert for two of a happy ending to close the night. The tasting menu is fully detailed with notes, wine names with corresponding year thus there are no secrets as Hopewell is very upfront and direct. 

Hopewell Valley Vineyards ensures the world there is HOPE!

This review is based entirely on the toll free customer service.  After waiting an eternal ten minutes of being on hold to be finally connected in speaking to a human being, the representative repeated to same questions three times. All I wanted was to be demoved from their mailing list of endless catalogs in the mail. Is it so difficult to be removed against my will?

Beautiful park in South Philadelphia known to South Philadelphians as "The Lakes" (originally named League Island Park and now locally known as the "Lakes"). 

The park's gazebo, lagoon, and creek are an oasis built by Olmsted Brothers, the firm of Frederick Law Olmsted and John Charles Olmsted in the early 1900s (same park designers as the renowned New York's Central Park). Franklin Delano Roosevelt Park was reclaimed mostly from marshlands.  My closest and sincere friends came to Philly in persuit of a day retreat away to celebrate my birthday differently outside the active yet abrasive hustle and bustle of New York City.  Franklin Delano Roosevelt Park replinish my sweetness lost enable me to retreat calmingly to renew my spirit.

Nearby located under Interstate 95 is FDR Skatepark which once played host to the Gravity Games 2005.  An excellant skate park with many ramp, vert ramp and wall of concrete known as a challenge for skaters, roller bladders of all levels from beginners to advanced to professional.  FDR Skatepark sits directly under Interstate 95 overpass thus protected from rain and snow in the winter months.  While I'm not the outdoors type of gal, my two close friends walked by as observers which I noted all athletics are not wearing any helmets or head gear.  In New York State skaters, roller bladders, et al are required by law to wear helmets sadly today's volatility world can damage goods.  Wishful thinking... why are there no protective gear for the heart in preventing it to be broken to become one man's vile trash and damage goods?!?

Warning:  Public restrooms are nastily vile as there are no locks on the stall's doors and no hooks to hold personal belongings.  There is no tiolet tissue holder attached to the wall either.

http://www.fairmountpark.org/fdrpark.asp

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Franklin_Delano_Roosevelt_Park

In my past life of adult times I bought a "First Christmas Together" Christmas ornament in honor of a special year.  

Lenox is traditional yet classic home decor and housewares.  I rate Lenox Corporation four stars due to lack of designs for "First Christmas Together" ornaments.

When you have to work on a weekend it's nice to stop off for lunch at a spot that screams panache. Luke (or Louuuuke) is a great place that (as it appears) tons of Yelpers flock to. Being brought here is a delicious technicality.

For me, N'Orleans fare goes a really long way; not that I don't love it; but I love it more when I have it less. My colleague ordered everything in oysters, and I mean everything. While he slurped away, I fell in love with my bisque. How can something so decadent and buttery, still taste light and sweet? 

Our drinks did not arrive during this wonderful appetizer round, though. That they had a crowd was putting it mildly. It's at these moments you can take in the decor: that being warm and relaxed, which I also loved. Our table was located very close to 3 other diners: I could have grabbed a handful of pickles from each of them. 

When our main meal arrived we were not disappointed. The cracked crab was amazing; amazing enough for all to worship at it's altar; it was coupled with a light slaw that was not knee deep in mayo; but spicy and tangy and on my plate it was gone! It came with a grilled stuffed tomato that was loaded with a crab and cheese mixture with a definite kick! Awesome.

My colleague ordered what many seemed to be ordering: the crab bit; in addition to fried green tomatoes. He seemed to have no complaints because he leveled his plate.

Our drinks came at the end of the meal, and it's a good thing too because by then our pH levels had altered dramatically. Though attentive in certain areas, the service was not "up there". But the food at Luke was wonderful.

They say everyone has a "double". Well, I have a friend at home who looks just like John Besh. Though Chef Besh didn't appear for me to compliment him on the meal: I can do that when I get home. :-)

Yes, I took the tour.
Yes, I loved the tour.
Yes, I would do it again when I had more time.

The fact of the matter is, no bones about it, there is much to be learned in New Orleans fabled Cemetery #1. Though I glided along with a coworker, I was informed that the SOC tour is the best deal in town; what they are about is maintaining and restoring so that interesting shrines of the deceased do not turn to ashes and dust.

They are also about the history component of these hallowed avenues; and our tour guide was both interesting and informative. There was clear-cut "respect in her voice. 

For example, many assume that "Basin Street" bodes ill for any possibility of resting in peace without a floatation device. Frankly, if you actually check out the amazing stone work in front of you it is so very French, so very Spanish: that it's nice to know that ethnic influence was the predominant piece in above ground resting places. Does it hurt in a flood? No.

Though we did not make a pilgrimage to #2, 3, or 4 sections, we did pause at the Glapion family mausoleum, that being the resting place of Voodoun priestess Marie Laveau. Was it my imagination or did I really smell roses when I placed by xxx on the side of her tomb? Or was it the mist and fog swirling around that added to our experience of the tour?

I know what I believe. Let's hope my request comes true.

As my cab pulled up, I had a flashback to a less than positive time. How vivid was that time? Let's just call it post traumatic stress disorder vivid. So, I was hoping against hope that history would not revisit itself in this particular inn of the Comfort Inn chain of places you call home when you're not able to be at home.

The check in was efficient and friendly which started things off well. I didn't have to dig out my own pen to sign anything as in days of yore.

A courteous and smiling employee showed me to my room, which continued the positive vibe; versus my recollection of dragging my suitcase in search of a room that would have won the award for "room located furthest away from anything".

As to my room; hmmm, clean, neat, all in place - that is refreshing, There was no refreshing the last time when particles of the ceiling rained down on my head in the shower.

As I settled down to sleep, I realized I could actually go to sleep, in the bed, as opposed to balancing precariously on the edge in hope of not catching ..... something microscopic. Nor did I have to focus on the faces of numerous passengers as their jet landed at Louis Armstrong.

Though my towels were forgotten, I must admit that time does heal some wounds of the business travel variety. The Comfort Inn may not be my first choice but they did a great job in dispelling a less than "comfortable" experience. Thanks!

After a 2 day whirlwind trip to the Big Easy, my work friend said, "You can't go back to Chicago without stopping at Gambino's." Okay, I'm game. I had heard about this place; even my family told me to "bring 'em back some olives" before I got on the plane. I had also passed some man at Louis Armstrong International who was going through the TSA with a giant King Cake. 

The selection of sweets and pastries at Gambino's was impressive. They had a ton of stuff; with a ton of calories. I was trying to calculate in my head intake versus output before making any selection.

The folks at Gambino's were pleasant and efficient; it was fairly busy and one woman juggled two customers at once. My colleague (unbeknown st to me) had ordered a (what I call) medium sized King Cake for pick up. It was ready and waiting. I thought I would take things one bakery good at a time.

I picked one of their macaroons. Oh my God. Nestled under a mixture of crushed pecans and who knows what else was massively sweet and succulent coconut. I'm sure I groaned audibly but it was to die for. Literally. The other item that really looked divine were the pralines. They had some sized small: so I got a couple (for when my pancreas stopped gyrating).

It was enough for me to forget all about the olives. While I was still in heaven, I saw King Cake upon King Cake exit the building. I just shook my head; those King Cakes have nothing on the macaroons. I almost wish there were a few things less high on the sweet Richter scale; if that is possible. 

The Gambino's are Chicago history. These Gambino's are in a class by themselves.

i take my 4-star rating back,
they were open in the great power outage of march 2009 -- for that, i was very thankful.

the first arby's to be given less than 5 stars.
but my heart broke when i discovered that they close early on weeknights (especially since the ones in metairie are open 'til ridiculously late in the morning).
srsly, how can a reputable fast food establishment 2 blocks from bourbon close before midnight?!?

Nothing satisfies like an Arby's Reuben.

I don't know if it's the soft as a cloud marbled Rye bread (I don't care for the crusty texture of traditional Rye), the secret sauce, the "meat," or what, but out of the almost hundred (rough estimate) Reuben sandwiches I've tried, I still crave the Arby's version.

The hotel is nicely finished. I loved the art pieces around the common areas the most.  The rooms and bathrooms were nice.  My room was on the second floor and faced Tchoupitoulas, so it was a little noisy, otherwise, it was all good.  The gym had a decent selection of equipment for a hotel and included a sauna (although there was no need for it in the summertime).

Service was courteous, but I had a customer service nightmare getting the rate I was promised and trying to adjust my bill at checkout which carried over into the next week.
not bad (same great stuff as the one in the quarter)... but for the real thing (sticky tables and all), go to the one on decatur.

The food was great. I had a light meal here (the place had caught my eye on the way "home"):

-- 1/2 dozen P&J oysters were fresh and ICE COLD
-- Fried oyster salad (?) ... Recommended by the server, who insisted that it wouldn't be oyster overkill. The salad was a little overdressed with salty dressing, but holy shit, the chopped up pieces of thick sliced bacon and fried oysters hit the spot

Service was okay. Not extremely attentive, but not bad either.

Atmosphere:
-- Decor was spot on for a hotel restaurant
-- Eavesdropped: "She thinks she's so cool for going to school in Alabama..." (AWESOME)

muthaFORKyeah!

I noticed this location on my way "home" from "work" a few months ago. I squealed with pure glee.

It is on par with other Arby's location, with an extra bonus: I no longer have to trek out to Metairie (WTF is wrong with I-10E?) to enjoy an item from the premier roast beef fast food chain.

i wanted to make sweet-sweet love to this market.

it rivals some of the korean markets in the san jo area in terms of cleanliness, price, selection (food and korean dramas on dvd!) and size. don't get me wrong, i love asian goods of all kinds, but i have moments where i miss the mother's land food (especially when i'm down in NOLA).

extra kudos for the location (it's conveniently right off vet's) and for the shopkeeper not asking me, "you ko-lee-an?" instead, he asked if it was my first time... the oriental name is a little off-putting, but it's the souf, so whatevs.

as the other reviewers said, the decor and drink selection make this a great place to be.

upgraded-dives like this are a dime a dozen in other big cities, but they're a rarity in this part of NOLA (hence the 5-star rating).

came here for a late dinner in the dining room. didn't come to see a show, so take my review with a grain of salt.
the restaurant has a very nice ambiance. there was "real" jazz music flowing into the dining room, the artwork that decorated the walls were really interesting, and the lighting and seating setup gave it an overall good feel.
the food was okay. i ordered a salad, grilled yellowfin and a side of green beans:
-- salad was a standard green salad. they get extra points for not using iceberg lettuce.
-- the yellowfin was decent... nothing to write home about, but it was cooked to my specifications.
-- the green beans were nice and crunchy, but oversalted.
five words: DEEP FRIED ROAST BEEF POBOY!

Dear Home,

I had BIG, MEATY oysters at this place called Drago's.

I had a lot of fun watching the guys behind the oyster grill bar shucking oysters, ladling a cheesy-garlicky-butter sauce out of a 50 gallon barrel, and playing with fire.

The entree (I got the catch of the day) was okay. The salad was meh, as were the veggies, but the redfish was nice and moist and the crab sauce hit the spot.

The oysters (both the raw and the chargrilled) were so delicious. I can't wait to come here again to stuff my face with oysters.

love,
cynthia

happy hour special: $7/dozen oysters.

i don't know that i'd enjoy the regular fare (it's a bit pricey, and after a crappy day @ work, i didn't want to be disappointed with not-good upscale dining), but the happy hour oysters were good and mad cheap. the bar service was fairly courteous as well.

i walked through the kitchen-stuff section today during a lunch break.

holy shi-za! they sell:
-4.57 gallon containers of deep frying oil
-the "original batter pro"
-a bacon grill/press

this greatly amuses me.

In Cali-Cali, this grocery sto' wouldn't even register on my meter. It's somewhere between the communist Russia Safeways and dingy Save Marts.

In the NO, it's a lifesaver when my body's reached it's saturation point with fried foodz. The salad bar, produce, prepackaged soup, and dairy are pricey compared to what I'm used to (I noticed that the meatz are cheap and they have quite a selection of Cajan/Creole specialty food also for cheap, if I were ever adventurous enough to try to cook in a Residence Inn kitchenette). But it's nice having a choice in what I stuff into my face.

it gets a few "novelty value" stars, but i have no idea what everyone is raving about.

it's a great tourist attraction, but fails as a means of reliable public transportation. i'm pretty sure i can walk faster than the streetcar.

ARGH. I found myself renting from Alamo for the THIRD time (as they were the cheapest and I was trying to save the governmentz monie$).

A litte better. They were more attentive.

Still they get an EPIC FAIL because they change $2.50 to be a part of their loyalty program. It's a bargain for a few hundred FF miles, but piece of crap, I can't think of another car rental company/hotel that charges for this "service."

I hope to never have to rent from them again.

I can't even begin to describe how happy I was to find about Green Truck. Everyone we worked with was helpful and had really great attitudes. I'd like to especially shout out Alex and Cordell for making this move great.

Visiting from out of town and looking for a unique cafe for breakfast and to do some computer work, I happened upon this gem (with Yelp's help).  Warm, welcoming atmosphere and employees and great food.

I wish I had looked at these reviews before bringing my car to the Collision Repair center for service.  After leaving my car there for one week, I received it back with only half of the work done.  There evidently was a dispute over what the repair center and what my insurance company were supposed to do, and it does appear that my insurance company bears some responsibility.  My primary concern is that when I spoke directly with the person at reception about having the repairs done, she neglected to tell me that there was a problem and that she needed additional information. Instead she told me everything was all set. I think she was overwhelmed and just wanted to move on to the next waiting person.  A week later, after having been told the car was completely repaired, I went to pick it up to find only half the work done - and, had to find this out myself.  No one at the repair service told me that they only did one part of the repair.  Poor, expensive, assembly-line service is what you will get at this place.

Review Update:
As Shawn at Don Brown mentioned, after posting this review, I was immediately contacted by Pam in Customer Service.  Everything Shawn said is correct.  Pam handled things very professionally and discussed concrete ways they will implement to make the service experience more helpful and supportive of the customer.  I appreciated her call and realized that I had I requested to speak with her or someone in the Customer Service area, much of yesterday's frustration could have been alleviated.  Lesson learned.

I love Tria. It is my go-to when don't know where else to go. They have an endless list of amazing beers and I have a weakness for every single kind of bruschetta they make.

Did I also mention how much I love cheese? I LOVE cheese. And they do not disappoint. 

I almost forgot the best thing on the menu. Beet salad. I know what you're all thinking... isn't that what my grandma eats that makes her teeth purple? Why yes, yes it is. But I can guarantee to you that your grandma has never tasted anything this good with beets.

I ordered pizza here when I visited my parents. It's baller. 

Seriously. 

Honey Mustard Chicken Pizza? 
Baller.

Bacon Cheeseburger Pizza?
Baller.

Taco Pizza?
Baller.

Also, did I mention that it is all diet food? 
Because, if I did, I was lying.

This place is legit!! The oyster pancake was just like the ones I had when I was staying in Taipei.  All the food was amazing! I highly advise anyone and everyone to come here.  Service was fast even with a packed house, the food came out quick and almost all at once.  For good fresh food in the down town area come here!!

So came here with a group after a long weekend looking for pho after partying, sadly it was not the pho we needed.  Compared to other pho spots the bowls were small, prices high, broth bland, tendon undercooked, no fish sauce, tea was an extra fee, the combo came with 1/2 a beef ball!!!! Add to this it took about 30 minutes to get all this to arrive at our table.

Got some sides from here on the way back the service was pretty quick and friendly staff.  But the max and cheese was more a soup than a creamy Mac.  Baked beans are solid with some
Meat and back bone to them.  The fried okra were the star of the 3 tasty tasty goodness totally get those!!!!!.  Didn't try the bbq so can't say anything about that this was just about the sides

The service and beer selection was great! The staff was super friendly and my friends and I had a great time hanging out at the bar. The menu looks amazing, but we just came in for drinks. I would have loved to try the Chili Con Queso with Crawfish, or Nachos w/ fried oysters.

This was the first stop on my South and Southwest camping trip. I specifically chose the KOA because I knew I could mess things up and they would be helpful.

Indeed they were. (Even as I set up my tent in the torrential rains that hit.) The facilities were first rate: clean showers, bathrooms, and a great little kitchen and washing machine area for those funky clothes days.

It's KOA: so you know there were about a billionty things for kids to do. The best part: directly across from Opryland. If you don't get why that's the best part...put down the computer, back away, and then run.

It's a bit out of the way for my trail running -- about 20 miles -- but definitely worth the stay.

The only annoyance: the campground lights sit along the tent grounds, which means there is a stream of light that you need to block out with the rainfly, even when it's not raining.

I can't say enough about Bob. Our kitchen sink clogged on Friday afternoon, and he came over to snake our drain. After removing the sludge from our pipe, we realized our basement drain was clogged as well. We called him on Saturday morning, and he came over to fix that as well. With no hassle and without breaking the bank, we had a fully functioning house again. I can't say enough about Bob and his assistants. Wonderful people, and wonderful work.

The food was decent. I was starving after a long day of trail running so it's hard to tell. I know I didn't love it, but it was relatively inexpensive, the staff was nice, and the food came out quickly.

They also had a large screen television with soccer (er, football) playing.

I think the best part of this is likely the deck outside. It was packed when I got there. Inside, was pretty empty.

My wife and I spent the last month shopping for furniture at various stores across Indianapolis. Without a doubt, our best experience was with Urban Home. We found the perfect kitchen table (a pub table with 4 chairs and a bench) at a great price. More importantly, though, we loved the service we received (as we continued to come back in). 

We found several pieces of furniture at other locations, and before we'd purchase anything, we returned to U.H. On two occasions, the manager was able to get us a better deal than we could elsewhere (and the two times he couldn't, he helped us figure out which piece was a better deal even though we weren't buying from him). 

We just can't say enough about the personal service, the good nature of the employees, and the positive vibe we had in the store. (The store is set up so that it's easy to chat with other customers without it feeling weird.)

Our advice: Before you buy anything, make sure you stop by Urban Home.

I love REI. This one is a tad small, but still had what I needed. The staff was nice, as well.

I was only there for a few days (I mean - I didn't STAY in the store, but I was in the town for a few days), and when I stopped by there wasn't much action. I'm used to REI stores being the epicenter of activities. 

So: good for gear, not so good for connecting with other outdoor freaks.

Soul Sista glad I didn't miss ya.

Been waiting for this place to open up, but I guess I must have missed the memo that it finally did, so as I was driving by and saw ppl inside I came to a screeching halt and popped in. First and foremost I was impressed by what they've done with this place, def a classy joint. Asked the waitress what she recommended and she immediately suggested the fried chicken (dumbest question of the year) so I went with the smothered fried chicken, mash and Mac and cheese. All was excellent, especially the mash. The waitress was attentive and polite, and the food came out quick without a hiccup. Really rooting for this place to do well in a part of town that desperately needs it. I'll be back to try some more, if everything is as good as what I initially had I may bump to 5 soon.
Panchero's is chipotle except for 2 things, it's not as good, and they charge u extra for veggies

DOONERZ = SUCCESS

I don't even know how to start this review. I've been to this place a number of times, but those number of times don't add up to many memories if you catch what I'm throwing at cha. 

All I know is that I walk in and literally say this, "give me the shit" which is usually followed by a confused stare, which is then followed with me reiterating "give me whatever's the shit"

They usually finally understand what I'm babbling and respond with "I got you bro"

What follows is amazingness. I couldn't tell you what the hell Im eating, but I will tell you it's definitely The Shit

You know why Mazzaro's is winning?

Cause $7 gets you a Sub that you can only finish if you're a fat bastard and an IPA that'll make you want to slap your mother. Thats a Value Meal right there

Best deli dtown? Not lucky dill, not ............... Wait is there even another one? Well if there is this place smokes that one aswell. It's basic, it's delicious, sandwiches are huge, it's affordable, and it's in a fucking historic train station. This shit wins

In the minority once again but I take this one over the new and pretty Tyrone one any day. It's a gym, you go, you lift, no bullshit. Wait times on machines are a lot better in my opinion, just doesn't seem as crowded. It doesn't have as many bells and whistles, but I don't use the bells and whistles so I don't care. And on that note, I gotta go........gym time

This place does not fuck around, not even for a second. The subs are delicious and big enough to feed a normal person twice easily. When it comes to a sub/sandwich shop Big Steins is the best for my money.

Tampa is known as the creator of the Cuban Sandwich, but the title of best might reside in my neck of the woods....... Good ole St Pete. There's so many things about this sandwich that make it excellent, but the one thing that shoots it into another stratosphere has to be the Pork. When they put the sandwich in the press and that mojo infused pork starts to make love with the Cuban bread it's lights out. That right there is where the Magic Happens and it goes from good to fucking phenomenal in a Cuban second (approx. 3-4 minutes Cuban time)

This sandwich is the Truth, I wouldn't Lie

Bfast options are limited in dtown, unless u wanna head over to beach drive for something overpriced and fancy it's pretty much between central coffee shop and Dome. And that battle can pretty much go either way, neither is amazing, neither is bad. It's pretty much a flip of the coin, luckily their right across the street from one another so u can literally flip that coin if you'd like.

The Setting: 3:05am on a Friday, Saturday night

The Place: dtown St. Pete

The Conflict: You've had way to many libations and you want pizza.

The options: Joey Brooklyn's, Fortunato's, mikes taps or certain death 

The answer: what block are you on? Wait ur not sure? Ok well ask someone where Joey Brooklyn's is at and go there........preferably not a cop.

The Resolution: waking up at 8am laid horizontally on ur bed still dressed in last nights clothes........real quick check ur shirt. Does it have pizza sauce on it? Yup? Ok you went to Joey Brooklyn's

I'm in the minority, exactly where I like to be. The foods good, the portions aren't, the price isn't. Sure it taste good, and yeah there's great beers on tap, but when I spend close to $20 and I'm still hungry at the end of it I feel robbed. It's BBQ not French cuisine, it should plentiful and filling. It cracks 3 stars cause it's a cool idea, and a cool place, but I'm not exactly rushing back

A perfect dive bar for all the just off of 4th st residents. Drinks are strong and cheap, and energy is inviting. It's def the kind of place you roll into with a group of good friends and leave as a drunk group of good friends. For those from the neighborhood it works out even better, u get trashed and then fall back into the back streets like the children from the corn........backstreets

Stack it high and let it fly

These subs should come with a disclaimer, the small is not small, not even close. Actually you could probably get away with eating half of the small and saving the rest for later. The amount of meat that they put on these subs is absolutely absurd......oh yeah and they also taste really good. Def a place worth checking out, you're def getting your money's worth here.

I love this hotel.  I was there there last weekend, and last month... at their restaurant to scope the whole place out for an upcoming event/intimate meeting. I usually do Hotel Monteleone  but Aces popped out to me because of their hipster feel (which is exactly what I've been looking for!).  Room was cool and was barely able to strum some chords on an acoustic guitar but reminiscent of my earlier years. Loved the menu at their restaurant and... absolutely loved "Church".   His service, quick wit and charm made my colleagues and I's evening at the bar. And while our servers have always been great at Aces, Church was the one who made us feel at home and welcomed. He was a quick friend to us. Not pretentious. I went up to the bar, asked for something unusual and he went out of his way more than expected. We wound up staying longer because of him. Talk about CX when we are writing about a white paper on customer experience. I would definitely use Aces for an upcoming event as long as Church was there making sure things happen. He is a gem and so is Aces. Thank you

Super disappointed. Came back to possibly host a banker event at Ace and found out that they had let their best person, " Church" go. This Gen Z manager was so full of their ego they totally missed what good customer service is all about. Not listening to my needs. Expecting me to bed over backwards. Whatever. If anyone knows where "Church" went or where I can find exceptional service, please DM me. It never ceases to amaze me how much egos get in the way. I am so disappointed in Ace's poor decisions as management has no clue. 

Can I give them less than one star?

Love Flanagans!

Some of the beat bar food. Great crowd.  Fun to have the ghost tours for those of us outsiders.  And....the couple of times I've been there I've had a serious crush on the bartender, Church.  

Not a place to miss if you're living in or visiting NOLA.
Seriously. The. *** BEST *** flavors, service, ambiance, & curb appeal!! Best, best, best!!! Such a favorite!!!!

Sucks. Sucks. Sucks. 

SMALL. SMOKEY. DIRTY. SCUM BAG. GROSS. 

After visiting Vegas, Mohegan Sun, Pechanga, & other International casino's, this pathetic Tampa location should have it's tail between it's legs. 

It's filthy. Literally dust and grime wherever you sit or stand....Dirty carpets...FILTHY bathrooms...ALL bathrooms...FILTHY...

No COMPS...No free cocktails as you play, no complementary players club buffet or discounted rooms compared to the other casinos. 

Not to mention the huge ATM & Valet fees. 

YUCK! Wish there was a negative star scale! 

Get your act together Seminole!
Great Hotel, best in Nashville hands down considering options. Not a 5 Star, but nice. Boutique hotel, on point concierge, 1.5 miles from downtown.

Great Amphitheatre. Very organized parking & exit for large event. 

There really doesn't seem to be a bad seat in the house. 

Great acoustics. 

Perfect location right next to Interstate. 

(but....stupid new name! "1-800-Ask-Gary" c'mon! We see him enough on the commercials!)

A perfect location, ambiance, comfort, welcoming & charm! 

Kimpton never disappoints! 

(Dog friendly too!)

5 star view. Exceptional service. 

But the food? Eh, I'm begging to think yelp has 4 stars based on a popularity vote. The flavors & quality were just ok. Nothing to write home about.

SO GREAT! 

Love the river view, fantastic lobby, comfortable & large rooms, fantastic service, exceptional restaurants, great location! 

(Only downer, $14.95 a day for WIFI)

Philadelphia is gritty, from the surroundings to the people. Phillies are dedicated fans and it defiantly showed. They came out hours before the game and sat in the rain til it started. We watched the Phillies vs the Washington Nationals on Monday, May 21st. It was funny routing for the Nationals the day before. We arrived over two hours early and they had already opened up a limited section of the park. We got a drink at Harry The K's the restaurant in left field named after Hall of Fame broadcaster Harry Kalas. You can sit and watch the full game there as long as you keep buying. We watched the Phillies batting practice and walked around the park as it opened. We had seats on the very top level (4 levels!) and it was high up there, still a great seat...but almost a touch of vertigo. The whole stadium felt huge. Capacity 43,651, but it felt like 50+

The video board in left field was so clear and massive, apparently it's the largest HD screen in the National League.  It also wouldn't be Philly without a replica Liberty Bell.  It "rings" and lights up after Philly home runs and wins. Unfortunately, we didn't see either. The Nats won. Another Philadelphia quirk is that their bullpens are in the outfield amongst the fans. When they first opened in 2004 the Phillies bullpen was closest to the fans and after Philly fans booed their own pitchers (these are the same fans that booed Santa Claus) they switched to have the visitors section closer for heckling.

The mascot always needs mentioning. Its rates high on my husbands list. The Phillie  Phanatic....a green beakish creature. The Phanatic has been named the best mascot before and he did not disappoint. He was absolutely hilarious. He came out with a full rain suit on when it began to sprinkle. He mimicked and danced with middle school cheerleaders. There are also videos of him traveling to the Galapagos Islands...his birthplace.

All in all, the stadium might not have a beautiful backdrop of the city, but it was still a beautiful park.  Its very open and you can see the game the entire time you walk around the park.  There were so many options for food (love the cheesesteakes!) and the craft beer was endless. You had to search for any macro beers if you wanted. We were highly impressed with the Philly beer scene.  Philly really was a passionate town about its sports, beer and food.

Quick and super friendly. Emily was super helpful with our order. The burgers were cooked just right and our order of fries and onion rings were just the right amount of crisp. Overall, this was a great experience.
Total jerks - completely rude to our large group and openly mocked us to our faces. We left immediately. I've never been so insulted - do not go here.

I wasn't feeling well... and if I had my choice it would have been a matzo ball soup type of night. Or I may have just skipped dinner and gone straight to bed, but felt like I needed to eat something while pregnant. 

My colleague and I opted for dinner at Wildflower Grill, conveniently located within the Matrix Hotel we were staying at. We made our way downstairs and were seated immediately (no reservations necessary on a Tues night).  

By no fault of Wildflower Grill, but thanks to my stuffed up nose, there wasn't much on the menu that sounded appealing, but I finally settled on a caesar salad. And of course I couldn't pass up on ordering the bread appetizer that so many yelpers raved about.  Both hit the spot, especially the very warm bread that practically melted in my mouth.

I'm sure there's even better food on the menu that my bread and salad, but I"ll have to wait until my next trip to Edmonton when hopefully I'm feeling 100%.

Thank you Comcast Wall for keeping us entertained for 3 hrs while working the check-in table at the fabulous Yelp Spring Feastival. Fortunately, the Philadelphia yelpers are one cool bunch so getting bored wasn't a problem, but when have to sit at a table for 3 hrs staring at a wall of a building it's pretty awesome if there's a show occurring right on that wall.

This is one cool wall! You'd think I'd be sick of watching it after 3 hrs, but not so much the case (maybe just a bit dizzy).  I do still question the tourists I watched stare at the wall for several hrs at a time. Yes, it was a rainy day in Philly, but surely there's cooler stuff to do than spend a day staring at a wall even as awesome as this one.

Traveling with a bad cold is not fun...I was totally that person full of germs that I typically avoid on planes. Fortunately once I arrived in Edmonton (after passing my germs to everyone on the plane) the Matrix Hotel provided me with a clean spacious room and a comfortable bed so I could get a little bit of rest during my short trip.

Overall, I liked this hotel and wouldn't definitely stay here again. My colleague and I were in town to do interviews and they have a nice lounge upstairs that was the perfect spot for them (and it helped that it was empty too). 

It's also centrally located near lots of restaurants, shops and more...so there's no need to rent a car in what I believe is typically a driving city.

The restaurant downstairs was also solid if you happen to visit during one of Edmonton's infamous cold winters.

It's your typical country bar, but considering I never go to country bars in Chicago I thought it was great! My friend had her rehearsal dinner here and it was a blast. A low key atmosphere, BBQ food that didn't do much for me (but my fiance and others seemed happy), and most importantly fabulous service (I had a drink in my hand at all times).

So apparently I visited Posh on the wrong day because there were not $9 suede boots like the ones Caitlin D snagged...lucky gal.  I didn't happen to snag any shoes, but that's  probably because I didn't save any room in my suitcase for yet another pair of shoes...even shoes as cool and funky as the ones at Posh.  If I ever do make it back to Nashville I'll be sure to save some room in the suitcase for a stop at Posh!

I was about to give up on Tampa after a few visits to Ybor City. No offense to the locals, but that street is Austin's Sixth Street Gone Wrong.  Then I discovered the lovely Harbour Island area and realized that I just haven't experienced the good parts of Tampa. Phew!

We found ourselves at Jackons's for dinner in Harbour Island, which was conveniently located behind The Westin my in-laws were staying at.  There's a little something for everyone on this menu: burgers, salads, and even sushi for raw fish addicts like myself.  I'm usually a bit suspicious of sushi from nontraditional sushi restaurants, but the yelpers raved about it so figured I couldn't go wrong.  And the yelpers were right (as usual)!  I truly enjoyed all of the fresh sashimi and crab roll that came with the Jackson Sushi Dinner.  Everything else seemed to be a hit at our table as well!

I hear this place also turns into a club late night. Clubbing isn't quite my thing these days, but I'd definitely come back for more sushi and other good eats.

I'm not typically a fan of Marriott Courtyards, but when I needed a hotel at the last minute due to attending a funeral anything would do. I noticed this Courtyard happened to be attached to the country club where they were holding a celebration of life following mass...and so I booked it! $200/night seemed a bit expensive for a Courtyard in the Philly burbs, but you can't put a price on convenience.

Overall, the hotel was fine. The staff was friendly enough, the room was comfortable enough and even spacious enough for 2 since my colleague and I opted to share a room. We weren't in the hotel very long, but got a bit of sleep, a quck workout in the adequate hotel gym and a coffee downstairs. There's a restaurant attached to the hotel as well, but we weren't there long enough for a meal.

If visiting Philly for fun I"d opt to stay downtown. If I had to be in the Springfield area again I probalby would look for other options, but this was A-Ok for what I needed.

My day trip to Nashville meant I didn't have to spend too much time away from the fam (yay), but it also meant I didn't get to explore much of Nashville (boo). I spent the entire day in the lovely Hutton Hotel and visited this onsite restaurant not once, but twice.  Yep, that's twice..once for lunch and once for dinner.  

I'm typically wary of hotel restaurants, but have to admit this one was pretty good. During a working lunch our party of 10 enjoyed their private room, which even had a TV that we were able to use for a presentation.  I started my meal with the corn gazpacho (eh) and then followed it up with the flat bread (yum). And my colleague was sweet enough to share her fries that came with my burger.

When I stopped back in later that night for dinner I decided to get my own fries and burger. I'm usually not a burger type of girl, but this one was so good!

The lunch service was a little on the slow side, but they were on their game during dinnertime, which allowed me plenty of time to get to the airport and head back to the fam.

I first dined here 15 years and it was easily the most delish meal of my lifetime. Then again, my standards weren't quite as high when I was 22, but it was tasty. Really tasty.

When I arrived back in NOLA 5 years later I planned on having a few less hurricanes, but did plan on going back to Emeril's.  Not sure if the quality had gone down or my standards had gone up, but it was just A-OK. 

And I went back again this past weekend after 10 years this time with 20+ friends in tow to celebrate a friend's 40th bday. I was hopeful it would live up to the initial 2002 hype, but the overall experience was more A-OK 2007.

I was starving so ate every last bite of food, but was almost annoyed to be wasting calories on mediocre food (besides the 6 pieces of delicious bread that I couldn't help but devour after a long travel day). As for the rest of the meal:
Crab cake: 3 stars
Mushroom pasta: 1 star
