Salad: 2 stars
Salmon: 3 stars
peanut butter pie: 4 stars (next time i'll be ordering JUST wine and peanut butter pie)

While serving a group of 20+ women who have had too much wine is no picnic, it was painfully slow...and we were receiving our yummy peanut butter pie when my friends at the table next to me where just getting their entrees.  Thank goodness I had good wine & even better company so it was still a memorable evening.

Not quite a country music fan (although I should be after 3 days in Nashville!), but have to say I enjoyed myself at the Country Music Hall of Fame and Museum.

Warning- they charge $20 to get in (slightly less for students and triple A members), which I thought was quite expensive, but I guess Nashville has to make their $$$ somehow!  

Many of the exhibits were pretty cool, but I didn't look at anything in too much detail because I was busy chatting away with my 2 friends and was having trouble multi tasking. 

And I probably should be embarrassed to admit that we spent more time in the gift shop of the Museum than looking at the exhibits....but if you're looking for a cowboy hat or anything else country related this is the place to get it!

Stayed here, as well as attended a friend's wedding, here this weekend. The wedding rate was $149/night and for that this is a 4 star hotel, but the usual rate is over $250 so in that case it's probably more like a 3 star hotel.

The good:
- Nice sized rooms with a separate living room area
- Comfortable beds
- A huge bathroom to primp myself for the wedding
- Right in the middle of downtown Nashville, as well as across from the country music museum
- Plenty of cabs always available even though Nashville isn't actually a cab friendly city
- elevators that move at lightning speed
- $13 breakfast buffet that I didn't try myself, but my fiance has mentioned what a great deal it was at least 10 times (it's the little things in life that excite him)

The bad
- unimpressive workout room
- pretty gross indoor pool that you couldn't pay me to step foot in
- they need to learn how to make a latte...I could hardly drink the one they made for me downstairs

For those of you looking to plan a special event in Nashville I"d also recommend the grand ballroom- my friend had a beautiful wedding here last night! It's a simple, yet elegant ballroom...the type where any decorations will work.  

Would I return to the Hilton during my next trip to Nashville (if there ever is another trip to Nashville)? Yes, probably...but it would depend on the price. I would be happy staying here for under $200, but over that I'd seek shelter elsewhere.

After waiting FOREVER for my iced latte I was expecting the best beverage ever, but it turned out to taste quite disgusting and I opted not to waste my one caffeinated drink of the day on such a drink.  Even Starbucks can do way better than this! I would have been happier at a SB, but my colleague and I had booked a few meetings at Transcend Coffee and were camped out for a few hours. 

I found myself waiting in another long line there just hours later when I got hungry, but wasn't impressed with any of their food options. I chose a muffin, ate a few bites and decided to hold out for lunch at MRKT.

I had already eaten an early dinner, but when colleagues suggested late night sushi I wasn't going to pass up raw fish. I have to admit I was skeptical of finding really good sushi in Nashville, but I was proved wrong. 

We called while on the way and were told there was a 15 min wait on a Thursday evening at 9pm. But then when we arrived literally 2 min later we spotted at least 10 open tables and were seated immediately. Perhaps pretending to have a wait makes them seem more popular? 

Sam, our fab waiter, helped us make the perfect choices for the 2 of us (myself included) who eat anything related to sushi and our other 2 colleagues who are vegan. 

We started with the crispy rice app, which I can't ever pass up when I see it on a menu. So good. And from there ordered 2 rolls. Both were fantastic. I'm blanking on one of the names, but would never forget the tasty kuro scallop roll.  And we could get enough of the crispy Brussels sprouts. I may even be able to get my "I don't touch vegetables" 3 yr old to eat these. 

I left so full (2 dinners will do that to you) and so impressed with Nashville's sushi scene.

Siam Elephant has risen back to the top of my local faves! They've punched more favor into their dishes. It had dipped down and become somewhat bland (only 3 star worthy), but with this latest visit just the other night, in which I had the pumpkin curry and my wife the pad thai, we both agreed that it was as good as ever. Way to bounce back Siam Elephant!
Lee's is old school and awesome! Very reasonable rates and quality work!

This place has had a really nice make over! Guess I hadn't been here in years, because the waitress said it had been like this for a couple years now. Before it looked like a greasy spoon diner from the 70s. Now it looks like a greasy spoon diner from the 2000s that's going for that 50s look. I like it!

As for the food, it's a-ok! Pretty standard breakfast/lunch diner. No real frills, just solid eggs and bacon type stuff with sandwiches/burgers for lunch. But they've also got three beers on tap: a national, a regional and a local. So that's kinda cool!

Good, quick service. All around decent place!

I've been to the French Press' secondary location a few times now. It has a slightly different vibe than the original, but it's still your typical hang-out for studying college kids and your general laptop users (meaning one person per table...luckily there's plenty of seating). The drinks are solid. The service is quick, polite and helpful.

Holy Moses, that parking lot! It's shared by a pet shop, a fast food chain and a busy drug store, and it's barely big enough for TJs shoppers alone!

Aside from that, I love this location. Shelves are usually well stocked, it's clean and the service is top-notch. You do get a flaky douche or two in from Montecito, but that's not TJ's fault.

I came here years ago, had a bad experience and didn't come back until just now. I don't know what it was back then, but the food tasted weird. Anyhow, I'm a Yelp fan so I check out reviews on here often and I noticed that Judge For Yourself was still getting high marks. I figured there had to be a reason, so I finally gave it another shot and am I glad I did! Sure, it is a greasy spoon kind of diner, but it's solid in that respect. Everything tasted just fine. There are a lot of restaurant choices in Santa Barbara, my list of go-to places is long. Judge For Yourself Cafe made it back on the list!

The local frozen yogurtry. Like the town, it's tiny. There are few choices than others of its kind, but a half dozen or so yogurt choices and about a dozen toppings to choose from should be a enough for most people. Usually clean and tidy. The kids running the place are always attentive and friendly.
Damn good! Love the crisp crust! The warm, gooey innards are divine! Located within the same storedfront as the taproom and donut place, this makes the perfect happy-hour spot!

Everything works, so that's a bonus! I didn't get short-changed at the change machine. My washer cleaned my clothes thoroughly and quickly. The dryer dried the shit out of my stuff super fast. I liked the big screen tv playing oldies rock from the '50s and '60s. There's wi-fi and tables & chairs to sit and work at.

This place is great! Love the vibe! Got the rosemary Thai tea and hummus, and loved both. Delicious all around! The hummus had a nice spiciness to it. Loved the bread that came with the hummus. Nice crunchy crust, soft squishy insides and perfectly seasoned with garlic and salt.  I'll be back to try more of their food and the very interesting drink concoctions!

I got married here!

Well, technically in the lovely rose garden out front, where there's lots of lawn space for picnics, frisbee, and fetch with Fido.

Tours of the Mission are reasonably priced and worth it. Plenty of plaques relaying the history. A few artifacts in a small museum-ish area to view for free.

The gift shop is obnoxiously large and sprawling.

You can walk around the ruins out front or walk the paths and find them in the scant trees for free. You can't go into the church for free anymore though, which blows.
Getting the right flowers for the occasion was easy-breezy with Tracey! Thanks for making my wife's special day specialer!

Like most things in ritzy Montecito, this is a nice library. It's got a cozy, homey atmosphere. The furniture in the reading room is comfy. 

The main drawback of this branch is its size. It's quite small. So, the book selection isn't vast, the computers for internet access are few, the aisles are narrow and seating is limited. 

Having said that, they do a lot with the little they have! The one or two staffers are helpful when asked. The selection of the books and other materials they do have are of good quality. And the place is usually quiet. Just what I look for in a library!

Classic, greasy spoon diner that specializes in breakfast. In the past I've heard complaints about the service and brusk treatment doled out by the owners, but when we went the service was nothing but pleasant, helpful and all around cordial. I'd say the place is aware of the bad comments because it seems like they're trying to do something about. I heard a waiter ask patrons a couple times while we were there how the service was. So good on them for trying to improve themselves!

I don't get the low ratings and poor reviews on this place. Everytime I've been the food and service have been great. Granted it's set up to accommodate 2-4 adults, not large parties. The atmosphere is nice and the prices are not rock bottom, so I wouldn't  recommend it for children. If you're looking for a family place, try Tony's across the street.

Super cheap (50 cents per trip per person as of this review), quiet, open-air transport up and down State Street. Great, inexpensive way to see the main drag without walking the often crowded sidewalks. Excellent way to get to the beach without taking your car and searching for parking.

But be warned, this is mostly for tourists. It rolls along at a leisurely pace and stops at every block. If you need to get somewhere fast, this isn't the transport you're looking for.

Interesting side note: These electrical busses were once owned by Disney and used to shuttle people back and forth from the parking lot. When they decided to upgrade, Santa Barbara bought them and created a new public transport line with them.
Big selection of candies, some of which they make on the premises. They even have some decent sugar-free options. I like the classic stuff as well, like candy cigarettes, wax lips and taffy.

These doughnuts are gorgeous to look at. They look like edible masterpieces. These are not small doughnuts, so be prepared to fill the belly. They are dense and decadent. They are decorated and addictive. These are like fork and knife kinda doughnuts. This place can also get a little busy, but patience is a virtue....

Sabrina's is definitely worth the detour. I would make the detour anytime. It is a bustling eatery (filled with locals, college students, and visitors alike) on the lower-level of a beautiful house. It almost feels like home with creative, innovative, and eccentric food that is comforting. We both ordered off of the special 90's hip hop menu. I got eggs florentine a.k.a. Salt-N-Peppa's "Let's Talk About Eggs Baby." I added lox, which was an eggsellent choice. The hollandaise was thick, but not heavy or rich, and it went well with the earthy spinach, the salty lox, and the creamy yolks. Boyfriend ordered the special stuffed French toast, which was out of control. It was sweet and oddly savory at the same time-- tangy with cream cheese studded with brownie bits and Bailey's, blending the chocolate with creaminess. Then the fresh strawberries and blueberries brought a bright tart moment that melded with the berry cinnamon honey syrup. There were so so so many things right with this Master P's "Make 'Em Say MMMM..." Special French toast. 

Love Sabrina's-- from the food to the vibe, it's classic with an edge.

I like this WF more than the other one on South St. This one offers inside seating and it's a great place to chow down on your salad from the salad bar or sip on a coffee with a friend. The grocery offering are the same as other Whole Foods - pricey, but good quality. Love it here.

this is a great place to hang out with friends (on one of their 'comfy' couches) or  study (at one of their scattered tables). they make good sandwiches and serve la colombe coffee. play $3 for an ice coffee (after tipping) is a bit much for me, but if i am going to sit here for a couple of hours, it is totally worth it.

I only ever come here because this market is two blocks from my place. If I were feeling not-so-lazy, I would make the hike to Trader Joe's. The staff are nice and they offer a wide variety of produce and groceries, but you pay a hefty premium for its location.

It's a decent "A-for effort" type place. Has a bar, plenty of seating, and provides a nice alternative to driving to KOP or Suburban Square/Ardmore. Bonus: it's very close to Hope's. When I lived close by, I used to come here.
Not totally impressed with the service here, but as with all the other Fooderies, I really enjoy their grocery and beer offerings.
Such a reliable good beer shop! The guys at the register are always so friendly, and this place really does feel like a deli! Also like that they are open LATE on most days.
This place is so great. Love the fresh fruit flavor offerings that change up regularly. This place is a must visit if you are in south philly or walking through the Italian market.
Love that hits place is just a few blocks from my office - it's got great beer, a wonderful staff, and amazing food! A fantastic place in West Philly / 44th Street corridor.

This place is fine and good at what it does - upscale, farm-to-table type (not sure if this place is really farm to table??) dishes. It has a great happy hour and a friendly staff. The place is still around after this many years, so they must be doing something right. It's a place I would bring my parents (or in-laws) for a nice sit down dinner.

The service here is great, the bar is CLASSIC, their cocktails delicious. Only complaint was the overly salty food. But that may just have been an off night for them. I would definitely come back here. FYI, for couples, it's a great date place.

The service here really is great. I love Queen Village and I love this restaurant. I was here with some friends, who may or may not have been obnoxious (from New York) and I was worried, but in the end everything worked out. I was impressed with all the dishes we ordered!
Amazing beer. Delicious sandwiches. And adult sandwich combos! So glad they have a 'new' location so close to me.

They get 4 stars because it is a great study space. The coffee is ... okay, if you like whiny South American brews. I appreciate that they use CounterCulture beans, but I prefer a darker, more full bodied brew. Coffee aside, the baristas are always fantastic and friendly and chatty. I love that OCF is just down the street from me!

The dark chocolate sorbetto is an absolute miracle. I don't know how something so creamy can possibly be dairy-free. It is, hands-down, the best dark chocolate sorbet I've ever had. Top it with their to-die-for peanut butter sauce and, well, deliciousness overload. 

I've also had the gelato and it's always really good, the hubs particularly likes the chocolate hazelnut gelato. The cookies are also very good, especially the ricotta cookies. And the employees are all so friendly! I was initially sad when What's the Scoop left, but I really love this place.

Finally attended a Night Market last week in Mt. Airy. Definitely LOVED the idea of it, but as others have noted, the crowds were intense. Managed to try takoyaki from the Maru Global booth and homemade gnocchi from one of the Italian booths, both of which were very good. But by the time we finished waiting in those lines (both of which were pretty long already), ALL the rest of the lines were way too daunting to even consider standing in. Very fun event and tasty food, but more vendors to thin out the crowds would be nice! If we go to another one, we'll get there as soon as it opens and make a beeline for the booths we're most interested in.

My favorite local burger and not just because of all the organic, grass-fed beef, sustainability stuff (although that certainly helps). Elevation sauce is a winner. So is the balsamic mustard. Veggie burgers are tasty, and I don't even like veggie burgers. Shakes? SO GOOD. Love the olive oil shoestring fries too, as long as I'm not in the mood for really "meaty" fries. Great service as well.

Finally ate here, during the parents' recent visit. It's actually more like 3.5 stars, but since that's not an option and their bread and iced tea were both FANTASTIC, I will up them to 4 as opposed to dropping them to 3.

Other than the DEE-LICIOUS bread and the very refreshing iced tea, the pasta was tasty and there are a TON of choices. As you can see (read) from this review, nothing inspired me to poetry or anything like that, but it was good old-fashioned comfort food and I get the idea it's very solid/reliable/consistent. Plus, service was speedy and efficient during the lunch rush.

Capiche? Capiche.

Love this place! We take pottery classes with Carol and I take a yoga class - both are fantastic. All their classes look like fun and the shows and special events are really interesting too. The grounds are incredible - an old mansion the likes of which you don't see anymore. The yoga class is sometimes held in the old ballroom on the 2nd floor - amazing.

When my fiance told me we were going to dinner at Vietnam for a friend's birthday, I actually asked him what kind of food he thought they served. He was like, umm, Vietnamese food. Well, I thought maybe they had some sort of avant garde or ironic name and they were actually a hot dog place or something. You never know!

Anyway, this is my new favorite restaurant. We've been here twice now and it's ruined me for all other food. The beef with broken rice is like a drug. It's actually sort of gross how fast I consume it. The pork clay pot inspires similarly crude behavior. But the food is just so good!

We've also tried the Vietnamese ravioli, chicken with broken rice, and chicken clay pot. None of them disappointed, although none stood out as much as the two mentioned above.

But! For dessert! You can get corn pudding! And it tastes like the actual DEFINITION of 'delicious.' Seriously, you must try it.

Drinks are tasty, fun, and humorously-named. Service has been spotty. But the food! Oh yeah.

I don't often Yelp anymore but I feel bad that I've never reviewed Crossroads. Everything I've ever had here has been excellent. In particular: the ricotta cookies, the PB + honey + banana smoothie, the iced tropical green tea, and the caprese sandwich. Plus, the staff (I think it's a family?) is just fantastic. Very friendly, and once when I dropped my ricotta cookie I got a new one for free :) It's in a bank but the coffee shop still has Sunday hours, thank goodness. Love this place!

Bottom line: TERRIBLE service absolutely does not make up for the mediocre food.

Our party of 3 started with a wedge salad (the person who ordered it said it was good), lobster roll starter and Caesar salad (both of which were sub-par). For our entrees, two of us had the filet (one thought it was pretty good, though not comparable to other similarly-priced steakhouses, the other thought it was actively bad) and one had the porterhouse, which he ordered Pittsburgh rare. The server confirmed the restaurant did offer a Pittsburgh rare preparation, but it came out extremely overcooked.

After the steaks came out, the server was nowhere to be seen for most of the meal. By the time he returned to check in, the filets were long finished and our friend was almost done with the 28oz porterhouse, but he pointed out how overdone it was, and the server looked for himself and agreed. He apologized and called it a "party foul," but did not offer anything to make up for it. The manager never checked in on us after this complaint. And when we got our check, not a single thing had been comped - not one drink, not one dessert (which, for the record, was also sub-par), and certainly not the $56 steak, which hadn't even been discounted.

My friend could have made a stink and insisted he wouldn't pay for the steak, or that another one be prepared for him properly. He didn't. He was very gracious, and was not rewarded one bit for that graciousness. Why would we return to this restaurant after that?

As far as I can tell, the only reason to come here is because you're forced to pay to enter the Valley Forge Casino and want to use your dining credit to recoup that cost (which is what we were doing). But I'd highly recommend you use your dining credit at a cheaper restaurant, because this place is SO overpriced you'll end up feeling like an idiot for paying so much for the meal even after the dining credit is removed from the bill. It would be different if the food were worth the cost, but it's not, and the absolutely awful service seals the deal. There's no reason to come here when there are so many better steakhouses a stone's throw away.

Now THIS is an f'in ICE CREAM PARLOR. That's what I'm talking about. Yeah!

I just love the idea of ice cream parlors. But I'm not sure I'd ever actually been in one until now. This place really feels like a throwback. To what, I'm not sure. But to something faaaantastic.

The entire place smells like waffles. Amazing waffles. You should get one with your ice cream, and then come back and thank me because it was so good.

Chocolate marshmallow = best flavor ever. Peanut butter sauce = famazing. Marshmallow sauce = omgz. Yes. Everything is fantastic and you'll want to hang out here after you're done eating because it's fun. And also because if you hung out for long enough and got hungry again, you could order more ice cream.

The waitresses are nice too!

Oh my GAWD, I found a Jimmy John's here. I thought all was lost when I left Chicago.

Alright alright, I know they're a chain. Normally I hate chains. I really do. In fact, I absolutely refuse to eat at any other chain "deli."

But Jimmy John's is so tasty! Sometimes I dream about their ham sandwiches. Even the bread is yum! And the signs all over their stores are funny and highly entertaining if you're eating by yourself.

As if Hope's didn't already make some of the best "normal" cookies around, they now have SEASONAL PUMPKIN COOKIES?! My heart cries with joy every time I eat one. They're even better if you microwave them so they get all warm and gooey.

Oh my goodness. Been wanting to try this place ever since noticing it on my Yelp mobile app as a nearby hot spot. Finally did last week.

EVERYTHING. SO GOOD.

From the soups (crab bisque for the husband, cream of broccoli for me) to the bread to the phenomenal main courses, everything lived up to the hype.

I can see why everyone says the chicken dishes are the stand-outs - my husband's was incredible, and I don't normally like Italian chicken dishes - but I have to give a shout-out to the pasta dishes as well. I had gnocchi and my friend had spinach ravioli and OH. MY GOODNESS. 

My friend said the alfredo sauce on his ravioli was the best he's ever had, and he's had a lot of alfredo sauce.

Cannot believe this unassuming BYO is so good, but it really and truly is. COME HERE. Now.

This is one of those family pizza parlors you would have just LOVED coming to as a kid. In fact, you probably did come here as a kid. After your Little League game. And your sister didn't like pizza so she ordered the dinosaur chicken nuggets. And everyone drank root beer. And your parents gave you quarters to put in the little toy vending machines.

It's that sort of place, so it kinda made me happy just looking inside it, which was why we ate there. As it turns out though, the pizza is just OK.

This is where I shop when the Selene co-op in Media doesn't have what I'm looking for. (So, if you read my review of Selene, then you know I came here to get the basil and parmesan cheese for my pesto sauce.) It is bigger and more "normal" looking, and it has a much wider selection -- but the trade-off is there's not as big of an emphasis on "whole foods," etc. Still, they carry a lot of local stuff, and it's nice to be able to come here for something I need at the last-minute that Selene just doesn't have.

I LOVE their selection of cheese, produce, and cut flowers the most. Oh and the baked goods. Chocolate zucchini cupcake! Awesome.

FYI, it is much more expensive to become a member here (I think $300) compared to Selene, but I don't think there's an annual fee -- and you don't need to be a member to shop here.

This store is fun to shop in and good for you, too. Stop buying fake stuff at Pier 1 and come here instead, buy the real deal, and know that you're supporting fair trade. Then you'll feel awesome AND you'll have a cool wall hanging, table runner, purse, bar of soap, box of tea, or basically whatever it is you're looking for.

One day I decided to make pesto sauce the authentic way, which meant I needed a mortar and pestle. When the fiance came home and saw the mortar and pestle sitting on the table, he said, "Where did you get that?" and I said, "Where do you THINK I got it?" I love this store because every time I need something bizarre like that, I can pretty much come here and buy it.

And join the birthday club! 15% off in your birthday month!

Harry's is a true treasure shop -- I can't think of what else I'd call it. Resale shop sounds too boring; thrift shop too low-end. Yet it's not quite an antique store. It's just a great shop with one of almost everything. 

Not only is it lots of fun to look around, it's even more fun to buy stuff at. Prices are very affordable, especially in the basement where everything is 50% off. We found an old-fashioned sewing basket and school desk down there for insanely cheap. On the main floor, we've gotten deals on nice furniture, including the coolest red hurricane lamp I have ever seen and an old-fashioned settee from Strawbridge & Clothiers.

He has 3 garages full of more stuff in the back. Ask to look at his Polaroids, and if you like what you see he'll take you back there to look.

Last but not least, Harry himself is friendly, chatty, helpful, and always willing to strike a deal. The price you see listed is NEVER final, and if you're a female with a pick-up truck but lacking in the ability to life a huge piece of furniture into the back by yourself, he'll find a way to help you out.

Having Tea = one of those things I absolutely love, which the boy... hates? Well, maybe 'hates' is a strong word, but at best, he tolerates it. Which is why I chose Valentine's Day to strongarm him into taking me to the Lincoln Room... after all, it was Valentine's Day, right?! To his credit, he seemed to like it at least a little bit.

I, on the other hand, LOVED IT. Having tea is so great. I mean really. The tiny sandwiches, the scones, the fact that you get your own individual pot of tea. What's not to love?

Everything we tried was exquisite but the soup stood out. I had the potato leek and I was practically licking the bowl. I also appreciated the various flavors of scone--most tea places I've been to only have one kind, which is NOT nearly as exciting as getting to choose "chocolate toffee" which is exactly what I did at the Lincoln Room. It was probably one of the best scones ever, even if I did forget to order the Devonshire cream.

I loved the tea sandwiches, but the best part of anything having to do with tea sandwiches was watching the little girl at the table behind us, who seemed to be terrified of hers--even though they replaced the artichoke one with a strawberry jam and cream cheese sandwich, which sounded pretty good to me. 

And it goes without saying that the tea itself was awesome.

The one thing we had that was NOT awesome was the special cupcake. I was surprised. It looked good, but it was sort of dry. However, the other dessert we tried--croissant bread pudding--more than made up for that. WOW.

The Lincoln Room is small and a bit cramped, but cute and cozy and definitely worth a trip on a Saturday morning.

YAY for the mushroom festival! If you missed out this past weekend and didn't go, never fear, there's always next year. One of my favorite festivals ever because... hello, mushrooms. As far as the eye can see! Talula's Table has one of my favorite booths - mushroom risotto, mushroom spring rolls, mushroom soup, and this year mushroom mac & cheese, all phenomenal. 

There is a bunch of mushroom food, of course (hubs tried mushroom ice cream this year), but there's also your typical festival food (fried EVERYTHING) and other fun goodies - I discovered mozzarella-filled arepas this year, which, well, may be the perfect food.

And there are tons of interesting vendors, all-you-can-drink root beer, and of course, all the regular businesses on State St. which are always fun to browse around. And, needless to say, you can also buy all sorts of different types of mushrooms to take home.

Oh Cherry Hill Mall!

To be honest the 3 stars is mostly for the nostalgia factor. We came here a lot with my cousins when we were younger.

It's gone downhill from what I can tell. And the construction right now is pretty annoying.

But they DO have a dairy queen, so that's awesome.

Farm Fresh Express makes it SO easy to eat local, it's almost ridiculous that anyone WOULDN'T use them. Basically, FFE goes to the local producers for you, so all you have to do is order and pay. No excuses, people!

FFE offers basically EVERYTHING. All sorts of meat, dairy products, fruits and veggies, baked goods and mixes, dry goods, grains, snacks, juices, salad dressing... even non-food items like soap, or a very good cookbook for how to cook in season. I meant it when I said "everything." Products are clearly marked as "Local" (most), "Regional," "Domestic," or "Americas." I seriously love this place.

There's even a delivery service, although I live close enough not to use that. The bonus for going into the store is that you can see all the cool stuff that's not listed on their website, like ICE CREAM!

AND, they give you a free keychain with your first order. It does not get much better than this, people.

We learned of Coconut Breeze when they left a flier on our door, and I was immediately excited to see that they deliver. Up til now, the only places we could get delivery from in our area were pizza joints and crappy Chinese food restaurants. A Jamaican restaurant is a huge step up.

We've ordered from them 3 or 4 times now, and each time the food has been delicious. Stew beef (which they only serve on Fridays and Saturdays) is a favorite. We've also tried jerk chicken, curry chicken, and stew chicken and enjoyed them all (although all of them have bones; the stew beef is boneless). I'm no expert on Jamaican cuisine, but everything has been delicious and that's all I care about. The medium size meat orders come with two sides, and we've tried the rice & peas (good but very spicy), white rice, mac and cheese, broccoli, plantains, mashed potatoes, and candied yams. All of the above are very good but we keep coming back to the rice & peas, mashed potatoes (sooo creamy), mac and cheese, and plantains. 

They also have a number of dishes we've yet to try - fry chicken, a couple different kinds of wings, goat, oxtail, soup, chicken and beef patties, pepper steak, stew peas, cabbage & carrots, and a bunch of different types of seafood. Prices are great and delivery is fast.

I had to write this review after the exceptional customer service experience we had last night - after ordering stew chicken and stew beef, we got two orders of stew chicken. I called to let them know, and they were so apologetic (even though I wasn't mad at all - just craving stew beef!) and actually had the owner himself bring over the correct order. He let us keep the additional, wrong order and brought us candied yams to try (I assume they're new because they're not on the menu we have). 

We were already fans of the delicious food, but thanks to the fantastic customer service this will definitely remain a staple for us!

FRIED MACARONI AND CHEESE! Oh my gosh. It's so good. I don't care how bad for you it is. Yummmm.

Oh also, turns out I like the large size pizza better than the small. I don't know. It's just better somehow.

I should preface this by saying that we ate on the Deck, and it was the last day of the season. So, it was windy and cold and we were one of only a few tables... the staff was perhaps a bit less focused on us than they might have been had we eaten there sometime during the summer.

Still, the service was pretty bad. The food, however, was absolutely fantastic. Which is why I'm averaging out to 3 stars.

Our experience started out promisingly enough, waiter was nice, windguards made sitting outside extremely manageable, etc etc etc. However, most of the food we ordered? Arrived at the SAME time. We got our drinks and appetizers first, but everything else from bread and butter (which we had to specifically request) to soups and salads to side dishes and entrees... ALL came out simultaneously.

Of course it didn't fit on the table. Yeah, that's why it's normally served in courses, you know, the bread followed by the appetizers followed by the soups and salads followed by the entrees and side dishes? Nope, not this time. It was almost comical trying to fit everything. Some dishes ended up balanced precariously on the edge of the table. And, of course, lots of things ended up getting cold because we were absolutely overwhelmed with regard to what to eat first.

That said, the food was VERY good (when we got to it while it was hot). Standouts were the squash soup, burrata mozzarella appetizer, scallop BLT, and the absolutely HEAVENLY mashed potatoes. The steak was fantastic too, and my mom loved whatever non-steak item she ordered... I think it was chicken, although it might have been fish. The only thing we didn't like was the side of sweet potatoes, which were oddly spicy.

Our waiter disappeared frequently, came around only once every few decades, and took forever to bring the check, but he was a pleasant fellow and I'm sure his service is normally much better when it's not freezing outside. Bottom line, the bad service and the great food sort of balanced each other out. The only thing you should keep in mind if you're planning to eat on the deck is that the menu is virtually identical to the fancy indoor dining room, so you're not going to save any money -- but you won't be forced to dress formally!

They have like, A BILLION kinds of milkshakes. Okay, not really, but they have so many that I can't imagine I'll ever try them all. And I am obsessed with milkshakes, so Nifty Fifties automatically goes on my list of places I'm somewhat ashamed to love.

It's your standard '50s-themed diner, with lots and lots of neon. The food is OK. It's the beverage menu that's really impressive. In addition to their insane variety of shakes, they can also flavor your soda with any one of a trillion syrups, and they make EGG CREMES, which really satisfies my inner Harriet the Spy.

One weird thing is that everything costs extra. Like, if you order a hamburger, it will literally arrive in front of you as a meat patty and a bun. If you want lettuce, tomatoes, etc. it'll cost you 20 cents each. (Mustard and ketchup are provided free on the counter.) Still, it's cheap, so I guess you get what you pay for. The hot dogs are good, for hot dogs, and the chicken nuggets are made on-site.

They also have about a kajillion of those 25-cent vending machines, which totally rocks my socks.

Alright, so we are trying to eat healthy & local but we're still human (aka, lazy). At least we ordered from Secane last night instead of, say, Domino's (ew). And it was pretty good. Apparently it's my fiance's favorite nearby pizza joint. I thought the crust was nice and crispy, but the cheese was a little greasier than I would have liked. I'm rounding up to 4 stars but if there were halves, they'd get a 3.5.

BUT, if you get a small they wrap it up in a paper bag instead of putting it in a box. It's very old-fashioned and cool.

Cash or check only.

I'm conflicted in my feelings about the Whole Foods chain. On the one hand, the stores are a great resource for people who are trying to make smarter food choices. On the other hand, I'd still rather make my own personal smarter food choices at a locally-owned store. However, I appreciate that Whole Foods is generally recognized as socially and environmentally responsible.

I wish they offered more local food, though. It is nice to see the "origin" listed for the produce you're buying, but an awful lot of it is still from pretty far away. For more info on this, see Michael Pollan's writings.

In any case, I still enjoy strolling around a Whole Foods as much as the next guy. I came to this one specifically because they carry the Diva Cup, which you should probably not look up if you're a man. But if you're a woman, you should check it out. And I'd like to give this Whole Foods an extra star for carrying that product, but then I'd probably subtract a star for how small the store is. Everything seems very cramped.

Bottom line? I'd definitely shop here before I'd shop at the Giant down the street.

OH LORD do I HATE this movie theater. It's the closest one to us but I will definitely go out of my way to avoid it. Allow me to recap for you 3 out of the 3 experiences I have had there:

1. Baby crying behind us for the entire movie. At a showing of "Iron Man," no less. Not exactly a film I'd take a baby to see. Oh WAIT! That's right, I wouldn't take a baby to see ANY movie that wasn't INTENDED for babies, because I wouldn't want to annoy my fellow patrons! Helloooo, that's what babysitters are for. If you don't have the money for a babysitter, you shouldn't be at a movie theater. Period. If you absolutely must watch "Iron Man" with your baby, do the rest of us a favor and RENT IT.

2. People mumbling loudly behind us during "Indiana Jones." With both this and the first example, the theater staff refused to do anything other than pop their head in the door and then leave (even though we complained numerous times).

3. The last time I was there was definitely the "best" time, but there came a point in the movie we were watching where a "twist" occurred. Except it was super-predictable and whatever. Still entertaining, but not exactly surprising. But I SWEAR TO GOD! Everyone else in the theater took that moment as, like, permission to start having all sorts of conversations. "WHOA! So he was leaving a trail the entire time? Seriously, he's a bad guy? Oh wow, I didn't see that coming!" LOUDLY. I mean, I'm glad that you were surprised by this shocking "twist" and all, but keep it to YOURSELF!

I realize that people talk in every theater, but I truly believe it's worse in this one. It's like an epidemic, and the staff is not AT ALL helpful. All in all, not worth it considering the theaters themselves are small and nothing to write home about. I'm through with this place.

Alright, so I made a list called "Beyond Trader Joe's." But Trader Joe's isn't so bad, and this one is particularly cute. I wouldn't buy my produce here, but there's a lot of other fun stuff, such as:

- Super absorbent kitchen cloths to replace paper towels
- Lavender sachets for the dryer to replace dryer sheets
- Healthier versions of the standard mac-and-cheese-in-a-box, brownies-from-a-mix, etc.
- Cocoa powdered dark chocolate covered almonds. I don't think these will help save the environment in any way, but they are really tasty!

Plus I like their grocery-drawing mentioned by another reviewer (bring your own reusable bags!) and the building the store is housed in is pretty cool too.

I just don't like their pizza. It's greasy AND floppy. A no-win situation as far as I'm concerned.

But to each his own. Everyone else who's ever lived at this house seems to like it just fine. Could be because it's down the street, though.

Well, not 2 days after I met someone who told me NEVER to take a pet to this place, our dog had a late-night emergency and this was the closest vet's office that was open.

Obviously, I was braced for the worst. But the receptionist was friendly and efficient and we got in right away. We were seen by a vet tech and, later, the on-call veterinarian in fairly quick succession. 

I didn't absolutely love the vet's bedside manner, and I found myself wishing on more than one occasion that we were at our own familiar vet's office, because I know our vet would have been much more comforting. But in the end, all that really matters is he did the surgery quickly and successfully and basically saved our dog's life. So you can't complain too much about that!

Post-op, I appreciated the fact that they were fairly communicative and that they have visiting hours for you to come see your pet. However, on the 2nd day after her surgery, they were much less communicative and it was hard to get a definite answer on whether or not we could bring her home. Still, all in all, it was not a bad experience by any means. I'm glad to know Old Marple will be here in the future, although I hope we don't need them again!
This is the best pet store I have ever shopped in. Organic treats, natural and healthy food, biodegradable doggy bags, a cat toy shaped like President Bush? You have got to come here.

I just bought a bike here and I couldn't be happier. They carry the Electra brand, which is fantastic for a person like me who is a teensy bit gun-shy when it comes to "getting back on the horse." Flat-foot technology, minimal shifting... plus, Electra makes adorable baskets and bells!

The sales staff is super nice and helpful, and you can ride the bike around a nearby empty parking lot if you want to try it out first. They even offer layaway if you're also feeling a bit gun-shy about paying for the bike!

For some reason my dad took to calling this place "Mayonnaise Burger," I guess because the first time we met here for dinner the ratio of burger to mayo was so perfectly done and delicious? And though it did become one of our favorite places to meet for dinner while I was in college (conveniently located as it is between a movie theater and a bookstore), it never quite recaptured the glory of that first visit.

3.50 stars.  

Gabby's wasn't open.  I knew that.  Neither was Rotier's.  But my handy Yelp app had assured me that Fido's was open.  Imagine the disappointment when I realized there was a very real possibility that no burgers would happen on this trip down to the Deep South.  Would I really have to wait two more weeks when I would find solace in East Texas?   

"We can try Burger up," I mentioned.  

"Why don't you just call them?" hissed the appropriately nicknamed Viper.  

True.  We didn't have to keep driving around aimlessly.  So I call Burger Up, and a very pleasant, sweet voice assures me they are indeed open.  

Viper: "What was her name?  She sounded hot."
  
Me: "Paige."

Viper: "Yeah, she's definitely hot.  Have you ever met an unattractive Paige?"

Me: "Good point.  At least we have that going for us."

Paige was indeed attractive, but this review isn't about a photogenic individual who happens to work at Burger Up.  It's about what ended up being a visit to our fourth choice for burgers in Nashville.  

Burger Up follows a national trend towards upscale burgers.  My particular order consisted of a medium rare patty served with aged cheddar, Benton's bacon (very good), and ketchup served on an artisan bun.  Basically, it was a gussied up bacon cheeseburger, but it was a rather tasty one.  My major complaint is that I wish the actual meat itself exhibited more flavor.  Having said that, the burger was cooked properly and the flavors worked well together.  I ordered some wilted spinach on the side (mediocre) and truffle fries.  Let's talk about those truffle fries for a bit.  I know more people are apparently into the sweet potato fries here, but I think they are missing the boat.  Burger Up's truffle tries have pleasant aroma, taste great, and are the perfect texture for soaking up oil.  If you are on a diet, it is true you should skip these delightful fries.  But if that were the case, why are you at a burger joint in the first place?  Seriously, if you get nothing else out of my review, please do yourself a favor and order the truffle fries.  

Burger Up also boast an interesting beer menu with semi-obscure breweries from the Deep South included in the list.  I tried a pecan-infused amber from Mississippi - not bad.  I could imagine Burger Up could be a decent place to drink for a bit after eating.  

If I attended Vanderbilt, I would probably go here on a moderately frequent basis.  If you want a change from the dive bar hamburger, Burger Up is a decent change of pace.

3.50 stars.  I was told to go here for the shrimp and grillades (grits) and fried chicken, but I ended up loving the gumbo more than anything.  Located in Mid-City, Li'l Dizzy's is a cozy diner serving up an all you can eat breakfast/lunch consisting of fried chicken, trout, shrimp creole, rice & beans, grits, gumbo, omelettes made to order, fruit, and maybe a few other items as well.  It was all pretty standard until I reached the gumbo.  

Li'l Dizzy's gumbo is heavenly.  They don't hold back on either the sausage or the seafood as you have generous cuts of andouille sausage and crab legs in the wonderfully thick dark brown soup.  They got the flavor so perfect I felt no need to add any tabasco to my order.  I'd definitely come back here for the gumbo.  

Overall, you have plenty of options for breakfast/lunch in this city, and Li'l Dizzy's is a good one if you are in Mid-City.  It's a great option if you just want a cup of gumbo.

I'm in love with the "hot chicken" concept, and I hope it goes national.  Nashville's unique contribution to Southern cooking entails the preparation of fried chicken basted in a fiery combination of peppers and spices that absolutely will send you running to the closest fire hydrant to squelch the burning sensation where your lips and tongue once resided.  Mr. Bolton will make you hot chicken from almost any part of the bird, and he will even do it with chicken tenders should you choose (which comes with the welcome addition of ranch sauce to alleviate some of the heat).  I opted for wings and a call to the fire department.  

Aside from the heat, it should be mentioned that Bolton's approach favors flavor.  The wings themselves were fried perfectly and reminded me why I frequently hold my head in only mildly feigned agony when eating "Southern food" in places like my current hometown of Washington DC.  The green beans at Bolton's, flavored liberally with bacon, were so impressive that I ended up ordering green beans at nearly every single restaurant and dive that I visited in Nashville.  I assumed it was a Nashville thing; I was wrong -- it is a Bolton's thing.  Maybe some pseudo-celebrity chef should visit Bolton's and say it was the best thing (s)he ever had; it certainly was the case for me when it comes to green beans.  The mac-n-cheese is also very nice with heavy use of white cheddar and liberal amounts of black pepper.  If you like a "bready" mac-n-cheese, this is probably not your style.  I thought it was delicious.  

Mr. Bolton himself was an appreciate and friendly man who probably should have been annoyed that two rather inebriated individuals were awkwardly ordering (ex. me: what's the one that is hot chicken?  Bolton: i can make any of them hot chicken?  me: ok, i'm confused now) but he helped us out anyhow.  I know Nashville loves this business, but if I ever find out how to teleport people, Mr. Bolton is coming to Washington DC.  But at least you got my lack of an advanced degree in any engineering on your side.  Outside of a moment of idiot savant-like genius on my part, you are probably safe.  

Finally, although it rarely happens, there are a few somewhat misguided reviews that lament that the chicken wasn't spicy enough when they ordered MILD or make similarly obvious patently illogical complaints.  There is a saying that the inability to appreciate the Mona Lisa speaks more about the criticizers than the actual work.  I feel the same way about the plebeian fools that dare to defile a culinary gift from the Gods (or, in this case, a gift from the able hands of Mr. Bolton and his staff).  Bolton's is divine and is a foodie must for anyone visiting Nashville.  Unless you are vegetarian or hate chicken, to visit Nashville and not try hot chicken from Bolton's is about as despicable as going to Vanderbilt and cheering for the University of Tennessee.  It simply should not happen under any circumstances.  As for locals, if you haven't been here, then I would highly recommend that you support this culinary gem of a local business.

While I will readily admit that gelato isn't exactly my first love, I can still appreciate the obvious work that goes into the preparation of the creations at Capogiro.  First and foremost, like Jeff W. and Michelle P. point out in their respective reviews, the actual substance is unparalleled within the frozen dairy industry (even surpassing the treats at DC's beloved Dairy Godmother) and the consistency in unmatched as well.  Second, the breadth of flavors is impressive.  While I was enjoying a more traditional Bacio, some of my dining companions were getting gelato spiked with all sorts of Thai spices and exotic fruits.  I commend Capogiro for providing both options.  Third, the price point is correct.  While spending $4-7 certainly may seem expensive for gelato, the generosity of the serving size is beyond reasonable debate.   Finally, I thought the individuals working the counter were quite patient with our group (which consisted of both grizzled Capogiro veterans and first time visitors).  The bottom line is that gelato is rarely a destination point; this is one of those rare spots that bends all your existing paradigms and rewrites them in an entirely positive fashion.  If you are in Philadelphia, it's worth a visit.

3.25 stars.  I always think of those old Road Runner/Wiley Coyote when I see the word "ACME" so I was rather hesitant based on simple nomenclature when we happened upon this branch of the famous New Orleans eatery.  In fairness, I eschewed the local specialty (the charbroiled oysters) in favor of fried oysters and seafood gumbo.  The fried oysters were quite good; the light, flavorful, and slightly spicy coating taking precious little flavor away from each underlying oyster.  The seafood gumbo was likewise a solid offering combining generous portions of backfin crab meat and shrimp with a satisfying roux.  I would have loved jumbo crab meat or plump shrimp especially at this price point, but the food was undeniably tasty.  Overall, I wouldn't call this destination cuisine, but then again, I haven't tried the charbroiled oysters.

4.25 stars.  Yes, it's absolutely touristy.  Yes, the trashy shitshow that is Bourbon Street spills off of the street and directly into this venue on a regular basis.  But if there is a better karaoke experience than Cat's Meow anywhere in the country, I've yet to see it.   

Now I've seen some people complain about the drinks here but Cat's Meow knows its audience.  Namely, the idea of serving drinks in glass is simply a terrible idea when you have patrons so obviously beyond their usual limits.  To wit, by the time we reached the second floor to take a Roman Colosseum view of the events below, two girls from a bachelorette party - one the bride and another an aging bleached blonde with a silicone chest - were fighting for crowd attention and eventually each other (silicone kicked the bride on the karaoke floor!).  No one wants glass in a venue like that.  

By the way, if you don't particularly care to karaoke or dance, may I strongly suggest this second floor?  From our original vantage point, you get a bird's eye view of all the lunacy.  For example, we watched a horrific breakup (the girl grabbed another man's you know what right in front of her man), people falling on stage, the best drunk dancing ever, and the obligatory drunk people coupling from the balcony.   

The range of songs offered by Cat's Meow is quite good.  But what really makes the event are the MC's who bring the party back every single time after a bad song.  These dudes can sing, dance and are pretty much a bachelorette's dream as they are pretty sculpted too.  Their ability to bring energy back into a place is borderline magical.  

It was my friend's b-day, and I was proud that she left the second floor and was having fun dirty dancing with the MC's.  Eventually, all of us participated in either dancing or singing, and just had a great overall time.  

If you're looking for a place where you're encouraged to leave your inhibitions behind in a positive manner, Cat's Meow is the appropriate tonic.

3.75 stars.  Conjure up images of New Orleans and at some point you are going to think of the humble "poor boy" sandwich (po' boy) consisting of a soft French style baguette, lettuce and onions, and a fried seafood interior.  At Domilise, you can get a number of these sandwiches (including the popular roast beef with debris gravy), but I went ahead and stuck with the seafood versions (if you order the half and half, you get a shrimp po' boy and an oyster one as well).  

Everyone has their favorite po' boys (mine happens to be at Darrell's in Lake Charles, LA), and I'll say Domilise is solid.  Both the shrimp and the oyster are satisfying, and you can get them dressed to your liking.  For essentially 12 dollars, you are served a rather generous sandwich.  This little shop is rightfully famous, but I'm still saying the best ones I've ever had are outside New Orleans.  

Still, that isn't to say you shouldn't come here (or Killer Po Boys or Guy's up the street or Parkway or really any other awesome po' boy in the city).  You will receive an extremely satisfying sandwich here and you'll even get some friendly service and LSU love from the people who operate it.   It's worth a visit if you are in New Orleans.

The restaurant had a nice atmosphere and the interior was decorated nicely.  But that's about where the impressiveness ends. The service didn't wow us but it was fine - no complaints.

The food choices are where the confusion sets in. The restaurant seems unsure as to what it wants to be.

Rode's has an extensive menu which is always a little concerning in terms of freshness and specialties. There is certainly something for everyone but nothing is amazing. When you are serving everything from chicken wings to filet mignon, it's difficult to specialize in everything.

I saw some previous comments about being overpriced and I would agree. At first, I thought things seemed reasonable but after eating I determined that the prices match the overall environment, but not the actual food. Despite the nice décor, I would consider this glorified bar food. It tries to be "upscale" but misses the mark. Example: we get a basket of bread wrapped in a cloth napkin, always a treat.....except in this case, unfolding the napkin reveals grocery-store baguette that hasn't even been warmed served with rock hard pats of cold butter. (I can do this at home.)

A real bakery, not just one of those places that bakes a million kinds of cookies. This place has lot so specialties and all are delicious. Be ware, once you enter the amazing smell inside the bakery will have you buying half the store.

Downside is that it is expensive. But you get what you pay for!

Really great food and amazing service. I have ordered take out from here several times and it never disappoints. Recently, David & Sons filled a special order for me for an item not on their menu and it turned out amazing. They saved my Easter brunch. So glad to have such high quality food in our area. Thank you David & Sons!

While I like the food this place cannot read an order correctly. They messed up my order last week and then refused to redeliver the food. Luckily, I ordered online so the website took care of the issue and reimbursed me. Who doesn't re-deliver? You gave me something I didn't ask for and then won't correct the mistake? How strange.

Ordered again this week, different item, and same thing. I asked for no cheese and added garlic, I got no garlic and lots of cheese. So, needless to say, this place is out. Too much hassle for me. Ordering food is supposed to be easy.

Family was in town Saturday and we wanted to have a nice meal somewhere. Being new to the area, we took a chance on Tavro. 

Having just moved from Philly's amazing restaurant scene, my expectations were limited for a small town restaurant. But Tavro 13 was exactly what we were looking for. Trendy/funky interior with a nice ambiance, although the place was fairly empty for a Saturday night. We ate in the dining room, but there is a bar on the other side. 

The food was worth every penny, absolutely delicious. We ordered filet mignon, chicken, and pork dishes and everyone was impressed but how good the food was. It's a great spot to  take out of town guests to. It's on the pricey side but, again, very worth it.

To note, the sign outside the restaurant says Red Hen (Rooster?) Inn. Not exactly sure what that's about since the menu's still have Tavro written on them.

Definitely will be back!

After coming here a couple of times, I can honestly say it's my new favorite nail salon for pampering. Particularly for the amazing pedicure. They really take their time with each step and give an amazing massage. Not the place to come if you need to be in and out quick, but if you want to be pampered, this is it. It lost a star because I haven't gotten a consistently good nail polish job here. Sometimes it's uneven or too thick.
